nodes.title: Circular from CBDT regarding linking Aadhaar card and PAN card.
Regarding hands-on training on the I-Got portal
कंत्राटी कामांचा व त्यासाठी नेमलेल्या कामगारांचा विमा शासकीय विमा निधीकडे उतरविणेबाबत.
पुणे महानगरपालिका कामगार कल्याण निधीमार्फत माध्यमिक व उच्च माध्यमिक परिक्षेमध्ये उत्तम यश संपादन केलेल्या पुणे मनपा अधिकारी/सेवकांच्या पाल्यांचा गुणगौरव समारंभासाठी अर्ज मागविणेबाबत.
Regarding the resignation of Shri. Vinayak Mahipatrao Patil, Clerk Typist, Road Department from the service of Pune Municipal Corporation.
Order - Regarding temporary promotion from the post of Junior Engineer (Mechanical) Class-3 to the post of Deputy Engineer (Mechanical) Class-2 in the Engineering Cadre
Regarding the appointment of Shri.Shrikant Dattatary Shedage to the post of Clerk-Typist Class-3 based on educational qualifications as per the recommendations of the Hon.Lad/Page Committee
transfer of an officer holding the position of "Superintending Engineer" (Civil) (Class-1) within the Engineering cadre.

Regarding technical quality inspection of development works being developed by various departments of Pune Municipal Corporation through a third party organization, M/s Engineers India Limited (Government of India undertaking).
Regarding the Report of the Clerk - typists who have been transferred periodically to the Pune Municipal Corporation establishment.
Regarding sending nominations for the basic residential program of Class-4 employees under the State Training Policy during the period from 21st July 2025 to 26th July 2025.
Regarding the departments under the control of the Additional Municipal Commissioner (General), Additional Municipal Commissioner (Estate), and Additional Municipal Commissioner (Special)
Regarding organizing a meeting of the members appointed in the committee established for the basic amenities of the newly included villages within the Pune Municipal Corporation limits.
Regarding the training of Pune Municipal Corporation’s website (http://pmc.gov.in) under the Maharashtra Government’s 150-Day Planning Framework Program.
Regarding deduction of the annual membership fee of Rs.300/- from the salary of the member employee.
Regarding appointment of Shri.Sagar Vasnat Malpote to the post of Peon, Class-4 as per the recommendations of the Hon'ble Lad/Page Committee as per educational qualification.
Regarding appointment of Shri.Nilesh Balkisan Yamul to the post of Peon, Class-4 as per the recommendations of the Hon'ble Lad/Page Committee as per educational qualification.
Regarding the incompleteness of the currency deposited in the Bank of Maharashtra from various accounts of Pune Municipal Corporation.
Action to be taken regarding spraying of insecticide in accordance with the complaint of mosquitoes in the main building of Pune Municipal Corporation.

Third place in the urban category of the fifth National Water Awards

raw.title: Pune Okayama Japanese Style Friendship Garden
raw.address: Sr. No. 537, Sinhagad Road, Pune
raw.body:
Pune Okayama friendship garden is a symbol of Indo-Japanese friendship between partner cities of Pune and Okayama and the garden is truly the pride of Pune. It is the biggest Japanese style garden, out of Japan, in Asia. The idea of recreating the original Japanese garden in Pune was, of course, inspired from the 300-year old Okayama Korakuen Garden developed by the Ikeda Royal family in the 12 spacious hectares in Okayama

The Japanese garden is spread over an area of 10 acres, representing the culture and intricate ideology of an authentic Japanese Garden. This garden is a perfect bridge between to cities of Okayama and Pune, encouraging cultural, traditional, economic, industry and friendship ties.

The garden is named after eminent Marathi litterateur Purushottam Laxman Deshpande, who was popularly known as Pu La Deshpande.
raw.entry_details:
• For children: ₹5
  • For adults: ₹10
  • Monthly pass: ₹100
  • For foreign nationals: ₹50

    Open all 7 days
raw.key_attractions:
• Harmonious Experience: The garden is planned in such a way that it gives the visitors a pleasing experience throughout the year. As a person strolls, he/she can enjoy the wide lawns, ponds, artificial hills, and forest, while listening to the murmur of a meandering stream. This brings one close to nature, revitalizes one's senses, and rejuvenates one spiritually. Characteristics of the garden are a composition of fire, harmony, line, spirit, world, and water. Thus, the garden expresses various elements, such as light and darkness, soft and hard, stillness and motion, and warm and cold.  There are wooden pergolas to sit and rest. There are bright red-orange fish in the ponds.
  • Unique Japanese Garden Theme: The only Japanese garden in India, inspired by the culture and concept of Japanese gardens.
  • Design Based on Zen Philosophy: Modeled after the Koraquan Garden in Okayama, Japan.
  • Grand Greenery: Lush, expansive greenery throughout the park.
  • Large Pond: A tranquil pond filled with multi-colored fishes.
  • Serpentine Streams: Flowing streams that enhance the natural beauty.
  • Diverse Bird Population: Home to numerous crows, other birds, and insects.
  • Indigenous and Foreign Trees: A mix of native and exotic tree species.
  • Six Pagodas: Beautiful pagodas made of mahogany wood.
  • Mesmerizing Waterfalls: Scenic waterfalls adding to the park's charm.
  • Open Surroundings: A peaceful environment that helps relieve tension.
raw.timings:
• Morning 6:00 AM to 11:00 AM
  • Evening 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM

raw.title: Saras Baug
raw.address: Sr. No. 138 Pai, Sadashiv Peth, Pune
raw.body:
Sarasbaug is a major landmark in the city of Pune in India. The place where the park now stands was once occupied by a small lake. However, the lake dried up and was later developed into Sarasbaug. The whole 25-acre complex is known as Sarasbaug. Sarasbaug is a historic and beautiful spot built in 1750 by Shrimant Nanasaheb Peshwe.  In 1784, Shrimant Madhavrao Peshwe build the famous Talyatil Ganpati temple, dedicated to Lord Siddhi Vinayak. The Ganesh temple in Saras Baug is also known as Talyatla Ganapati (in Marathi: तळ्यातला गणपती ) which translates as the Ganapati of the lake.

Today, Sarasbaug has lovely gardens, fountains, a jogging track, lotus flowers, and a memorial for martyrs. It’s a peaceful place loved by families, tourists, and devotees alike. Visit to enjoy nature, history, and calmness!
raw.key_attractions:
• Artificial Pond: Built by Shrimant Nanasaheb Peshwe in 1750 AD, covering an area of 25 acres, initially used for boating and swimming elephants.
  • Siddhi Vinayak Temple: Established by Shrimant Madhavrao Peshwe in 1784, featuring the deity with a right-turned trunk.
  • Talyatil Ganpati: The temple's unique location surrounded by the pond and garden makes it popular among tourists and devotees.
  • Memorial of Martyrs: A tribute to martyrs located within the area.
  • Navloba Temple: A historic temple included in the attractions.
  • Majestic Fountains: Beautiful, leaping fountains enhance the visual appeal.
  • Grand Meadow: A spacious and picturesque green space.
  • Lotus Flowers in the Pond: Adding natural beauty to the surroundings.
  • Jogging Track: A recreational path for fitness enthusiasts.
raw.timings:
• Morning 6:00 AM to 11:00 AM
  • Evening 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM

raw.title: Peshwe Energy Garden and Adventure Park
raw.address: Sr. No. 138 Pai, Sadashiv Peth, Pune
raw.body: It has been named after the Peshwas who were prime ministers to the kings and owners of the Parvati area. The park is located adjacent to the Sarasbaug garden and in the vicinity of the Parvati temple hill.
raw.key_attractions:
• Adventure Park for Children: Previously the area was part of a lake that was subsequently converted into a garden. The Peshwe Park is now called ‘Peshwe Adventure Park', especially after the induction of 50 types of adventure sports games/activities like net climbing, walk rope climbing, wall climbing, grappling, tower climbing, balancing, high altitude cycling, rope skidding, crossing the pond on a rope, etc. are just name of few (for 3-16 age group).
  • Educational Models: Pune Municipal Corporation has attempted to increase the general awareness regarding the importance and the need of non-conventional sources of energy. Educational models of solar energy, hydel energy and biogas energy projects are presented which provide information about their basic concepts to young minds.
  • Halls of Energy Generation: Educational displays showcasing traditional energy methods.
  • Children's Playground: A fun and safe area for kids to play.
  • Natural Pond: A peaceful pond enhancing the park’s tranquility.
  • Pagoda in the Pond: A picturesque pagoda located in the center of the pond.
  • Phulrani (Flower Garden): A vibrant garden full of colorful flowers.
  • Boating Facility: Offering boating experiences on the pond.
  • Confluence of Sports and Training: A unique blend of recreational sports and educational training activities.
raw.timings:
• Morning 10:00 AM to Afternoon 1:00 PM
  • Afternoon 2:00 PM to Evening 6:00 PM
  • ( Wednesday weekly holiday )

raw.title: Chhatrapati Sambhaji Raje Garden
raw.address: Jangali Maharaj Road, Pune - 411004 (Adjust to Balgandharva Natyagruha)
raw.body:
Chatrapati Sambhajiraje Garden built by Pune Municipal Corporation flaunts the Aquarium of freshwater ornamental fishes, which was set up on 1st Aug 1952. The aquarium at the garden is loved by kids as it serves the educational as well as entertainment purpose for them. A garden is a perfect place for children, young as well as for seniors. It also offers a mini fort & big fountain which attract kids as well as elders. The big fountain located at the centre of the park enhances the beauty of the surroundings with its sparkling showers. The park has also created a special play park which attracts the children around the city.
Exercise lovers enjoy the plenty of space and jogging track at the garden. We find the people resting under the cool shades of tall green trees during the daytime. A variety of colourful flower plants soothes eyes and the lovely fragrance tickles nostrils. The green and a well-maintained garden are watered by a sprinkler system. This system helps to keep the garden green all year around.
raw.key_attractions:
• Aquarium: A small aquarium where all the aquatic world lovers can take the pleasure of watching the variety of fishes. The aquarium mainly appeals to the kids.
  • Rare Trees: Mani Mohar, Rudraksha, Kailaspati, Golden bottle brush, Bhadraksh, Sitaashok , Kanchan are some of the rare trees that are housed in the garden.
  • Statues: Features statues of famous personalities like singer Ramchandra Ganesh Kundgolkar (Sawai Gandharva) and dramatist Ram Ganesh Gadkari.
  • Shivmandir: A temple dedicated to Lord Shiva.
  • Fountains: Beautiful fountains add charm to the garden.
  • Pagodas: Recreation spaces with pagodas.
  • Historical Tank: A tank with historical significance.
  • Imaginary Fort: A creatively designed fort structure.
  • Lakshmi Idol: A well-crafted idol of Goddess Lakshmi.
  • Exhibitions: The Pune Municipal Corporation organizes some remarkable exhibitions in the garden every year. The flower exhibition and fort exhibition are the prime attractions during Diwali. At this time, the exhibition showcases the miniatures of various forts. In this exhibition, participants construct the forts by traditional techniques. Best fort is honored by prize.

  • A grand event for environment lovers, drawing around two lakh visitors from across Maharashtra.
raw.timings:
Garden Timings:

  • Morning: 6:00 AM to 11:00 AM
  • Evening: 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM

    Open all 7 days

Aquarium Timings:

  • Morning: 8:00 AM to 11:00 AM
  • Evening: 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM

( Wednesday weekly holiday )

raw.title: Late Yashwantrao Chavan Garden (Seven Wonder Theme Park)
raw.address: Sr. No. 82, Parvati Darshan, Pune.
raw.body:
Established in 1993 and covering an area of 8,000 square meters, the Seven Wonders Park offers a unique opportunity to experience some of the most famous landmarks of the world right in the heart of the city. The park features replicas of iconic structures such as the Taj Mahal, the Great Pyramids of Giza, the Leaning Tower of Pisa, Stonehenge, and the Colosseum, allowing visitors, especially students, to fulfill their curiosity about these global wonders.

The park also provides engaging 3D and 4D shows, offering an immersive experience that brings these wonders to life. For children, there are plenty of playthings and recreational activities to enjoy. With its fascinating blend of education and entertainment, the park is a popular destination for families and tourists alike, offering a fun and informative visit to some of the world's greatest architectural marvels.
raw.key_attractions:
• Replicas of Global Landmarks: Includes the Taj Mahal, Great Pyramids of Giza, Leaning Tower of Pisa, Stonehenge, and the Colosseum.
  • 3D and 4D Shows: Immersive experiences that bring the wonders to life.
  • Playthings for Kids: Fun recreational activities and play areas for children.
  • Educational Value: Offers an informative visit, especially for students curious about world history and architecture.
  • Family-Friendly: A perfect destination for families and tourists to explore and learn about the world's wonders.
raw.timings:
• 6:00 AM to 11:00 AM

  • 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM
     

    Open all 7 days

raw.title: Kamala Nehru Park Garden
raw.address: Survey No. 223, Plot No. P, Bhandarkar Road, Erandwane, Pune
raw.body:
Kamala Nehru Park, built in 1956, is named after the wife of India’s first Prime Minister, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru. Since its establishment, the park has blossomed into a lush green space, making it a perfect retreat for nature lovers.

The park offers a serene environment for relaxation, with well-maintained gardens and ample greenery, providing a peaceful escape from the city's hustle and bustle. It's a popular destination for both locals and tourists seeking a tranquil spot to enjoy nature
raw.key_attractions:
• Children's Playground: Dedicated play area for kids.
  • Fountain: Enhancing the beauty of the garden.
  • Recreation Center: Space for leisure activities.
  • Garden of Poems: A unique garden themed around poetry.
  • Replica of Nat Aeroplane: A model of the victorious Nat aircraft from the Indo-Pak war.
  • Jogging Track: Perfect for fitness enthusiasts.
raw.timings:
• 6:00 AM to 11:00 AM
  • 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM

    Open all 7 days

raw.title: Lumbini Garden
raw.address: Survey No. 191A, Maharashtra Housing Board, Yerwada, Pune 411006
raw.body:
This garden was established in 2011, this beautifully designed garden draws inspiration from Lumbini, Nepal, the revered birthplace of Gautam Buddha. It offers visitors a tranquil space to reflect and unwind. The park is adorned with life-like depictions of pivotal scenes from Gautam Buddha's life, allowing visitors to immerse themselves in his teachings and journey. Impressive statues, including a grand bronze sculpture, add to the garden's spiritual essence.

For recreation, the garden features a jogging track, a children’s play area, and a serene pavilion (pagoda) that invites quiet moments of contemplation. The serene atmosphere, combined with lush greenery, makes this garden a perfect destination for those seeking peace, inspiration, and a deeper connection to nature.
raw.key_attractions:
• Nice and well-developed garden with ample space for walking, meditation, and exercise.
  • jogging track and pagoda facility is available for citizens.
  • Theme of garden is based on lord Buddha’s life. and on that basic name of garden is given as “LUMBINI GARDEN”
  • There is a fountain in garden which is designing in rose palet shape.
  • There is Different types of Sculpture of Lord Buddha is created in garden which is based on his life.
  • Beautiful surroundings with lush greenery and sculptures depicting the life of Buddha.
  • Different types of trees and shrubs also make garden more beautiful, well maintained shaped trees.

raw.title: Late Sanjay Mahadeo Nimhan Gram Sanskruti Garden
raw.address: S. No. 8, Someshwarwadi, Pashan, Pune
raw.body: To evoke the image of India's rural culture, Village Park near Someshwar Wadi has been constructed. It is a replica of rural India, offering visitors an immersive experience of traditional village life. The park showcases life-size models of a Gram Panchayat, Patil Wada, traditional cattle sheds, and farming tools, capturing the essence of rural culture, agriculture, and heritage. Visitors can enjoy vibrant scenes of bhajan, kirtan, a village school, and wedding ceremonies, alongside models of wild animals in natural habitats. The park's serene environment, complemented by the Someshwar Temple and riverbank, provides a peaceful escape from urban life, making it a must-visit for tourists seeking a glimpse into rural India.
raw.key_attractions:
Village Management Representation -  Its main goal is to give an overall experience of village life including various traditions, customs, festivals and events. The garden depicts structure of village and life cycle of village populace In Maharashtra,12 balutedarand 18 a/utedar mutually complement village management. This characteristic is reflected in garden landscaping with Huge village border (Gaonwesh) and PatilWada, and they are the most attractive places in the garden.

Village Business Representation -  The garden gives experience of village business, life cycle and costumes through 68 different themes. A total of 555 statues including those of blacksmith, barber, cobbler, goldsmith, astrologer, tailor, farmer, carpenter and so on are at the Village Park, and the expressions of these personality statues are created wonderfully.

Traditional farming practices, cowshed and village market are attractively designed and represented. It has a temple where religious programmes are held daily. It also features one of the greatest religious movements of India, the Palkhi. A Panchayat with Tanta Mukti Kendra, where disputes of villagers are solved mutually, is also depicted.
raw.timings:
• Morning 10:00 AM to Evening 8:00 PM

    Open all 7 days

raw.title: Shahid Major Pradeep Tathawade Garden
raw.address: Sr. No. 61/1A/1, Karve Nagar, Pune.
raw.body:
Major Pradeep Tathawade Udyan is a major landmark of Pune. It is developed and maintained by PMC's Garden Department. It was opened to public on October 31, 2002. A life-size statue of Major Pradeep Tathawade, who sacrificed his life fighting for the country with militants in Poonch district of Jammu in June 2000 and after whom the park is named, stands tall at the garden entrance.

Spread over 2.75 acres; it has 260-metre­ The garden includes several water fountains, children's play area and at the centre of the garden, there is an artificial pond with fish in it. A battle tank that was pressed into service during the lndo-Pak war (1971) was gifted to the PMC by the Indian Army. It is placed in the garden for visitors to view.

The visitors from the vicinity of areas like Dhanukar Colony, Bhusari Colony, Paud Road and Sinhagad Road regularly visit this garden. People regularly visit the garden to practice yoga and attend laughter club in the morning and jog in the evenings. Blessed with a lush green lawn, a cluster of trees and comfortable sitting arrangements, it is a haven for relaxation, especially for senior citizens.
raw.key_attractions:
• Stage Facing Lawn: A huge stage facing lawn is available to the citizens.  Many cultural and social activities are organised here, as it has comfortable seating arrangement for citizens.
  • Yoga Centre: A small yoga centre located in the middle of the garden is a treat for yoga enthusiasts, while a small pond with a variety of small fish sets this garden apart from the others. Children can be seen glued to the pond, trying to catch a glimpse of their favourite marine life.
  • Variety of Trees: The park is dotted with mostly indigenous trees like Mango, Neem, Pimpal, Banyan, Amia, Cheery, Almond, Palash, Kanchan, Jamun, Bamboo and Bel are planted here. The garden also has varieties of roses, marigold, Dahlia, Zinnia, Jasmine, Shoeflower, jai-jui and chamak besides many different types of shrubs like bougainvillea.

  • Outside the park

    The garden is maintained by PMC's Garden Department. There are no food stalls outside this garden. Outdoor games and pet animals are not allowed into it.
raw.timings:
• 6:00 AM to 11:00 AM
  • 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM

    Open all 7 days

raw.title: Matoshree Ramai Bhimrao Ambedkar Garden
raw.address: Sr. No. 42-A, In Front of Wadia College, Pune.
raw.body:
Created in 2011 and spanning 10,000 square meters, this park is known for its precise design and well-planned layout. At its heart is a huge fountain that adds an elegant touch to the surroundings. The park is surrounded by dense trees, providing ample shade and a peaceful atmosphere. Visitors can enjoy the Yoga Hall, offering a space for relaxation and fitness, while the pagoda adds a beautiful architectural feature.

An open cultural platform provides a venue for performances and events, and a children's playground ensures a fun space for kids. For those seeking exercise, the jogging track offers a dedicated path through the park. The expansive meadow allows children to play freely in a safe and open area. With its calm environment and abundant greenery, the park is a perfect escape for those looking to unwind or engage in outdoor activities.
raw.key_attractions:
• Huge Fountain: A striking feature at the heart of the park.
  • Dense Trees: Providing shade and creating a tranquil atmosphere.
  • Yoga Hall: A dedicated space for relaxation and wellness.
  • Pagoda: An aesthetically pleasing architectural element.
  • Open Cultural Platform: A space for performances and events.
  • Children's Playground: A fun and safe area for kids to play.
  • Jogging Track: A well-maintained track for fitness enthusiasts.
  • Expansive Meadow: A large area for children to play and families to enjoy.

raw.address: Plot No. D, Model Colony, Shivajinagar, Pune.
raw.body: Chittaranjan Vatika Garden, established in 1996, spans an area of 20,000 square meters and offers a variety of attractions for visitors. The garden features a 600-meter-long jogging track, a children's playground, and a traffic park designed to train schoolchildren. It also includes an open gym, a modern fountain-style irrigation system, a recreation center, and a Yoga Hut for wellness activities. The garden is home to a cultural center, a meadow, and is surrounded by dense trees, making it a peaceful retreat for all age groups.

Furthermore, Dhumal Garden plays a crucial role in preserving the natural environment and promoting sustainable practices. By visiting, you support these efforts and help ensure that the park remains a sanctuary for future generations. Visiting parks can also improve physical and mental health, as outdoor activities and serene environments keep the body active and the mind refreshed. Dhumal Garden offers a unique blend of relaxation, recreation, and inspiration. It caters to various interests and provides a rewarding experience for people of all ages. So next time you're planning a trip or looking for a fun activity, consider visiting Dhumal Garden and discover the treasures it holds.

Garden theme is based on children's park. So that purpose many of playing equipments like slides, swing, Spinning wheel,  duck wheel spinning etc. are installed Only for children's.

raw.title: Lakaki Lake
raw.address: Sr. No. 511/510/501/502, Model Colony, Shivajinagar, Pune
raw.body:
Amidst the hustle and bustle of the city, we found a quiet place where you'd want to be left alone with your thoughts. The Lakaki lake, known to a very few people of the city, is located in Model Colony. There's a walking track along the beautiful lake for those who'd like to run by the lake or enjoy an evening stroll. And from either side of the track, you can see a different view.

The lake, in its current state is an extension of an old natural lake. The development of this lake in its current state was carried out by one of Pune's famous industrial family, the Kirloskars and have named the lake after the founder of the Kirloskar industries, Laxman Kashinath Kirloskar. That's why the lake is called La-Ka-Ki lake.

As this lake park is not known to many people, the place is generally vacant. You will find a few locals on their morning or evening walks. The lake plays a host to a number of birds of different species. You can find storks, bulbuls, ducks, cranes among others, taking a dip into the lake's cool waters.

The walking track around the lake has a number of benches throughout. The best part is that from each bench, you'll view the lake from a different angle. You can take a book and read in peace, find inspiration or simply listen to music as you enjoy the view.
raw.key_attractions:
• Serene Escape – A peaceful retreat amidst the city's hustle and bustle, perfect for solitude and relaxation.
  • Scenic Walking Track – A beautiful lakeside pathway for jogging, walking, or enjoying an evening stroll.
  • Unique Lake History – Named after Laxman Kashinath Kirloskar, developed by the renowned Kirloskar family.
  • Rich Birdlife – Home to diverse bird species like storks, bulbuls, ducks, and cranes.
  • Secluded & Less Crowded – A hidden gem in Pune, offering a tranquil atmosphere away from crowds.
  • Multiple Viewing Angles – Benches placed strategically along the track provide different perspectives of the lake.
  • Perfect for Reading & Reflection – Ideal for book lovers, artists, and those seeking inspiration.
raw.timings:
• Morning 6:00 AM to 10:00 AM
  • Evening 4:00 PM to 7:00 PM

    Open all 7 days

raw.address: Sr. No. 199, 204, 205, 206 (Part) & 209 (Part), Lohgaon, Viman Nagar, Pune.
raw.body: The Udaan Biodiversity Park, situated in Pune’s Viman Nagar, has been welcoming visitors since 2012. Known as Udaan Jaiv Vividhata Garden, this park was developed through a partnership between the Zensar Foundation (an independent trust under Zensar Technologies, a software and services firm) and the Pune Municipal Corporation. The park was designed to promote biodiversity by transforming barren, rocky terrain into a thriving ecosystem, providing a habitat for diverse species to flourish.

📞 Emergency Contacts

Current Status of Dams in Pune Region

July 15, 2025
Red Alert in Pune District – Large Discharge Likely Today (15 July 2025) from Khadakwasla Dam to Regulate Reservoir Levels, Citizens Advised to Stay Alert
July 15, 2025
On 15th July 2025 at 2:00 PM, water discharge from Mulshi Dam will increase from 8200 to 12300 Cusecs. Residents near the river are advised to remain alert.
July 14, 2025
As of 14th July 2025, Mulshi Dam is 76.53% full and rainfall activity continues with varying intensity. The ongoing water discharge of 1100 Cusecs into the Mula River will be increased to 3500 Cusecs at 6:00 PM today. If the rainfall continues or increases, the discharge may be further adjusted.
July 07, 2025
Mulshi Dam in the Pune region is currently 76.67% full, and continuous rainfall is ongoing in the catchment area. At present, 5,800 cusecs of water is being discharged into the Mula River, which is scheduled to be increased to 8,200 cusecs at 3:00 PM. Citizens residing near the riverbanks are advised to remain alert.
July 02, 2025
at 10:00 PM, the discharge from Khadakwasla Dam into the Mutha river is being increased from 2,464 cusecs to 3,883 cusecs. This is subject to change as per requirement. Residents along the riverbanks are requested to remain alert.

raw.title: Swachh Survekshan 2025 - Deep Cleaning Drive
summary:
Swachh Survekshan 2025 - Deep Cleaning Drive

July 12, 2025
Pune on the path of cleanliness, even at night!

The Solid Waste Management Department of Pune Municipal Corporation has launched night-time mechanical sweeping operations from 12th July 2025.

The formal inauguration was carried out by Hon. Municipal Commissioner Shri Naval Kishore Ram on the Swargate–Satara Road.

The event was attended by Additional Commissioners Shri Prithviraj B. P. and Shri Omprakash Divate, Deputy Commissioner (SWM) Shri Sandeep Kadam, Assistant Commissioners Smt. Surekha Bhange (Dhankawadi-Sahakarnagar) and Smt. Nalini Suryawanshi (Bibwewadi), along with officials from the health and engineering departments.
July 11, 2025
To ensure cleanliness in Pune, the PMC Commissioner conducted a midnight inspection. A total of 213 vehicles and 1,472 sanitation workers were deployed during the night shift. During the night, 188 metric tons of waste were collected.
July 03, 2025
A cleanliness rally was organized in Ambegaon Budruk by PMC's Dhanakwadi-Sahakarnagar ward office to raise awareness about sanitation. Citizens actively participated to support the cause of a cleaner Pune.
July 04, 2025
In line with Swachh Survekshan 2025, the Pune Municipal Corporation conducted the "Swachh Pune Abhiyan" and "Safai Apnao – Bimari Bhagao Abhiyan" on 04/07/2025 under the Bhavani Peth and Yerwada-Kalas-Dhanori Ward Offices. The Deep Cleaning Drive covered areas from Swargate Jedge Chowk to Cantonment Gate, Shankarsheth Road and flyover, and from Bombay Sappers Chandrama Chowk to Mental Corner.
July 03, 2025
As part of Swachh Survekshan 2025, the Pune Municipal Corporation organized a “Deep Cleaning Drive” under the Kasba-Vishrambaugwada Ward Office from Panchami Hotel on Satara Road to Swargate Chowk, and under the Shivajinagar-Ghole Road Ward Office covering the areas from Senapati Bapat Road to Chatushrungi Mandir, including Shivaji Housing Society and Vaiduwadi.

summary:
Join Us in Building a Progressive and Inclusive Pune

Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) warmly invites companies, corporate foundations, institutions, and philanthropic organizations to become valued partners in the city's journey toward inclusive development and urban excellence.

Under the ambit of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), we welcome your collaboration on initiatives that:

  • Uplift communities
  • Protect the environment
  • Strengthen public infrastructure
  • Create long-lasting social impact

Whether through health, education, sustainability, or innovation, your partnership can help shape a progressive, equitable, and sustainable Pune for current and future generations.

Why Partner with PMC?

Pune is one of India’s fastest-growing urban centers. At PMC, we are committed to delivering quality services, resilient infrastructure, and inclusive growth. Your CSR support can accelerate transformation in key areas that impact millions of lives.

Here’s why your partnership matters:

  • Transparent & Accountable Governance
  • Impact-Driven and Scalable Projects
  • Credible and Proven Implementation Mechanisms
  • Public Recognition for Contributors

raw.title: Pune Shines in Swachh Survekshan 2024 Rankings!
raw.summary:
Pune Shines in Swachh Survekshan 2024 Rankings!

Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has achieved a remarkable feat in the Swachh Survekshan 2024 rankings by securing the 8th position at the national level (in the category of cities with population above 10 lakhs) and 2nd position in Maharashtra. This recognition reflects the collective efforts of PMC officials, staff and citizens toward a cleaner and greener city.

Key Highlights from PMC’s Achievements:

  • Pune received the Water+ and GFC 5-Star Certification.
  • 100% Door-to-Door Garbage Collection across 8.5 lakh+ households and commercial properties using over 900 active vehicles.
  • Source-level segregation is practiced in 984 locations citywide.
  • 16 wet and 14 dry waste processing centers are operational using advanced technologies like composting, biogas, bio-CNG, and RDF.
  • Decentralized composting initiatives promoted in housing societies and communities.
  • Continuous 3-shift sweeping and night-time cleaning to maintain cleanliness across the city.
  • 17 permanent RRR (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle) centers have been established to encourage responsible waste handling.
  • Massive awareness campaigns like Swachhta Abhiyan, and plastic-free initiatives are regularly undertaken.
  • Citizen engagement through schools, colleges, and local groups has significantly contributed to the achievement.

The consistent guidance of the Hon. Municipal Commissioner Shri. Naval Kishore Ram, Additional Commissioners, health and sanitation teams, and active media feedback have played a vital role in improving on-ground implementation.

The contribution of Zonal Deputy Commissioners, Assistant Commissioners, Health Inspectors, Engineers, and Safai Karamcharis has made this achievement possible.

raw.title: Launch of ‘Road Adoption Scheme’ Held Successfully
raw.summary:
Launch of ‘Road Adoption Scheme’ Held Successfully

Date: 16th July 2025

Pune Municipal Corporation launched the ‘Road Adoption Scheme’ on Wednesday, 16th July 2025, by Zone no. 1 Office. The scheme was inaugurated by Hon. Municipal Commissioner Mr. Naval Kishore Ram, in the presence of Additional Commissioners and department heads.

The aim of the scheme is to improve the condition, safety, and cleanliness of city roads. Under this program, PMC officers and social workers/NGOs have been assigned responsibility for specific roads, acting as "guardians".

They will regularly inspect and ensure action is taken on 29 key aspects, including:

  • Walkable, clean footpaths
  • Pothole-free roads
  • Removal of encroachments, flexes, and banners
  • Clearing of hanging internet cables
  • Visibility of zebra crossings
  • Maintenance and painting of dividers
  • Trimming dangerous tree branches
  • Proper alignment of drainage and chambers
  • Regular cleanliness and debris removal

A total of 90 participants – 45 PMC staff and 45 active citizens – have been appointed. All work will be done voluntarily, with local citizen involvement ensuring regular monitoring and faster action on road issues.

The scheme is currently running as a pilot project in selected roads under the three ward offices of zone 1. If successful, it may be expanded citywide.

Hon. Commissioner Mr. Naval Kishore Ram shared his views and stated, “This initiative will ensure better maintenance of city roads with direct public participation. We aim for cleaner and safer roads for all citizens.”

The event was attended by:

  1. Mr. M. J. Pradeep Chandran (Addl. Commissioner – General)
  2. Mr. Omprakash Divte (Addl. Commissioner – Works)
  3. Mr. Aniruddha Pawaskar (Chief Engineer – Roads)
  4. Mr. Sandeep Dhole Patil (Deputy Commissioner – Solid Waste Management)
  5. Mr. Sandeep Khalate (Deputy Commissioner – Encroachment)
  6. Mr. Ballal (Deputy Commissioner – Zone 5)
  7. Mr. Thorat (Deputy Commissioner – Zone 4)

All Assistant Commissioners from respective wards

Citizens who addressed the gathering included Mr. Dnyaneshwar Molak, Dr. Siddharth Dhende, Mrs. Kamal Dhole Patil, Mrs. Shyamala Desai, Mrs. Kanij Sukhrani, Mrs. Vanita Vagaskar, Mrs. Lata Rajguru, and Mrs. Ashwini Landge.

 

The event was organized by Mr. Madhav Jagtap, Deputy Commissioner of Zone 1, and anchored by Mr. Vivek Dev.

raw.title: Reduce Pollution, Make Life Beautiful!
raw.summary:
A workshop under the National Clean Air Programme titled "Towards Clean Air in Pune" was organized by the Environment Department of Pune Municipal Corporation at Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru Cultural Hall, Ghole Road.

In this program, Mr. Mangesh Dighe, Environment Officer; Mr. Amar Desai, Deputy Regional Transport Officer; Ms. Ritu Parchure from the Prayas organization; and Mr. Ranjit Gadgil from the Parisar organization guided the attendees on air quality and measures to reduce pollution.

The workshop was attended by representatives from various departments of the Pune Municipal Corporation, Maharashtra Pollution Control Board, Regional Transport Office, and Traffic Police. Group discussions were also held to find solutions for pollution caused by transportation, construction, solid waste, and other sources.

To achieve clean air and a healthy Pune, it is essential for all of us to come together!

raw.title: Plastic Free Pune cleanliness drive
raw.summary:
Successfully organized "Plastic Free Pune" cleanliness drive under the "My Bharat initiative"!

Plastic free Pune cleanliness drive was organized by the Environment and Solid Waste Management Department of Pune Municipal Corporation on 14th May 2025 at Bhide Pool from 7 to 9 am.

A total of 215 volunteers and officers participated in this event. Pune Ploggers, I-Volunteers, Respected Punawala Clean City Initiative, Swachh Pune Service Co-operative, PMC Health Inspector, Mokadam, Cleaning staff as well as teachers and students of Marathwada Mitra Mandal College, Mamasaheb Mohol Vidyalaya, Four Sight College of Commerce, Choice College of Art and Commerce participated.

During this mission:

  • Cleaning done at Bhide bridge area and Mula-Mutha river bank
  • 955 kg of dry waste - plastic, thermacol, wrappers etc. It has been collected
  • All participants registered on My Bharat portal
  • All involved took the oath of cleanliness

In this campaign. Implemented under the guidance of Commissioner Pune Municipal Corporation.

The aim is behind this initiative that every citizen should come forward by realizing their responsibility for a clean, beautiful and eco-friendly Puja.

Come on, let's take initiative and create plastic free Pune!

raw.title: Heritage Yatra 2025 – A Celebration of Pune’s Cultural Legacy

images.alt: Heritage Yatra 2025 – A Celebration of Pune’s Cultural Legacy

raw.summary:
On the occasion of the Amrut Mahotsav year of the Pune Municipal Corporation, a cultural heritage festival “Heritage Yatra 2025” will be jointly organized by the Pune Municipal Corporation and M.I.T. A.D.T. University from April 23 to 26, 2025.
To mark the Amrut Mahotsav year and World Heritage Day, the program “Heritage Yatra 2025,” based on the heritage theme, will be held at Kalagram, Pu. La. Deshpande Garden, Sinhagad Road, from April 23 to 26, 2025. The event will be inaugurated at 5:00 PM on April 23, 2025, at the hands of the Hon’ble Municipal Commissioner, Dr. Rajendra B. Bhosale.

Various programs will be organized under “Heritage Yatra 2025.” One of the key highlights will be a cultural performance titled “Agyat Shalaka,” which will highlight the contributions of unknown Indian women warriors who fought for the motherland. This performance will be presented by the Mumbai-based ‘Rangved’ group on April 23, 2025, after the inauguration.

Additionally, from April 23 to 26, multiple competitions and events based on the heritage theme will be held for school and college students. These will include essay competitions, storytelling competitions, debate competitions, and more. Workshops will be conducted on subjects such as theatre, musical theatre, Madhubani art, painting, bamboo craft, and other traditional forms.

A photography competition will also be held for the younger generation, focusing on the architectural frames of old Pune – its doors and windows.

A Heritage Walk from Shaniwarwada to Vishrambaug Wada will have been organized on April 18, 2025, to commemorate World Heritage Day. Another Heritage Walk will be held on April 24, 2025, from 7:00 AM to 10:00 AM.

Overall, this program will provide a grand platform to showcase and experience the rich historical and cultural heritage of Pune. The entire event will be hosted at Kalagram, Pu. La. Deshpande Garden.
Kalagram will stand as a proud creation developed by the Pune Municipal Corporation, and every citizen of Pune will be proud of it. All citizens will be encouraged to visit and participate in this vibrant celebration.

raw.title: PMC's IWMS Wins Second Prize in Rajiv Gandhi Administrative Mobility Competition 2023-24
raw.summary:
The Rajiv Gandhi Administrative Acceleration Campaign and Competition has awarded the Integrated Works Management System (IWMS) implemented by Pune Municipal Corporation with a state government award. This award is given to initiatives implemented in government offices to make administrative work citizen-centric and enhance decision-making efficiency.

For the past three years, City Engineer Prashant Waghmare has played a key role in implementing this system. According to the Pune Municipal Corporation's budget, various development works are carried out in the city using approved development funds. To ensure that these development works are technically sound, accurate, high-quality, transparent, and citizen-friendly, the Pune Municipal Corporation has introduced this system through CSR initiatives.

This system facilitates the entire process online, from preparing the pre-estimate report for development works to the tendering process. The implementation of this computerized system has been carried out in phases over the past three years. It has been successfully deployed in various departments such as Roads, Water Supply, Building Construction, Sewerage Maintenance & Repair, Parks, Electrical Works, etc. Additionally, it has been implemented in all 15 regional offices under the municipal zones.

raw.title: World Tuberculosis Day
raw.summary:
Pune, March 24, 2025 – The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) Health Department organized a special event to mark World TB Day at Janajyoti Savitribai Phule Memorial (Theatre), Ganjpeth, Pune. The program aimed to raise awareness about tuberculosis (TB), its prevention, and available treatment options.

The event was graced by the presence of Shri. M. J. Pradip Chandran, Additional Commissioner of PMC, as the Guest of Honour. Addressing the audience, he emphasized the importance of early diagnosis, timely medical intervention, and public awareness in controlling TB. He urged citizens to stay informed about TB symptoms and treatment options available at government healthcare facilities.

Healthcare professionals, social workers, and representatives from various organizations participated in the event, discussing strategies for TB elimination and spreading awareness about the disease. Informative sessions on symptoms, causes, and preventive measures were conducted to educate the public.

A documentary was screened, highlighting the global efforts to combat TB and the importance of community participation in controlling its spread. Individuals who have successfully overcome TB shared their experiences, encouraging others to seek timely treatment without fear or stigma.

The event concluded with a call for community involvement in spreading awareness, promoting early detection, and supporting those undergoing TB treatment. The PMC Health Department reiterated its commitment to working towards a healthier Pune by fostering awareness and preventive measures against TB.

raw.title: Vaccination Campaign
raw.summary:
Japanese Encephalitis (JE) Vaccination Campaign by Pune Municipal Corporation

Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) is actively conducting a comprehensive Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccination campaign across various schools in the city. This initiative is part of PMC's broader public health strategy to combat vector-borne diseases in urban areas. The campaign aims to protect children from the deadly JE virus, which is transmitted through mosquito bites and can cause severe brain infections with potentially life-threatening consequences.
Key Highlights of the Campaign:

  • Target Group:  School-going children in Pune between the ages of 1-15 years
  • Objective: To immunize children against Japanese Encephalitis and achieve at least 95% coverage
  • Execution: Vaccination drives are being conducted in multiple schools with mobile health teams comprising medical officers, nurses, and support staff.
  • Health Awareness: Students and parents are being educated about symptoms, prevention, and mosquito control measures through interactive sessions and informational materials
Campaign Implementation Strategy:
  • Phase-wise Approach: The campaign is being implemented in multiple phases, starting with schools in high-risk areas
  • Consent Process: Written consent is obtained from parents before vaccination
  • Documentation: Each vaccinated child receives a vaccination card for record-keeping
  • Follow-up Mechanism: A robust follow-up system ensures children receive complete immunization
What is Japanese Encephalitis?

It is a viral brain infection spread primarily by Culex mosquitoes, which breed in rice fields and standing water. The virus can cause inflammation of the brain membranes, leading to significant neurological damage. Symptoms include high fever, headache, neck stiffness, disorientation, coma, seizures, spastic paralysis and ultimately, death in severe cases The fatality rate ranges from 20-30% of those who develop encephalitis, with 30-50% of survivors suffering permanent neurological damage. The best prevention is vaccination along with comprehensive mosquito control measures

Public Health Impact:

The PMC's initiative aligns with national immunization guidelines and is crucial in ensuring better public health and disease prevention among children. JE vaccination has proven highly effective in reducing the incidence of this dangerous disease in endemic areas. According to health experts, a single dose of the vaccine provides long-lasting immunity in most recipients.

Community Engagement:

Beyond school-based vaccination, the PMC is partnering with community organizations, residential welfare associations, and local healthcare providers to raise awareness about JE prevention. Information campaigns through radio, newspapers, and social media are supplementing the direct outreach efforts. More schools are expected to be covered in the upcoming phases of the campaign, with PMC health officials aiming to complete the vaccination drive before the onset of the monsoon season when mosquito breeding typically increases.

raw.title: Plastic Waste
summary:
The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has been implementing various initiatives and actions as part of the plastic ban enforcement.

Key Initiatives Related to Plastic Ban

  1. Awareness Campaigns on Plastic Ban
    • Every year, PMC publishes notifications through press releases regarding the fines imposed for using banned plastic (SUP).
  2. Flying Squads and Vehicles
    • A total of 18 new vehicles have been procured: 15 for regional offices, 2 for the main office, and 1 specifically for the plastic squad.
    • These vehicles are utilized for actions related to plastic ban enforcement, garbage burning, illegal dumping, debris management, and more.
  3. CSR-Based Activities
    • Under CSR initiatives, PMC ensures the collection and appropriate disposal of multi-layered plastic (MLP).
  4. Establishment of RRR Centers (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle)
    • RRR centers have been set up in all regional offices.
    • Citizens are encouraged to collect and deposit old books, documents, plastic, glass, e-waste, clothes, footwear, and other items at these centers.
    • The collected materials are supplied to stakeholders for reuse or recycling into new products.
  5. River Protection Measures
    • Nets have been installed on bridges to prevent citizens from dumping waste into rivers.

Fines and Enforcement

  • Since October 2, 2023, a total of 72,778 cases have been registered, and fines amounting to ₹4.03 crore have been collected.
  • Flying squads alone have imposed fines totaling approximately ₹3 crore.
  • A total of 6,268 kilograms of plastic has been confiscated.

Plastic Recycling Initiatives

PMC has launched several initiatives for recycling plastic:

  1. Waste to Wonder Project
    • Murals have been created using recycled plastic.
  2. Repurposing into Clothing
    • A total of 750 T-shirts were made from 1 ton of plastic collected from waste.
  3. Partnership with Organizations
    • Organizations like "KARIGAR," "FEELGOODECO," and "PRIMAPLASTECH" have contributed by producing items such as pots, brushes, and benches from recycled plastic.

Multi-Layered Plastic (MLP) Management

  1. MLP Collection and Processing
    • MLP is collected daily at designated collection centers.
    • The collected plastic is sorted, baled, and sent to authorized recycling centers.
  2. Cost Management for Recycling
    • ITC provides financial assistance under the Viability Gap Funding (VGF) scheme to support the recycling process.

Public Awareness and Participation

  • Extensive awareness campaigns are conducted to promote cleanliness in the city.
  • Citizens violating rules are educated, issued warnings, and fined if non-compliance continues.

The PMC remains committed to protecting the environment and promoting the benefits of plastic recycling and reuse.

raw.title: E-Waste Collection
summary:
In the age of rapid digitalization, our lives are increasingly intertwined with wearable devices, high-end computers, and various digital home appliances. However, the fate of these electronic marvels after their useful life comes to an end poses a critical question. Pune Municipal Corporation has spearheaded a series of groundbreaking initiatives aimed at not only reducing the volume of electronic waste (E-waste) but also ensuring its proper recycling. Over the past few years, these efforts have yielded significant results. Pune Municipal Corporation, Janwani, Poornam EcoVision Foundation and Cummins India Limited are implementing the E-waste Management Project in Pune City. This Project intends to educate citizens on getting E-waste separation at the source level and handing it over to authorized E-Waste Collection Agencies. The awareness is conducted through Society Level, School Level drives, it also covers small and medium commercial establishments. A city-level Mega E-waste Awareness and Collection Drive is also conducted twice a year to create buzz about E-waste, where over 1000 volunteers take participation to collect E-waste across 300 plus locations from Pune city. Apart from the above, we also organize a “Best out of E-waste” competition for students from 1st to 10th std. resulting in significant response and children's commitment. We reached out to 17000 students during this BOEC competition and over 450 projects were presented by students in the year 2024. Also, the response received from societies and commercial establishments by donating E Waste for reuse and to process scientifically every year is appreciable. We also donate refurbished computers to the needy schools.

E-waste Sculpture –

A glaring issue is surfaced during the recycling process - the disposal of incorrectly printed PCB boards, often referred to as 'virgin' boards. This inefficient disposal method consumes excessive energy and contributes to pollution. It has become evident that a more sustainable approach would be to repurpose this material whenever possible. To address this challenge, Pune Municipal Corporation , Cummins India Foundation has partnered with Janwani Organization to introduce a groundbreaking concept – the E-Waste Sculpture. This initiative brings forth a captivating array of art pieces, including wall lamps, hanging lamps, and a chandelier, all powered by recycled E-waste materials. The innovative E-Waste Sculpture now graces Balasaheb Thakrey Garden in Dahanukar Colony, Kothrud, Pune.

The presentation of this remarkable sculpture aligns perfectly with the launch of the Indian Swachhata League, a campaign dedicated to cleanliness and sustainability. Mr. Sandip Kadam, Deputy Commissioner, PMC had the honor of presenting this symbol of sustainability to the citizens of the Pune Municipal Corporation. The event was attended by esteemed dignitaries. This collaborative effort not only shines a light on the issue of E-waste management but also offers an innovative solution that combines sustainability, art, and community engagement. Through this E-Waste Sculpture, we demonstrate a commitment to a greener and more sustainable future for Pune and beyond.

raw.title: Garden Waste
summary:
Pune city has a 28% green cover, contributing to a daily generation of 60 to 70 metric tons (MT) of garden waste. To manage this effectively, Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has implemented a dedicated collection and processing system for garden waste.

Garden Waste Management System
  • A specialized collection system has been set up to gather garden waste from residential areas, parks, and commercial spaces.
  • The collected waste undergoes shredding to reduce its volume and prepare it for further processing.
  • PMC has developed a centralized garden waste processing facility, where shredded waste is converted into compost, mulch, or biofuel.
  • Awareness programs encourage citizens and housing societies to segregate garden waste at the source and dispose of it responsibly.
  • In addition to collection services, PMC has designated drop-off points for individuals and landscaping businesses to deposit garden waste.
  • The compost produced from processed garden waste is used for urban greening projects, public gardens, and tree plantation initiatives across the city.
Future Plans for Garden Waste Management
  • PMC aims to introduce decentralized composting units in different wards to process waste locally.
  • Advanced biogas technology is being explored to convert garden waste into renewable energy.
  • Collaborations with private organizations and environmental groups are being considered to enhance waste recycling and promote sustainable waste management practices.

Efficient garden waste management is a crucial step in maintaining Pune's green cover, reducing landfill waste, and promoting sustainable urban development.

raw.title: Construction & Demolition Waste
summary:
The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) generates approximately 250 metric tons (MT) of Construction and Demolition (C&D) waste per day from various sources.

PMC’s Initiatives for C&D Waste Management
  • PMC has prepared a Detailed Project Report (DPR) to assess the quantity, quality, and sources of C&D waste.
  • Consultations have been conducted with various stakeholders to understand their concerns regarding C&D waste.
  • Separate tenders have been developed for the collection, transportation, processing, and disposal of C&D waste.
  • The district administration has allocated 2 acres of land in Wagholi for C&D waste processing.
  • A 250 MTPD C&D waste processing plant has been installed in Wagholi, on Pune’s eastern outskirts.
  • The collected waste is processed into construction products such as blocks and aggregates.
  • PMC plans to install an additional 200 MTPD C&D waste processing plant within the city.
  • Strict actions are being taken to minimize C&D waste in other areas through spot fines and green net closures.
Sources of C&D Waste in Pune
  • Various departments of PMC, MLGL, telephone companies, private developers, etc., generate large amounts of C&D waste.
  • PMC has planned to establish an independent system for the collection and transportation of C&D waste.
  • A contractor has been appointed under PMC Resolution No. 812 dated 21.12.2016 to manage the collection, transportation, and processing of C&D waste.
  • A toll-free number (18002339595) has been made available for C&D waste-related inquiries.
  • The C&D waste generated by PMC departments, MLGL, telephone companies, and private developers will be collected and deposited at designated locations as per PMC’s directions.

raw.title: Mobile App Policy
summary:
Pune Municipal Corporation built the PMC Office Connect app as a free app. This SERVICE is provided by Pune Municipal Corporation at no cost and is intended for use as is.

This page is used to inform website visitors regarding our policies with the collection, use, and disclosure of Personal Information if anyone decides to use our Service.

If you choose to use our Service, then you agree to the collection and use of information in relation to this policy. The personal information that we collect is used to provide and improve the service. We will not use or share your information with anyone except as described in this Privacy Policy.

The terms used in this Privacy Policy have the same meanings as in our Terms and Conditions, which is accessible at PMC Office Connect unless otherwise defined in this Privacy Policy.

Information Collection and Use

For a better experience, while using our Service, we may require you to provide us with certain personally identifiable information. The information that we request is will be retained by us and used as described in this privacy policy.

The app does use third-party services that may collect information used to identify you.

Link to privacy policy of third-party service providers used by the app

  • Google Play Services

Log Data

We want to inform you that whenever you use our Service, in a case of an error in the app we collect data and information (through third party products) on your phone called Log Data. This Log Data may include information such as your device Internet Protocol (“IP”) address, device name, operating system version, the configuration of the app when utilizing our Service, the time and date of your use of the Service, and other statistics.

Cookies

Cookies are files with a small amount of data that is commonly used an anonymous unique identifier. These are sent to your browser from the website that you visit and are stored on your device's internal memory.

This Service does not use these “cookies” explicitly. However, the app may use third-party code and libraries that use “cookies” to collect information and to improve their services. You have the option to either accept or refuse these cookies and know when a cookie is being sent to your device. If you choose to refuse our cookies, you may not be able to use some portions of this Service.

Service Providers

We may employ third-party companies and individuals due to the following reasons:

  • To facilitate our Service;
  • To provide the Service on our behalf;
  • To perform Service-related services; or
  • To assist us in analyzing how our Service is used.

We want to inform users of this Service that these third parties have access to your Personal Information. The reason is to perform the tasks assigned to them on our behalf. However, they are obligated not to disclose or use the information for any other purpose.

Security

We value your trust in providing us with your Personal Information, thus, we are striving to use commercially acceptable means of protecting it. But remember that no method of transmission over the internet, or method of electronic storage is 100% secure and reliable, and we cannot guarantee its absolute security.

Links to Other Sites

This Service may contain links to other sites. If you click on a third-party link, you will be directed to that site. Note that these external sites are not operated by us. Therefore, we strongly advise you to review the Privacy Policy of these websites. We have no control over and assume no responsibility for the content, privacy policies, or practices of any third-party sites or services.

Children’s Privacy

These Services do not address anyone under the age of 13. We do not knowingly collect personally identifiable information from children under 13. In the case that we discover that a child under 13 has provided us with personal information, we immediately delete this from our servers. If you are a parent or guardian and you are aware that your child has provided us with personal information, please contact us so that we will be able to take necessary actions.

Changes to This Privacy Policy

We may update our Privacy Policy from time to time. Thus, you are advised to review this page periodically for any changes. We will notify you of any changes by posting the new Privacy Policy on this page. These changes are effective immediately after they are posted on this page.

Contact Us

If you have any questions or suggestions about our Privacy Policy, do not hesitate to contact us.

You can write to us at info@punecorporation.org

The Pune Municipal Corporation has planned a tree survey based on geographical location (geo-enabled). This information will also be displayed on the city's map. raw.title: Grading of Listed Buildings
summary:
According to Rule No. 14.5 of the UDCPR 2020, the regulations regarding the Conservation of Heritage buildings/precincts/Natural features are mentioned. Point No. 14.5.8 specifically provides information on the Grading of the listed buildings.
Grade I- 

Heritage Grade-I comprises buildings and precincts of National or Historic importance, excellence in architectural style, design technology and material usage and/or aesthetics ; associated with a great historic event, personality, movement or institution. They have been and are the prime landmarks of the city and of National importance

Grade II- 

Heritage Grade-II (A and B) comprises buildings and precincts of Regional importance , possessing special architectural or aesthetic merit, or cultural or historical significance though of a lower scale than Heritage Grade-I. They are local landmarks ,which contribute to the image and identity of the region. They may be the work of master craftsmen or may be models of proportion and ornamentation or designed to suit a particular climate

Grade III- 

Heritage Grade-III comprises buildings and precincts of local importance for townscape ,they evoke architectural, aesthetic ,or sociological interest though not as in Heritage Grade -II. These contribute to determine the character of the locality and can be representative of life-style of a particular community or region and, may also be distinguished by setting on a street line or special character of the façade and uniformity of height width and scale.

Scope of change
Grade I - 

No interventions be permitted either on exterior or interior unless it is necessary in the interest of strengthening and prolonging the life of the buildings or precincts or any part of features thereof. For this purpose absolutely essential and minimum changes would be allowed and they must be in accordance with the original. Repairs shall be with the use of like to like material.

Grade II -

Grade - II (A) - Internal changes and adaptive reuse and external changes may by and large be allowed but subject to strict scrutiny. Care would be taken to ensure the conservation of all special aspects for which it is included in heritage Grade - II

Grade - II (B) - In addition to the above, extension of Additional building in the same plot or compound, in certain circumstances be allowed, provided that, the extension/additional building is in harmony with (and does not detract from) the existing heritage buildings or precincts especially in terms of height, and façade.

Grade III - 

External, internal changes and adaptive reuse would by and large be allowed. Changes can include extensions, and additional buildings in the same plot or compound. However any changes should be such that they do not detract from the existing heritage building/precinct.

Procedure
Grade I - 

Development permission for the changes would be given by the Authority on the advice of the Heritage Conservation Committee.

Grade II - 

Development permission for the changes/additional Construction would be given by the Authority on the advice of the Heritage Conservation Committee.

Grade III - 

Development permission for the changes/additional Construction would be given by the Authority on the advice of the Heritage Conservation Committee.

List of heritage sites within the old limits of Pune Municipal Corporation - Grade I, Grade II, Grade III (Submitted to the Government of Maharashtra for final approval)

raw.title: PARMM Project (JAICA Funded)
summary:
Pollution Abatement of River Mula-Mutha (PARMM) at Pune

Under the National River Conservation Plan

Pune Municipal Corporation

  • The project of Pollution Abatement of River Mula Mutha at Pune (Old Limit) was sanctioned under the National River Conservation Plan of the Ministry of Environment Forest and Climate Change, Government of India on 14/01/2016. 
  • For this project Minutes of Discussion (MOD) between Japan International Corporation Agency (JICA), National River Conservation Directorate (NRCD) and Pune Municipal Corporation was signed on 23rd February 2015. The project cost is Rs. 990.26 Cr. 
  • JICA (Japan International Cooperation Agency) has approved the loan for this project through the Central Government. The Government of India has sanctioned a grant of Rs 841.72 Cr. (85%) and the share of Pune Municipal Corporation is Rs. 148.54 Cr. (15%).  
  • It was decided to club all the STP and sewerage packages on the 'One City One Operator' concept. The re-packaging proposal submitted by Pune Municipal Corporation in August 2020 was approved by JICA in September 2020.
  • The final approval of the tender process by JICA was given on 21/02/2022. The tender process for Package ‘A’ was carried out by Pune Municipal Corporation and the work was awarded to "Enviro Control and Toshiba Water Solutions JV" dated 03/03/2022. 
  • Hon’ble Prime Minister of India Shri. Narendra Modi inaugurated the project on 06/03/2022.
  • Out of a total of 11 Sewage Treatment Plants, Work of 10 Sewage Treatment Plants are in progress and the development of main sewer lines is in progress.
  • Correspondence is in progress with Mahatma Phule Agricultural University, Rahuri and Forest Department, Govt. of Maharashtra for taking possession of the necessary land for construction of 10 MLD Botanical Garden Sewage Treatment Plant.

raw.title: FAQ for Riverfront Development Project
summary:
Frequently Asked Questions

1. Which Rivers Pass-Through Pune?

Pune lies on the western margin of the Deccan plateau, on the leeward side of the Sahyadri mountain range. The city is blessed with Mula and Mutha Rivers that originate in the Sahyadri ranges and traverse across Pune. The two rivers further meet and upon their confluence Mula-Mutha river is formed which further drains itself into the Bhima River. The total length of these three rivers traversing through Pune Municipal Corporation is 44km approximately. Out of this, 22.2km is Mula River, 10.4km is Mutha River and 11.8km is Mula Mutha River.

Fig . Map showing Pune and its Rivers and their catchment area and flood discharge

Both Mula and Mutha Rivers are dammed in their upstream. Mutha River has three dams- Khadakwasla, Warasgaon and Temghar while Mula River has Mulshi Dam that controls the release of water in the rivers. The rainfall only in the catchment area below the dams finds its way into the rivers.

The rainfall upstream reaches the reservoirs of the various dams from which it is released into the rivers in a controlled manner. The map below shows the catchment areas and the flood discharge for Pune's Rivers

2. What Is The Present Condition Of Pune's Rivers?

Pune's Rivers have been degraded over time. This is due to a number of factors:

Urbanization along the river - Heavy urbanization in PMC and PCMC areas over the past few decades has led to haphazard urban development along the river. At some locations, the development extends right up to the edge of the river.

Construction of Dams - The Mutha and Mula Rivers in Pune have dams in their upstream, controlling the discharge of water into them. Presently, the dams have stopped the flow of water into the rivers, keeping them dry.

Release of untreated sewage - Significant Number of Naalas and piped outfalls discharge untreated sewage directly into the rivers, converting the river into a polluted drain.

Lack of Access - Pune's rivers are not easily accessible. In the areas that are already developed, there are very few points where one can approach the Rivers. While along most of its length, the banks are lined by private properties making the River inaccessible for citizens.

Poor connectivity across the banks - results in the river becoming a barrier that divides the city. All of the above has over a period of time transformed a beautiful river into a polluted drain that the city has turned its back to.

3. What Is The Natural Width Or Extent Of Pune's Rivers?

There is no hard and fast boundary that separates a river channel from the land that surrounds it and therefore it is not possible to define the natural width of any river. Think of the lines on your palm when holding it at an incline. Rivers are essentially irregular inclined channels with land on either side sloping towards the channel.

The width of a river, or its extent, therefore, has to be artificially demarcated. Two departments of the state government normally concerned with designating the extent of the river are:

i. Irrigation Department, which designates the width of the river with reference to flooding.

ii. Revenue Department, which designates the extent of the river based on land ownership information.

4. How Does The Irrigation Department Define And Demarcate the Extent Of The Rivers?

The Irrigation Department demarcates the extent of a river as the area that is likely to be inundated when the river floods.

To do this, technical specialists such as geographers and hydraulic engineers first simulate the level of water that can be expected at all points along the centre line of the river channel during a flood. They mark the area on either side that is likely to be inundated on topographic maps. This area of inundation is demarcated as the extent of the river.

When demarcated in this way, the extent (or width) of the River depends on two factors:

1) Natural geography of the river and the surrounding terrain- ridges, valleys, slope, nature of the bank, soil, etc.

2) Level of flood passing through the River

The Irrigation Department of the Government of Maharashtra has used a blue line to demarcate the area along Pune's Rivers that is likely to be inundated by the highest flood that can be expected during any 25-year period. Furthermore, they have used a red line to demarcate the area that will be inundated by the highest flood expected during any 100-year period.

5. How Does The Revenue Department Define And Demarcate the Extent Of The Rivers?

The Revenue Department defines the Rivers extent based on land ownership information. They distinguish between plots of land and riverbed land using cadastral records. Cadastral records comprise 1) cadastral maps which show the shape and location of plots and, 2) ownership cadasters which record plot size and the name of the owner

Information for cadastral maps was originally collated by surveying the extent of plots as defined by boundary walls, fences, etc. on the ground. At the time when such surveys were carried out, land within a river channel that was not customarily owned by anyone (say, because it was prone to periodic flooding or was unclaimed for other reasons) was designated as being riverbed land. The extent of the river according to Revenue Department maps is based on this customary understanding of what constituted the riverbed at that time when the original survey was undertaken. Therefore, where revision surveys have not been conducted, Revenue maps reflect a historic situation.

6. What Are The Problems Associated With Using Maps Produced By Revenue Department To Define Rivers Extents?

Cadastral maps were originally created for collecting agricultural revenue. Mapping technology was primitive at that time. As a consequence Revenue Maps are cartographically inaccurate. Information for ownership cadasters is usually more up to date.

Since Revenue Departments cadastral maps are the basis for legally determining ownership of land, they exert much legal force, even though the extent of plots and riverbed land as demarcated in them are cartographically inaccurate. Thus, despite the River extent demarcated in Revenue maps carrying much legal force, there is nothing natural about the demarcation.

7. What Does The Pune Riverfront Development Project Propose To Do?

Build Embankments for flood protection

The project proposes to protect low-lying areas along the river from flooding by building a variety of well-modulated embankments along the banks of Pune's Rivers. In sparsely developed areas, further away from the city centre, rural riparian embankments will be built. In moderately developed areas urban riparian embankments will be built. In an intensely developed area with high banks, more engineered embankments will be built. The embankments on either side of the river will be designed to contain floods.

Reduce the impact of man-made obstructions to the flow of water in the river

The Pune Riverfront Development Projects first concern is to address the threat of flooding in the city. It recognizes that a considerable portion of the area within the red and blue lines area that can get inundated is already developed. The project first proposes to reduce the impact of indiscriminately built obstructions such as bridges, causeways, weirs, check dams etc. on the flow of water in Pune's rivers by removing, streamlining, remodelling, or rebuilding them. The effect of such interventions will be to reduce the high flood level. This in turn will reduce the extent of the area likely to get flooded by a 25 or 100-year flood.

Create a public realm along the river

Building the embankments will also enable the creation of a continuous public realm along both banks of Pune's rivers. Having such a continuous public realm will ensure that, unlike today, people will be able to move along the length of the river.

Curb Pollution by Drainage and Sewage Treatment Works

The project also proposes to curb the sewage flowing directly into the Pune Rivers by laying an interceptor sewer which will curb and divert the sewage to the nearest STP. As this project will span for a longer time duration, thus, it becomes essential to plan for infrastructure services well in advance. The embankment so designed will house the interceptor sewer line curbing the sewage falling directly into the river.

Enhance connectivity

At present, there is limited connectivity along and across the Pune's Rivers. There are far too few connections and there are long stretches where the river lacks connectivity across to the other side. The project thus proposes to strengthen the existing street network by introducing bridges and access roads that will further enhance the connectivity to the river. Pedestrian and cycling routes will also be planned along the promenades of the riverfront.

Integrate River into the life of the city

Another objective of this project is to create a network of gardens, open spaces, and public promenades that will preserve the natural environment and turn the Pune Rivers into an important asset for the city. Also, existing open spaces like gardens and parks, heritage structures along the river, ghats etc. will also be integrated with the riverfront development.

8. What Risks Do The Development Within The Red And Blue Lined Inundation Areas Face?

The various ruling of Courts and the National Green Tribunal has prohibited all construction in the area between the blue lines and restricted development in the area between the red lines. Thus the development within the red and blue lines exists in an area where development is not allowed and hence faces the risks related to the same. Also as explained in the points above, all the plots lying within the red and blue lined areas are vulnerable to the highest flood expected during any 100-year period, based on the current ground conditions.

9. How Does The Pune Municipal Corporation Plan To Involve The Public In The Riverfront Project?

The Pune Municipal Corporation is interested in creating awareness and sensitivity about Pune Riverfront Development Project in Pune city. The PMC also intends to consult Pune's citizens and maintain transparency in what it intends to do. By taking such an approach it intends to also build popular support for the project.

raw.title: Other Department Vehicles
summary:
Water Supply Department - Water Tanker

The Motor Vehicle Department has a total of 57 water tankers, out of which 39 are operated by the Water Supply Department, while the remaining 17 are managed by the Garden Department. The capacity of these municipal water tankers ranges from 9,000 liters to 10,000 liters. The tankers under the Water Supply Department are used to provide drinking water to the city's residents and to water trees in various gardens across Pune city.
Health Department - Ambulance

The Motor Vehicle Department has 54 ambulances owned by the Municipal Corporation. Among them, 3 vehicles are hearse cars, while the remaining 51 ambulances are operated by various municipal hospitals.
Fire Department Vehicles

The Pune Municipal Corporation Fire Department has approximately 68 vehicles of various types, including 19 fire engines, 5 water bowsers, 5 mist guns, 11 mini utility vehicles, 6 motorcycles, 3 rescue vans, 4 hydraulic platform vehicles, 6 Devdoot vehicles, and 2 jeeps. Among these, the hydraulic platform vehicles can reach up to 70 meters in height and are used for firefighting and rescue operations to prevent loss of life.
Garden Department - Hydraulic Platform

The Motor Vehicle Department has 10 hydraulic platform vehicles owned by the Municipal Corporation, all of which are operated by the Garden Department. These vehicles are used for trimming hazardous tree branches along city roads.
Electricity Department - Electric Ladder

The Motor Vehicle Department has a total of 11 electric ladder vehicles owned by the Municipal Corporation, with 11-meter and 13-meter capacities. These vehicles are used for streetlight maintenance in the city.
Encroachment and Unauthorized Construction Demolition Department - Utility Vehicles

The Motor Vehicle Department owns 15 utility trucks and 10 enclosed trucks (used by the demolition squad) for the Municipal Corporation. These vehicles are used for removing unauthorized street vendors and illegal constructions.
