raw.title: Pune Climate Action Plan
summary:
Project Brief

NIUA (National Institute of Urban Affairs) and GCoM (Global Covenant of Mayors) South Asia have partnered to support the Pune Municipal Corporation for the development of the Pune Climate Action Plan. Through this engagement, the project will work to support in implementing ambitious climate and energy commitments, focusing on ‘translating’ commitments into actions through the target and priority-setting process, based on Climate Action Plans. Over the past few months, a dedicated team at NIUA has been working on compiling a comprehensive Greenhouse Gas (GHG) inventory and conducting a thorough vulnerability assessment.

Journey So Far

We began the process of developing the Pune Climate Action Plan in May. Over the past few months, our dedicated team has been working on compiling a comprehensive Greenhouse Gas (GHG) inventory and conducting a thorough vulnerability assessment. We have conducted two stakeholder consultations, one in May and the other in September, with government officials, academia, civil society organizations, and educational institutions.

The culmination of this work was shared with key stakeholders, including the Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Environment at Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC), Shri. Madhav Jagtap; Chief Engineer of the Water Supply Department at PMC, Sh. Aniruddha Pawaskar; Deputy Commissioner of the Solid Waste Management Department at PMC, Smt. Asha Raut; Head of the Information Technology Department at PMC, Sh. Rahul Jagtap; and Environmental Conservation Officer of the Environment Department at PMC, Sh. Mangesh Dighe. Additionally, the NIUA team engaged in constructive dialogues with numerous departments and received data and suggestions from vital organizations and departments like the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD); Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology (IITM); Centre for Development of Advanced Computing, India (C-DAC); Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Co. Ltd. (MSEDCL); Maha Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MMRCL); and Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Ltd. (PMPML). This has helped us in identifying various interventions that might help fortify our city against the challenges of climate change.

What is a City Climate Action Plan (CCAP)?

A climate action plan is like a blueprint for a city to tackle the issue of climate change and reduce its impact on the environment. It's a comprehensive strategy or roadmap developed by governments, organizations, communities, or individuals to address the challenges of climate change and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. These plans are designed to mitigate the impacts of climate change and transition to a more sustainable and resilient future.

What is the relevance of the City Climate Action Plan?

Cities are centers of population and economic activity, and they are responsible for a significant portion of global greenhouse gas emissions. As more people around the world move to cities, the emissions from urban areas continue to rise. Climate action plans for cities are crucial in addressing this emissions challenge and mitigating climate change. Climate change has direct and immediate impacts on cities, including more frequent and severe heat waves, flooding, sealevel rise, and other extreme weather events. Local governments are often the first responders to these challenges, making it imperative to have plans in place to protect residents and infrastructure. It can lead to more energy-efficient buildings, better public transportation, green spaces, and cleaner industries, creating a higher quality of life for residents. Creating climate action plans for Indian cities is essential for addressing climate change, improving local environmental conditions, fostering sustainable development, and ensuring the well-being of citizens. Climate action plans involve input from local communities, encouraging citizen participation and ownership of environmental issues. This engagement can lead to more effective and sustainable solutions.

Why does Pune need a Climate Action Plan?

Pune has experienced significant growth and development. However, this progress has come at a cost in terms of increased greenhouse gas emissions and environmental challenges. As per the PMC Environment Status report 2018 (ESR), the city's average per-capita emissions have increased by 12% from 2012 to 2017, a rise within 5 years. This rising trend of per-capita emissions in Pune is a cause for concern. It has also caused more pollution and environmental problems. These problems not only contribute to climate change but also pose risk to the city's residents in the form of extreme heat and changing rainfall patterns. The rising temperatures have led to an increased reliance on air conditioning systems and making living conditions uncomfortable in the natural environment. Additionally, the changing rainfall pattern and the city's topography make it vulnerable to flooding, waterlogging, and landslides. Heavy rainfall combined with excessive concretization prevents water absorption that raises the potential for disasters in low-lying areas, along streams and rivers, and on hill slopes. To address these challenges and ensure a sustainable future, Pune needs to focus on clean energy infrastructure, efficient water management, and waste management. Implementing a comprehensive climate action plan is crucial for identifying and prioritizing actions to address environmental issues.

How will the Climate Action Plan benefit Pune city?

Climate Action Plan for Pune can have wide-ranging benefits, including environmental, economic, social, and health advantages. By addressing climate change and improving sustainability, Pune can become a more resilient, livable, and prosperous city for its residents. A Climate Action Plan for Pune can help the city with having a baseline of the emissions being produced in the city along with a diagnostic survey of the city’s existing infrastructure. By transitioning to cleaner energy sources, promoting energy efficiency, and implementing sustainable transportation options, Pune can contribute to global efforts to mitigate climate change.

A climate action plan would help Pune access funding for sustainable initiatives, engage stakeholders, and track progress towards its goals. It would further provide a roadmap for implementing water conservation measures, and improving waste management practices. By taking these steps, Pune can preserve its natural environment, mitigate climate change, and ensure a better quality of life for its residents.

Who will prepare the Climate Action Plan?

The Climate Action Plan is prepared for a city. Therefore, Pune Climate Action Plan is also a cityled initiative that will be prepared by the Pune Municipal Corporation where NIUA (National Institute of Urban Affairs) and GCoM (Global Covenant of Mayors) South Asia have partnered to facilitate and support the development of the same. Through this engagement, the project will work with Pune Municipal Corporation to support in implementing ambitious climate and energy commitments, focusing on ‘translating’ commitments into actions through the target and prioritysetting process, based on Climate Action Plans.

Who will implement the Climate Action Plan?

The final draft of the Climate Action Plan developed by the NIUA will be submitted to the Pune Municipal Corporation and the concerned city officials. The Pune Municipal Corporation will launch the same, based on which the city officials will be able to use the same going forward for various planning and development applications for the cities.

Role of Citizens

Citizen’s participation is crucial for developing a Climate Action Plan that is effective, inclusive, and sustainable. It strengthens community resilience, fosters ownership, and ensures that the plan reflects the unique needs and aspirations of Pune's residents, ultimately leading to a more climate-resilient and sustainable city.

As Citizen of Pune city, you can play a crucial role in developing the city's Climate Action Plan. Participate and share your ideas, concerns, and suggestions for the Climate Action Plan by filling the google form. Your opinions matter and can help shape the plan. Attend meetings and workshops organized by the Pune Municipal Corporation to provide your inputs for the development of Pune’s Climate Action Plan. Additionally, raise awareness about climate issues within your community and encourage others to participate in the survey by filling google form. Every small action counts towards building a more sustainable and climate-resilient city.

raw.title: Journey of Pune Fire Brigade
summary:
The Pune Fire Brigade has evolved significantly since its establishment. Below is an overview of its history and milestones:

1856

The Pune Municipality was established. However, until 1884, there was no public safety system in the municipality, and limited information is available regarding how the district authorities dealt with emergencies from 1856 to 1884.

1884-1914

During this period, hand pumps or manual engines were used to extinguish fires. As there were no telephones or motor vehicles, fire alerts were communicated by running or blowing whistles to the fire brigade office.

1912-1913

The Pune Municipality purchased two land steam fire engines, which increased the efficiency of the brigade by reducing human labor. However, the engines were still drawn by bullock carts, which consumed a lot of time and delayed the response, increasing the damage caused by the fires.

1924

To overcome this, in 1924, these engines were mounted on motor vehicles, significantly improving response times. The Renault company’s engines were equipped with a tank capable of carrying 500 gallons of water, which was constantly filled.

Expansion and Organization (1920s-1940s)

During this period, the city of Pune expanded, leading to the establishment of fire brigades in other municipalities and suburbs. However, there was a lack of coordination between the fire brigades of different municipalities, which sometimes led to conflicts during emergencies.

1942

To address this, in 1942, a cooperative association was formed, bringing together the fire brigades of Pune Municipal Corporation, suburban areas, and the cantonment. They agreed to share fire engines when necessary. A special officer for training and a chief officer with full decision-making authority were also appointed during this time.

1950

Pune Municipality was transformed into a Municipal Corporation, expanding its operational area. As more villages and towns came under the jurisdiction of Pune, new firefighting equipment was introduced. This included five 6-horsepower portable pumps, two trailer pumps, and two 450-gallon water tanks, which were utilized during emergencies. As the city continued to grow, the fire brigade evolved with more officers, staff, and positions being created to meet the increasing demands.

Current Status

Today, the Pune Fire Brigade operates 12 fire stations, with additional stations being established to meet the city’s growing needs. Over the years, the brigade has handled numerous difficult situations with expertise. Beyond fire-related incidents, the fire brigade is also called to assist in other emergencies such as:

  • Gas or toxic gas leaks
  • Fallen trees
  • Drowning accidents
  • Children trapped inside buildings
  • Rescuing trapped animals and birds

The Pune Fire Brigade continues to serve the city with dedication, responding swiftly to various emergencies and ensuring public safety.

raw.title: Fire Brigade Information
summary:
Among the essential services provided to citizens within the municipal limits, fire services are a critical responsibility of the Pune Municipal Corporation. To fulfill this duty, the Pune Municipal Corporation has established its own Fire Brigade. Under this service, in the event of a fire, natural or man-made disaster, or accidental incident within or outside the municipal limits, the Fire Brigade provides immediate necessary assistance to the citizens. The key information about the Fire Brigade is as follows:

  • Fire Stations in Pune: There are a total of 20 operational fire stations in Pune city at various locations.
  • Expansion Plans: Considering the growing expansion of the Pune Municipal Corporation, there are plans to establish 5 new fire stations in different parts of the city. These locations include. 
    • Mohammadwadi
    • Baner
    • Kharadi
    • Dhayari
    • Bavdhan
  • Headquarters Development: The old building of the Pune Fire Brigade headquarters is being demolished, and construction of a new "Main Administrative Center" is underway.
  • Staff and Vacancies: The Pune Fire Brigade has a total of 910 authorized positions across various ranks. Currently, 491 officers and staff are employed. There are 419 vacant positions in various categories. Recently, 160 personnel were recruited for the position of Fire Rescue Workers. For the first time, a woman has been appointed to this position at the Central Fire Station. A proposal for filling the remaining vacant positions will be presented soon.
  • Fire Vehicles: The Fire Brigade operates a variety of fire-fighting vehicles, and complete details about these vehicles are provided separately.
  • Fire Safety Awareness: The Fire Brigade organizes fire safety awareness programs and demonstrations at various locations in Pune, such as residential societies, schools, colleges, malls, multiplexes, hospitals, slum areas, industrial colonies, and government offices. These sessions provide primary fire safety measures and guidance on how to prevent and protect against fire hazards.

raw.title: Cultural Center Booking
summary:
Experience Pune’s Cultural Heritage with "Rang Yatra"

The Cultural Department of Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has launched the "Rang Yatra" mobile application for online booking and reservations of cultural centers owned by PMC within Pune city. This app digitizes the booking process, making it easy to reserve venues, process refunds, make payments, and cancel bookings, eliminating the need for manual paperwork.

Additionally, the app provides a detailed schedule of upcoming cultural events up to 3 months in advance, ensuring that citizens have access to the most accurate and up-to-date information. "Rang Yatra" is the only official application that provides a verified schedule of all events, programs, and shows hosted in PMC-owned cultural centers.

Download the "Rang Yatra" App Now:

Android: Download from Google Play - https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=in.gov.pmc.psrs&hl=en_IN
iOS: Download from the App Store - https://apps.apple.com/in/app/rang-yatra/id6714465033

Key Features of the "Rang Yatra" App:

  • Seamless Online Booking – Reserve cultural centers effortlessly.
  • Digitized Payment & Refund Process – Book, pay, and get refunds easily.
  • Official Event Timetable – Access schedules of upcoming events up to 3 months in advance.
  • Accurate & Verified Information – Get the correct details of all PMC-hosted shows and programs.
  • User-Friendly Interface – A smooth and intuitive experience for hassle-free bookings.

Explore, Experience, and Celebrate Pune’s Culture with the Rang Yatra App!

raw.title: Closed Circuit Television System (CCTV)
summary:
Complaint/Information:
The Closed Circuit Television (CCTV) system is part of the Pune City Surveillance (PCS) and is used to monitor the entire city of Pune. This system provides the following benefits:

  • Assists Pune Police in maintaining law and order in the city.
  • Provides support during investigations.
  • Improves traffic management.
  • Aids in investigating criminal activities and preventing them.
  • Assistance to Pune Police in maintaining law and order in the city.
  • This system provides 24-hour live video feeds, and it also has an automatic alert system. This allows the police to get real-time updates on the incident site and helps them take timely actions.

Assistance during investigations:
The system continuously records the area, making it easy for the police to review past incidents.

Assistance in traffic management:
The system is equipped with video analytics features that automatically alert when traffic rules are violated.

Investigating and preventing criminal activities:
Continuous video recordings, alerts on crowd gatherings, suspicious movement, or objects, and license plate recognition help the police in investigating crimes and preventing them.

Background:
The Pune City Police is responsible for law enforcement in an area of around 790 square kilometers, covering Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad. The Pune Police is a branch of the Maharashtra Police, and the current Pune Commissionerate was established on July 1, 1965. The Pune City Police Department operates through 33 police stations and is also responsible for traffic management on the city's roads.

The Police Commissionerate is divided into two divisions: North and South. An additional Police Commissioner is appointed for each division. Each division is further split into two sub-divisions, resulting in a total of four sub-divisions in Pune city: Division-1, Division-2, Division-3, and Division-4. The responsibility of each sub-division lies with a Deputy Police Commissioner, and Assistant Police Commissioners oversee these sub-divisions.

Details of the Police Divisions and Sub-Divisions:

Zone-4Khadki
Wanawadi

Pune Police Commissionerate consists of a total of 9 sub-divisions. Each sub-division houses 2 to 6 police stations. Additionally, there are a total of 33 police stations, including those under the Pimpri-Chinchwad Municipal Corporation and two defense cantonment boards. Each police station is headed by a Senior Police Inspector, and there are 107 police chowkies under the Pune Police Commissionerate, each led by an API/PSI officer.

Beneficiaries of the System:

  • Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC)
  • Pimpri-Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC)
  • Khadki Cantonment Board (KCB)
  • Pune Cantonment Board (PCB)
  • Airports, Railways
  • Shopping Malls, Multiplexes, Cinemas, Schools, Hotels, Hospitals, and other public places
  • Financial Institutions, Corporate Houses
  • General Public

Overview:

 The PCS system, based on IP-based outdoor security cameras, is installed across the city. Video data captured from various cameras is stored in data centers. This data is monitored from all police stations, police commissioner offices, PMC offices, and PCMC offices.

  • The system includes 1,363 cameras.
  • 1,068 fixed-box cameras
  • 217 Pan-Tilt-Zoom (PTZ) cameras
  • 78 Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) cameras

These cameras are installed at 418 locations, including NPR cameras. The live feed from these cameras is saved and transmitted to the data center. Data can be stored for up to 90 days, with live feeds from ANPR cameras being stored for up to 180 days.

Monitoring Centers:

The following monitoring centers have been set up to monitor the live feed:

  • Police Commissioner Office: The monitoring center here can track up to 150 cameras at a time.
  • Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC): This monitoring center can track 60 cameras at a time.
  • Pimpri-Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC): This center can track 25 cameras at a time.
  • District Collector Office: This center can monitor 10 cameras at a time.
  • Control Centers in Divisional Offices: From these centers, 10% of the cameras in each division can be monitored.
  • Police Stations: The monitoring centers in 40 police stations can track 40% of the cameras installed in their jurisdiction.

Components of the System:

  • Network and Connectivity:
    All equipment used for surveillance is connected via a dedicated network, providing 24/7 access to video feeds at data centers and monitoring centers.
  • Data Centers and Applications:
    High-end server facilities with large storage capacities have been established to store video data from all cameras and monitoring applications.
  • Control and Monitoring Centers:
    A control center has been set up at the Police Commissionerate, with additional centers at the offices of the Additional Police Commissioner, Deputy Police Commissioner, PMC, PCMC, District Collector Office, and police stations for live video-feed monitoring.
  • Joint Monitoring:
    The surveillance system will soon integrate with the monitoring systems of private and public institutions, allowing live feeds in case of an emergency situation.
  • Help Desk and Facility Management System:
    A special mechanism has been created for the maintenance of infrastructure, with support from human resources. A responsive help desk ensures that any technical issues are resolved quickly to restore the system's functionality.

Appropriate Use of the System:

  • Maintaining Law and Order:
    This includes monitoring local disturbances, riots, crowd gatherings, public celebrations, events, and fire-related incidents.
  • Investigation of Crimes:
    The system helps in investigating cases of burglary, robbery, and theft, identifying individuals and vehicles, harassment by shopkeepers/local people, assaults, and murder investigations.
  • Traffic Control:
    Cameras can be used to monitor traffic routes, congestion at intersections, traffic networks, violations of traffic rules, hit-and-run cases, and accidents, providing crucial information during incidents.

This system plays a vital role in enhancing public safety, improving law enforcement, and maintaining smooth traffic management in Pune city.

raw.title: Fire and Rescue Vehicle
summary:
• Latest cutting edge state of art technology system with combined features and functionality of both Fire Tendering as well as Emergency Rescue Operation, and capable of moving at high speeds. Its compact and light weight structure enables to reach the accident spot and its combined function helps to perform the complete job within no time, whereby savings valuable lives and assets of people
  • The vehicle is equipped with high pressure jetting system capable of combating the deadliest fire and at the same time the sophisticated rescue tools help in evacuation and safe guarding valuables
  • Safeguarding the lives of not only the people in accident but also the fire fighting personnel is equally important in any fire rescue operations. The vehicle is equipped with all those tools and gadgets to monitor the fire personnel during the fire fighting and evacuation operation and update the backup teams for immediate support if needed
  • Aryan’s Multi functional vehicle is powered by the powerful chassis engine with higher payloads. We are also proud to say that only our vehicle is ARAI approved for 1+3 seating and able to accommodate all the equipment that this vehicle is built for
  • As well as acting as reconnaissance vehicle, with on-board firefighting equipment, such as tanks, pumps and monitors, they are also able to respond to minor incidents alone, or act as front-line or additional response vehicles as part of a highly efficient response system
  • Features & Functionality:

    • Operation capability at all locations such as cities, villages, coastal areas, hill stations and in all climatic conditions and difficult situations
    • Efficient use of manpower and resources to deploy this system

    • Agile movement and operation in heavy traffic conditions and narrow and limited spaces

raw.title: Riverfront Development Project
summary:
Riverfront Development

River Mula and Mutha are very important rivers passing through the centre of Pune city bifurcating the PMC and PCMC areas. The twin cities are experiencing heavy urbanization for the past few decades which has created pressure on these rivers.

The rivers have become largely inaccessible from the city and are no longer seen as assets to the city. The city has turned its back on these rivers. In order to cope with these current issues and create a meaningful public realm along the rivers, Pune Municipal Corporation has instigated a comprehensive project - Mula, Mutha and Mula-Mutha Riverfront Development Project in the entire Pune Municipal corporation area.

There are three rivers passing through the Pune Municipal Corporation area namely Mula, Mutha and Mula-Mutha, with an approximate total length of 44kms and widths varying from 80mts to 250mts.

raw.title: Machinery Permit
summary:
Permission for machinery used in production is granted by the License and Sky Sign Department under Section 313. According to Schedule 18, Parts 1 to 4 of Section 313 of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act, machinery operating on electricity, water, or steam requires approval after submitting the necessary documents in the prescribed SP-5 form. These machinery permits must be renewed periodically by submitting the required documents in the SP-6 form.

For example, permits are issued for businesses involved in cloth dyeing, electroplating, spice production, brick and tile manufacturing, dynamite production, metal casting, fireworks, slaked lime, matchboxes, rubber products, paper, snuff, soap making, and tar processing.

Under Section 376(1)(d)(2), permits are also issued for businesses such as blacksmith work, metal sheet covering, brass work, glasswork, wood cutting mills, metalworking on lathes, machine laundries, carpentry workshops using electricity or other power sources, tire retreading, plastic manufacturing, and French polish production.

When an application is received for a business using machinery powered by electricity, water, or steam, the permit inspector conducts a site visit. The business owner is then informed about the required documents for the permit. After verifying these documents, the inspector forwards the application through the Municipal Assistant Commissioner for approval by the Deputy Commissioner of the concerned zone.

Once a permit is granted, a No Objection Certificate (NOC) is issued for the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited (MSEDCL). The business owner must then submit an application to MSEDCL to obtain electricity for the business.

raw.title: Solar Tax Benefits
summary:
Pune is going the solar way.

The city is the second-largest market in terms of solar manufacturers and users in the country

The city has the ideal weather conditions for using solar devices. Currently, about 20 per cent of the houses in Pune are using solar water heating units. This percentage would increase because of the central and local government incentives mentioned below.

The solar water heaters are not expensive if we consider their long-term utility. One family has to spend approximately Rs. 25,000 for a solar water heater. The central government is promoting the installation of solar water heating systems through a soft loan scheme being operated through the Indian Renewable Energy Development Agency Ltd and banks.

The government also provides an interest subsidy, besides a 5% rebate on property tax. Capital subsidy is available for installation of solar water heating systems to registered institutions and commercial establishments.

Citizens can receive the benefits of this tax rebate by applying at the respective ward offices. One can submit the application on plain piece of paper along with photographs of solar system installed.

raw.title: Pune 24X7 Water Supply
summary:
Old Limits of the Integrated Water Supply Project: 

  • Pune City has been divided into a total of 5 sections based on the capacity of its water treatment centres.
    (Package-1: Parvati, Package-2: Bhama Askhed, Jagtik Line, Package-3: Warje, Package-4: Lashkar and Package-5: Vadgaon)
  • Each section includes the construction of water storage tanks, the main pressure pipelines that supply water to these tanks (Packages 6 & 7), works on the water distribution mains, pumping stations, civic amenity centres, etc.
  • The project comprises a total of 7 civic amenity centres.
  • AMR meters will be installed on water connections throughout the city under the project.
  • The completed works under the project will be transferred for maintenance and repairs to the contractors: M/s. L & T Construction (Packages 1, 2, 3, 5) and M/s. Jain Irrigation System (Package-4).

Water Supply Project – Newly Included 34 Villages + Yevalewadi:

Details of the Water Supply Scheme for the Included Villages

  • For the villages of Bavdhan Bu, Mhalunge & Sus, and Lohagaon & Wagholi, 5, 6, and 13 tanks are proposed respectively; the tender process for the pipeline works in these villages has been completed and the on-site work is underway.
  • For the villages of Narhe, Ambegaon Bu., Ambegaon Khu., Kolewadi, Jambhulwadi, Dhayri, Khadakwasla, Nandoshi, Nanded, Kirkatwadi, and Sanas nagar, the DPR work has been completed.
  • The preparation of the DPR is in progress for the villages of Bhilarewadi, Gadewadi, Gujer Nimbalkarwadi, Yevalewadi, Shevalwadi, Hadapsar Sadesathrani, Keshavnagar Mundhwa, Undri, Pisoli, Vadachiwadi, Holkarwadi, Autade Handewadi, Kondhve Dhavde, Kopare, Shivane, Uttam Nagar, Manjari Bu. Furusungi, and Uruli Devachi.

raw.title: Cultural Center Services
summary:
Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) provides a range of cultural services through its cultural centers, fostering arts, heritage, and community engagement. These centers serve as hubs for artistic expression, learning, and cultural preservation.

Services Offered:

  • Event & Program Hosting – Organizing cultural festivals, exhibitions, and workshops.
  • Arts & Heritage Promotion – Supporting local artists, theater, and traditional performances.
  • Community Engagement – Conducting cultural awareness programs and public participation events.
  • Library & Learning Resources – Providing access to books, manuscripts, and research materials on cultural heritage.
  • Auditorium & Venue Rentals – Offering spaces for cultural and social events.

These services aim to preserve Pune’s rich cultural heritage while encouraging creativity and participation among citizens.

Sr. No Different Application to Tree Authority Documents
1 Trimming of branches of trees 1. Application with address

Copies of the map to be approved by the Building Permission Department, signed by the concerned Architect, showing the location of the existing trees on the property by tracing them in Green color along with their serial numbers and the location of the trees to be planted as per the rating by tracing them in blue color.

5. Form A in the prescribed format containing the name and signature of the owner/occupier for the tree census under Section 7(b) of Tree Act.

a) The tree / tree expansion is dangerous.
b) The tree / tree expansion is being hindered by obstacles.

2. Commencement Certificate
3. Provisional No Objection Certificate.

5 The number of new trees to be planted to replace the trees to be felled shall be equal to the estimated age of the trees to be felled. Trees are shown in blue and proposed replanting trees are shown in yellow on the map . The measurements should be shown with the water.
6. Photo of the tree to be cut down.
7. Documents related to ownership of the land.
8. Form D Under Section 11(2) L Guarantee.

a) Number of trees planted in lieu of felling of trees .........

2. Photos of planted trees.

6. Current status of the trees to be replanted as per the permission letter : Out of which........live trees ........dead tree.
7. A color photograph of the tree to be planted as a replacement for the trees cut down, including the geographical location and location of the tree, and information about the tree's name in front of it.

raw.title: EV readiness plan for city
summary:
The Pune Municipal Corporation is working with RMI and RMI India for preparing an EV readiness plan that determines the actions to be undertaken by various stakeholders to develop a conducive EV ecosystem that accelerates EV adoption in the city.

The EV readiness plan for the city shall set quantitative targets to be achieved by Pune EV ecosystem within the desired timeline. The plan shall also provide a detailed solutions identifying short-term and long-term goals and guide the respective stakeholders to achieve these targets.

City EV Accelerator Workshop:

The Pune city accelerator workshop was conducted on 16th of December, 2021 with an aim of seeking inputs and insights from various stakeholders to inform Pune’s EV readiness plan. The objectives were as follows:

  • Identify barriers in the EV ecosystem and corresponding cross-cutting enablers that Pune City can implement to support the EV ecosystem.
  • Make the city an attractive destination for setting up EV businesses and pilots
  • Generate insights to guide other cities in the state and inform state and national EV policy frameworks

raw.title: Information & Technology Awards
summary:
IEEE International Smart Cities Award - Emerging Economy - Legacy Cities

The Pune Municipal Corporation’s innovative 'PMC Care' project has won the first prize in the ‘Emerging Economy - Legacy Cities category at the IEEE International Smart Cities Award. The award, conferred by the IEEE Smart Cities Technical Community, was presented at the IEEE International Smart Cities Conference held in Pattaya, Thailand, from October 29 to November 1, 2024.

PMC Care is a citizen engagement platform designed to boost public participation in municipal activities and to streamline access to services through a mobile app and portal. The platform provides essential services and updates, including grievance redressal, online payment of municipal taxes like property tax, and notifications on water shutdowns. It also keeps citizens informed of various city-centric updates and services the civic body offers. The platform has already been widely adopted, with lakhs of Pune citizens actively using the service, gaining international recognition for its impactful role in enhancing citizen engagement.

Awards: Results of IEEE Smart Cities Contest 2024

 

City E-Governance Index

Policy Research Organization (PRO) is a Pune-based think tank primarily focusing on research and analysis of local urban policies and governance. Their work focuses on generating insights into local governance to deepen understanding and drive meaningful change. By producing high-quality research and data-driven content, they aim to empower policymakers, advocacy groups, media, politicians, and citizens with the tools they need to make informed decisions.

In 2025 Pune Municipal Corporation received first rank in Maharashtra with a total score of 8.22 out of 10. In past years PMC has improved its performance. In year 2023 it was ranked 5th in Maharashtra, in 2024 4th and now in 2025, it is ranked 1st.

raw.title: Are EVs economically cheaper to be driven in Pune?
summary:
Vehicle Total Cost of Ownership (TCO)

The TCO of a vehicle can be interpreted as the expenses incurred by the user throughout the life of the vehicle. Though EVs have a higher upfront cost, the cost of operation is significantly lower as compared to ICE vehicles. Further, with higher daily travelled distance, the economics for EVs improve.

A) Two wheeler Private use

Daily distance travelled in km: 30 km
Maximum life of vehicle in years: 7 years
Maximum life of the vehicle in km: 250000 km
National and state incentives reduce the overall capital cost of electric 2W (private uses) by 64%.

B) Two wheeler Commercial use

Daily distance travelled in km: 60 km
Maximum life of vehicle in years: 7 years
Maximum life of the vehicle in km: 250000 km
National and state incentives reduce the overall capital cost of electric 2W (commercial use) by 58%.

C) Three wheeler autos

Daily distance travelled in km: 80 km
Maximum life of vehicle in years: 12 years
Maximum life of the vehicle in km: 600000 km
National and state incentives reduce the overall capital cost of electric auto by 49%

D) Four wheeler car Private use

Daily distance travelled in km: 50 km
Maximum life of vehicle in years: 10 years
Maximum life of the vehicle in km: 300000 km
National and state incentives reduce the overall capital cost of electric 4W (private use) by 39%

E) Four wheeler car Commercial use

Daily distance travelled in km: 160 km
Maximum life of vehicle in years: 10 years
Maximum life of the vehicle in km: 400000 km
National and state incentives reduce the overall capital cost of electric 4W (commercial use) by 48%

F) PMPML electric buses: Total Cost of Ownership

The total cost of ownership (TCO) of any mode of transport is the expenses incurred by the user throughout the life of the vehicle. (i.e., the price of a purchased good or service plus all other costs related to owning and operating it). According to our analysis, the TCO of an e-bus with incentives is INR 51.49/km—about 5 percent and 15 percent lower than the TCO of CNG (INR 54.09/km) and diesel buses (INR 59.89/km), respectively.

The TCO of the e-bus without government incentives is estimated to be 10 percent less than that of a comparable diesel bus and almost equal to that of a comparable CNG bus.

Each e-bus can save about INR 69 lakhs (about USD 92,000) over the lifetime of the vehicle compared to a CNG or diesel variant. This results in cost savings of about INR 450 crores (about USD 60 million) for the fleet of 650 e-buses. The maintenance cost of conventional-fuel buses can be three times greater than the maintenance cost of e-buses. Moreover, the cost of fuel per kilometer is much lower. Electricity is INR 6/kWh (or INR 6.79/km) and the current cost per litre of diesel in Maharashtra is INR 96.72/litre ( or 19.25/km). Despite the additional costs associated with charging infrastructure equipment and installation and battery replacement, the cost of operating a CNG or diesel bus is about 10 percent higher than an e-bus.

raw.title: Key Rules for Safety and Precaution
summary:
Fire Safety Guidelines

Handling Cooking Gas Cylinders

What to Do:

  • Open all doors and windows immediately if there is a gas leak.
  • Turn off the gas regulator.
  • Always close the gas valve before sleeping.
  • Call the fire brigade by dialling 101.

What to Avoid:

  • Do not place the cylinder horizontally or near the stove.
  • Do not switch electric appliances on or off during a gas leak.
  • Do not use gas tubes without the ISI mark.
  • Do not ignore a continuously flickering gas flame.

Educational Institutions / Schools

What to Do:

  • Ensure firefighting equipment is well-maintained.
  • Alert everyone by sounding alarms during emergencies.
  • Have evacuation spots pre-planned for students and staff.
  • Train students and staff on emergency procedures.

What to Avoid:

  • Do not panic or engage in unsafe behaviour.
  • Do not move away from designated evacuation areas.
  • Do not delay giving first aid to victims.
  • Never disobey firefighters' instructions.

Bursting Firecrackers

What to Do:

  • Keep a bucket of water and sand nearby.
  • Wear cotton clothing and maintain a safe distance.
  • Dispose of used crackers in water or sand.
  • Only burst crackers in open spaces under adult supervision.

What to Avoid:

  • Never burst crackers indoors.
  • Do not relight partially burnt crackers.
  • Avoid throwing burning crackers in open areas.
  • Do not allow small children to handle dangerous crackers.

Safety Guidelines for Different Situations In Industrial Factories

What to Do:

  • Maintain fire safety equipment regularly.
  • Keep flammable substances away from welding areas.
  • Use protective gear like gloves and glasses.

What to Avoid:

  • Do not leave live wires exposed.
  • Do not smoke in no-smoking zones.
  • Do not leave welding guns unattended.

For High-Rise Buildings

What to Do:

  • Be mentally prepared to use fire safety tools.
  • Familiarize yourself with emergency exits.
  • Organize regular fire drills.

What to Avoid:

  • Do not delay evacuation.
  • Do not block stairways.
  • Never use the lift during a fire emergency.

During Earthquakes or Floods

What to Do:

  • During earthquakes, shield your head and stand near structural columns.
  • Turn off gas, electricity, and water supplies.
  • During floods, move to higher ground immediately.

What to Avoid:

  • Do not stand near balconies during earthquakes or floods.
  • Avoid touching electrical appliances during floods.
  • Do not believe or spread rumours during disasters.

General Safety

What to Do:

  • Keep stoves, matches, and chemicals away from children.
  • Replace damaged electrical wiring immediately.
  • Ensure all electrical devices are turned off when not in use.

What to Avoid:

  • Avoid cluttering homes or offices.
  • Do not smoke in public places.
  • Use sand or soil to extinguish electrical fires, not water.

By following these guidelines, we can ensure our safety and effectively handle emergencies.

As per the resolution No. 1/455 dated 29/07/2008 of the Municipal Commissioner of Pune Municipal Corporation and the authority transfer order No. Outward No. GA. VA. The zoning-related work within the jurisdiction is carried out through 15 regional offices under the control of the concerned Deputy Commissioner and competent authority for Divisions 1 to 5. raw.title: Frequently Asked Questions
summary:
Department of Encroachment / Unauthorized Construction Removal

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) on Services or Administrative Workings.

1. Is it illegal to do business in any part of Pune city?
Answer: Encroachments on public roads, building side margins, roads, or footpaths in Pune Municipal Corporation areas are considered illegal.

2. Are small businesses on public roads / footpaths legal / authorized?
Answer: Citizens who obtain written permission or a license from the Municipal Corporation and comply with the rules are considered legal businesses.

3. What action is taken if a licensed business fails to comply with the conditions of the license or occupies more space?
Answer: Initially, a warning is issued. If the rules are not followed, the license is suspended, goods are seized, or the license is revoked.

4. Where can complaints regarding encroachments on roads / footpaths be made?
Answer: Complaints can be filed in writing, by phone, or by email to the Assistant Commissioner of the relevant ward office.

5. What action is taken against illegal encroachments, and how soon is action taken after an application?
Answer: An initial survey is conducted, and based on the type of encroachment, goods are seized or a warning is issued. Action is generally taken within 7 to 15 days.

6. Is action only taken on citizen complaints, or does the ward office take action on its own?
Answer: No, the ward office regularly takes action on illegal encroachments on its own.

7. What preventive measures are taken against repeat offenders of encroachments?
Answer: Their goods are seized and are not immediately returned. Additionally, other government departments like Health and Police also take legal action as per the law.

8. Who is responsible for future encroachments after removal?
Answer: The responsibility lies with the concerned ward office, appointed officers, and the police department jointly.

9. Can seized goods be retrieved after encroachment removal? What fine is levied?
Answer: After the vendor's application, goods are returned after payment of a specified fee as per the Municipal Corporation's policy.

10. Does PMC compensate for damages to vendors' goods after removal of encroachments?
Answer: No, the Municipal Corporation does not provide any compensation for damages.

11. Can any citizen or business have permission to do business on footpaths?
Answer: Citizens who meet the criteria as per PMC's policy are granted permission.

12. Under "The Street Vendors Act-2014," is it permissible to set up a stall or do business on roads / footpaths?
Answer: No, vendors without an old stall license or newly registered vendors must conduct business only with a handcart or "pothari."

13. Can registered vendors set up stalls or permanent structures for their business?
Answer: No.

14. Can registered vendors transfer their license or business to someone else?
Answer: No.

15. Do registered vendors get electricity, water, or sewage connections?
Answer: No, newly registered vendors are not provided with legal or illegal electricity, water, or drainage connections.

16. Can food street vendors use flammable substances like gas, kerosene, etc.?
Answer: No, but eligible vendors following the rules are allocated space in the "Food Market Zone" as determined by the Municipal Corporation.

17.What action is taken against registered vendors who use more space than authorized?
Answer: If the rules are not followed after a warning, the license is suspended, goods are seized, or the license is revoked.

18. Does the Municipal Corporation give temporary permission for selling fruits or goods during festivals or seasons?
Answer: This depends on the prevailing policy under "The Street Vendors Act-2014."

19. Is permission required to erect tents, stages, or arches on public roads?
Answer: Yes, an application must be submitted with the necessary documents according to the "Pandal Policy-2015."

20. Where should an application for permission to set up a tent, stage, or arch be submitted?
Answer: The application should be submitted to the Assistant Commissioner of the concerned ward office.

21. Is it legal to dig up roads and set up tents, stages, arches, etc.?
Answer: No, if found, a fine is imposed as per the "Booth Policy-2015."

22. Does PMC take action on illegal tents, stages, arches, etc.?
Answer: Yes, the ward office takes action as per the prevailing policies.

23. Is it permissible to put banners on official tents for private companies or political advertisements?
Answer: Special permission is required for this.

24. What action is taken if tents, stages, or arches are not removed after the permitted period?
Answer: The ward office will take legal action and seize the goods.

25. Is it legal to place materials on the road during construction or renovation?
Answer: No, PMC issues notices and seizes the materials.

26. Does PMC take action on abandoned or damaged vehicles?
Answer: Yes, vehicles are seized after issuing a notice.

27. Is it permissible to park vehicles on the road for more than 7 days or for sale?
Answer: No.

28. Can private passenger buses stop anywhere to pick up passengers?
Answer: No, action is taken if found.

29. Does PMC take action on illegal religious places?
Answer: Yes, citizens can file complaints on the PMC Care app.

30. Where should complaints about noise pollution be made?
Answer: Complaints should be made at the local police station or on the PMC website.

raw.title: Website Policy
summary:
Copyright Policy

The content featured on this portal can be reproduced in any form or medium without requiring specific permission. However, this is subject to the condition that the content is accurately reproduced and is not used in a derogatory or misleading context. When content is published or issued to others, the source must be prominently acknowledged.

This permission does not extend to any content on this portal that is identified as third-party copyright material. Authorization to reproduce such material must be obtained from the copyright holders concerned.

Privacy Policy

This portal does not automatically capture any specific personal information (such as name, phone number, or email) from visitors that can identify them personally. The portal logs the following information for statistical purposes:

  • Internet Protocol (IP) address
  • Domain name
  • Browser type
  • Operating system
  • Date and time of visit
  • Pages accessed

These details are not linked to the identities of individuals unless an attempt to damage the site is detected. We do not attempt to track users' browsing activities unless legally required by law enforcement agencies.

If the Pune Municipal Corporation portal requests personal information from you, you will be informed about the purpose for which it will be used, and adequate security measures will be taken to protect your personal information.

Updates to Privacy Policy:

  • Cookie Policy: The portal may use cookies to enhance user experience. These cookies do not store personally identifiable information.
  • Data Retention: User data collected for specific interactions, such as form submissions, will be retained only for the duration required by municipal regulations.

Linking Policy

  1. Links to External Websites/Portals:
    This portal contains links to other government, non-government, or private organization websites/portals. These links are provided for user convenience. When navigating to an external website, the privacy and security policies of the respective site will apply. Pune Municipal Corporation is not responsible for the content or reliability of the linked websites and does not endorse the views expressed in them. The presence of links should not be considered an endorsement of their content or views.
  2. Links from External Websites/Portals to This Portal:
    Direct links to this portal's content are permitted without prior approval, provided the content is accurately represented and not framed within another website. All linked content must open in a new browser window.

Updates to Linking Policy:

  • Links to PMC pages must maintain the original context and presentation without modifications.
  • Framing PMC pages within external sites remains prohibited to ensure user transparency

raw.title: Amrit Mahotsav competition winning logo
summary:
Implementation of the Amrit Mahotsav Logo Across PMC Departments

The Cultural Department of Pune Municipal Corporation has successfully conducted an Online Logo Competition as part of the Amrit Mahotsav of Pune Municipal Corporation celebrations. This initiative was undertaken to create a distinctive visual identity for all activities and programs organized under the Amrit Mahotsav banner. The Cultural Department, known for promoting artistic talent and cultural heritage in the city, received an overwhelming response to this competition with more than 300 creative submissions from artists, designers, and art enthusiasts. The department had announced this competition through various media channels and educational institutions to ensure maximum participation from the creative community.

After a rigorous selection process, Miss. Tanuja Suresh Nanekar from Nanekarwadi, Taluka Khed, Pune District has been declared the winner of this prestigious competition.

Jury Panel

The competition entries were evaluated by a distinguished panel of art educators and experts:

  • Shri Rahul Balwant, Principal, Abhinav Kala Mahavidyalaya
  • Ms. Samata Bendre, Vice Principal, Dr. D. Y. Patil College, Akurdi
  • Shri Girish Charwad, Principal, Fine Arts College, Bharati Vidyapeeth, Pune

The Cultural Department organized multiple rounds of judging to ensure a fair and transparent selection process. The final design was chosen based on its creative concept, visual appeal, and relevance to the theme of Amrit Mahotsav.

Implementation Directive:

All PMC departments are directed to download and incorporate the official Amrit Mahotsav logo in official communications, documents, and activities throughout the year, ensuring a consistent and unified identity for the celebrations.

The Cultural Department will be organizing a special felicitation ceremony to honor the winner and acknowledge all participants' contributions to this national celebration.

raw.title: About PMC
summary:
Pune Municipal Corporation: Celebrating the 75th Anniversary of Its Formation

The city of Pune is very important in India from the cultural, educational, and industrial perspective. The city is important due to the Pune Municipal Corporation, which has been actively involved in the governance, development, and well-being of the citizens of the city. The Pune Municipal Corporation played a key role in the development of the city over the last 75 years. The Pune Municipal Corporation will be celebrating its 75th anniversary in the year 2025, thus reaching a milestone.

Population and Area of Pune Municipal Corporation

The geographical area of the Pune Municipal Corporation is around 527 square kilometers. According to the 2011 census, the population of the city of Pune is over 94,26,959 people. The continuous growth of the suburbs is the reason for the continuous population growth of the city, thus increasing the demand for infrastructure development.

Work Areas of the Pune Municipal Corporation

Pune Municipal Corporation is at the forefront of every sector. Some of the prime sectors are listed below:

1. Education

Education Pune city is a major and prominent center of higher schooling and education. The Municipal Corporation implements various programs of school education in Pune. Various programs have been launched in PMC schools for imparting quality education to students.

2. Hygiene and Health

The Pune Municipal Corporation operates the 'Swachh Pune, Sundar Pune' initiative in the direction of promoting cleanliness. The Corporation is also actively engaged in enhancing sanitation through waste collection management, sewage treatment, and health centers. Free treatment to citizens is offered by public hospitals and primary health centers.

3. Traffic Management

The Pune Municipal Corporation is constantly involved in resolving traffic problems. With the implementation of the metro and the development of cycle tracks, attempts are being made to improve traffic management in the city. Besides this, the Corporation is constantly attempting to upgrade the quality of roads in Pune.

4. Water Supply and Water Management

Water Supply and Water Management Different sources of water supply water to the city of Pune. Water storage and water conservation are the key concerns for the Corporation to try to develop better methods of water management. The water supply system of Pune has been improved to provide a more efficient delivery.

5. Cultural and Tourism Sector

Cultural and Tourism Sector Pune city is culturally and historically significant. Pune Municipal Corporation hosts various cultural events and is involved in the preservation of historical places. Therefore, Pune's significance in the tourism industry has grown.

6. Smart City and New Technology

The Pune Municipal Corporation is also modernizing the city's various services under the Smart City initiative. For increased convenience and service to Pune citizens, smart traffic lights and digital services have been made available.

7. Housing and Social Security

Housing and Social Security The Municipal Corporation administers huge housing schemes to benefit the poor and weaker sections. Besides, it endeavors to enhance public health services and encourage social security schemes for the well-being of citizens.

Pune Municipal Corporation's work on the occasion of its 75th anniversary:

Corporation celebrates its 75th anniversary, it is clear that tremendous progress has been made in all sectors of the city. During this period, the Corporation has made many significant decisions to promote the growth of the city. In celebration of the 75th anniversary, the Pune Municipal Corporation is adopting future plans to enable the city's next phase of growth. The Pune Municipal Corporation has a very important role in the development and governance of the city of Pune. The Corporation has worked earnestly for 75 years, and during that time, it has worked wonders in various areas such as School Education, Health, Sanitation, Transport, Water Management, and Culture. In the 75th year of the city, the work of the Pune Municipal Corporation has offered a positive perspective for the city's future. The work of the Corporation at the current juncture will also contribute even more to the overall growth of the city.

raw.title: Garden Rules
summary:
1. Do not cause any damage to the garden features or amenities.
  2. Use the walking track in a single direction while strolling in the garden.
  3. Dispose of waste in the bins provided. Maintain cleanliness in the garden and restrooms. Avoid water wastage.
  4. Garden play equipment is for children under 12 years, while gym equipment is for individuals above 16 years and should be used at their own risk.
  5. Playing outdoor or seated games in the garden is strictly prohibited.
  6. Bringing pets or feeding animals and birds within the garden is strictly prohibited.
  7. Spitting, smoking, consuming alcohol, engaging in indecent behavior, or acting inappropriately within the garden premises is strictly prohibited.
  8. Bringing any private vehicles or bicycles into the garden is strictly prohibited.
  9. Political flags, banners, signs, posters, or advertisements are not allowed in the garden premises.
  10. Do not touch any electrical appliances or wires within the garden.
  11. Avoid using prohibited materials like plastic, thermocol, or inflammable substances. Do not create hazardous situations in the garden.
  12. Vendors, hawkers, cooking, selling, eating, littering, or causing pollution in the garden are strictly prohibited.
  13. Follow the directive issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, on 18/01/2024, regarding the Flag Code of India.
  14. Citizens visiting the garden are responsible for their belongings like mobile phones, valuable items, etc.
  15. Organizing public meetings, festivals, processions, rallies, cultural or religious events, or other gatherings without prior approval is strictly prohibited.
  16. Activities such as environmental exhibitions, health and yoga camps, recreational clubs, picnics, art competitions, photography, or video shooting are not allowed without prior permission.
  17. Do not argue with security personnel if trying to access the garden outside designated hours.
  18. Security guards are authorized to enforce these rules and take necessary action if violations occur.
  19. Any individual or organization found engaging in unauthorized construction, misuse of space, or violating these rules will be penalized under the Public Property Damage Prevention Act, 1984.
  20. Citizens visiting the garden are requested to cooperate with the Pune Municipal Corporation by adhering to these rules to keep the garden well-maintained.

raw.title: 43rd Fruits, Flowers, and Vegetable Exhibition by Pune Municipal Corporation
summary:
Description: 

 

On the occasion of the 75th anniversary of Pune Municipal Corporation, the Garden Department and Tree Authority are organizing the 43rd Fruits, Flowers, and Vegetable Exhibition. This grand event will take place on Saturday, 15th February 2025, and Sunday, 16th February 2025, at Chhatrapati Sambhaji Raje Garden, Jangli Maharaj Road, Shivajinagar, Pune.

Exhibition Highlights

  1. Diverse and Attractive Sections:
    • Displays of ornamental plants and flower arrangements.
    • Artistic decoration with flowers.
    • Grand showcases of roses and seasonal flowers.
    • Special sections on gardens and tree conservation initiatives.
  2. Competitions:
    • Competitions based on fruits, flowers, and vegetables across various categories.
    • Special attraction: Nature and environment-themed photography competition.
  3. Sales and Stalls:
    • Sale of ornamental plants, fruit trees, and gardening materials.
    • Stall fee: ₹2,950/- (including rent and cleaning charges).

Program Schedule

  • Inauguration: Saturday, 15th February 2025, at 11:00 AM.
  • Prize Distribution: Sunday, 16th February 2025, at 5:00 PM.
  • Exhibition Timings:
    • 15th February: 11:00 AM to 8:30 PM.
    • 16th February: 8:00 AM to 8:30 PM.

Entry Details

  • Free Entry, but submission of a registration form is mandatory for participation.
  • Interested participants should complete their registration by 9th February 2025.

Contact Information

  • Mr. Ratnakar Karade (Assistant Garden Officer): 9689938523
  • Ms. Snehal Harpale (Assistant Garden Officer): 9689930024
  • Ms. Shruti Nazirkar (Assistant Garden Officer): 9689937553

All citizens, school students, farmers, and gardening enthusiasts are cordially invited to participate in this grand exhibition.

(Ashok Ghorpade), Chief Garden Officer, Pune Municipal Corporation

 

Start Date: 

Saturday, February 15, 2025 to Sunday, February 16, 2025

Department Name:

  • Garden Department

raw.title: Pune Municipal Corporation's 75th Anniversary Online Logo Design Competition
summary:
Terms and Conditions for Pune Municipal Corporation’s 75th Anniversary Online Logo Competition

  1. The Pune Municipal Corporation's 75th Anniversary Online Logo Competition is free of charge. The logo design should reflect the image of Pune Municipal Corporation and represent the journey of the Amrut Mahotsav (Platinum Jubilee).
  2. The design should blend traditional values with a modern perspective.
  3. The logo should be compact and fit within minimal space.
  4. It should be suitable for use across various mediums, including print and digital platforms.
  5. The letters, imagery, graphics, and concept should be clear and purpose-driven.
  6. Emphasis should be placed on visibility, creativity, proportion, and innovation, ensuring compliance with international guidelines.
  7. The logo must not violate any provisions of the Copyright Act, 1957.
  8. A brief description of the colors, typography, and core concept of the logo must be submitted along with the design.
  9. Upon declaration of the winner, the selected logo’s ownership rights must be transferred to Pune Municipal Corporation by submitting a letter of agreement.
  10. Participants must submit a declaration stating that the logo design is their original creation, along with their full name, address, contact number, and email ID.
  11. Participants must be Indian citizens and must submit a copy of their Aadhaar card.
  12. Each participant is allowed to submit only one entry.
  13. Logo designs will be accepted online from 25/01/2025 to 10/02/2025 until 5:00 PM via the website. https://fxurl.co/LogoCompetition The logo designs will be opened on 11/02/2025 at 3:00 PM.
  14. The logo must be submitted in a non-edited PDF format.
  15. The logo design should be submitted only in A4 size format.
  16. After evaluating all entries, the Pune Municipal Corporation committee will announce the winner. The first prize winner will receive a cash award of ₹1,75,000/- (One Lakh Seventy-Five Thousand Only) along with a certificate.
  17. Pune Municipal Corporation reserves the right to accept, reject, or cancel any entry at its discretion.

Competition Date
Sat Jan 25 2025 - Mon Feb 10 2025

Registration date
Sat Jan 25 2025 - Mon Feb 10 2025

Terms and condition
Open for All

Website Link
https://fxurl.co/LogoCompetition

raw.title: Current Status
summary:
Previous Situation

It is evident that rivers have always been extremely important to the city of Pune. However, in the past few decades, the quality of river water had deteriorated, and the city had gradually started neglecting the river. During that time, the most critical issues related to the rivers were as follows:

  • Untreated sewage was being directly discharged into the rivers.
  • A large amount of garbage was being dumped into the rivers.
  • Construction debris was being thrown into the rivers.
  • The rivers were being encroached upon due to unplanned development.
  • The risk of flooding was increasing.
  • The rivers were not easily accessible to the citizens.
  • Instead of uniting the city, the rivers were dividing it.

Objectives

  • Clean the river and make it pollution-free
  • Reduce the risk of flooding
  • Make the riverbank easily and conveniently accessible to citizens
  • Efficiently retain and manage water storage
  • Improve the city's connectivity and integration with the riverfront
  • Enhance the environment by integrating existing heritage structures, recreational spaces, religious and socio-cultural activities

raw.title: Bharat Ratna Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Student Hostel
summary:
Information about Bharat Ratna Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Student Hostel

Objective:
The Bharat Ratna Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Student Hostel was established by the Pune Municipal Corporation to provide accommodation for students from outside Pune city so that they can pursue higher education in Pune.

Established: 1968
Capacity: 400 students

Admission Process:
The hostel primarily provides admission to students belonging to backward castes and tribes, as well as those whose parents' total annual income does not exceed ₹1 lakh. Eligible students must reside in rural areas outside Pune city and must be enrolled in full-time courses in engineering, medical, science and agriculture, arts, commerce, and other disciplines at colleges within the Pune Municipal Corporation limits.

For admissions, preference is given to students from engineering, medical, science, agriculture, arts, and commerce fields. The admission process is based on a merit list, which is prepared considering the marks obtained in the last qualifying examination. Priority is given to orphans, homeless students, and those who have lost their parents due to COVID-19, provided they submit the required certificates.

Students seeking admission must apply online between July and August at DBT Portal. Before this, advertisements are published in leading newspapers like Pudhari and Lokmat.

During the online admission process, students must upload scanned and attested copies of the following documents:

  1. Caste certificate
  2. Income certificate issued by the Tehsildar
  3. Required mark sheets
  4. Ration card
  5. School leaving certificate
  6. Original bonafide certificate from the admitted college with an official stamp
  7. Aadhaar card
  8. Xerox copy of bank passbook
  9. Fee receipt and security deposit challan for previously admitted students
  10. Three recent passport-sized photographs

Once selected, students must submit their online application along with attested copies of the required documents at Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Student Hostel, Ghole Road, Shivajinagar, Pune - 05 for verification.

After completing the online admission process, a merit list of selected students is published on the website and displayed on the hostel's notice board. The hostel admission process is then carried out for the selected students.

Students admitted to the hostel receive a monthly DBT (Direct Benefit Transfer) allowance of ₹2,150 from Pune Municipal Corporation for meal expenses, which is directly deposited into their bank accounts.

The rules, terms, and conditions for hostel admission can be viewed at DBT Portal.

DBT Portal

raw.title: Ambulance
summary:
Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) is committed to providing timely and efficient emergency medical services to citizens. A well-equipped ambulance network operates across the city, ensuring rapid response in critical situations. These ambulances cater to various medical needs, including basic life support (BLS), advanced life support (ALS), and neonatal care. PMC, in collaboration with empanelled private agencies, ensures 24/7 availability of ambulances to handle medical emergencies, accidents, and patient transfers.

Citizens can access ambulance services through the designated helpline numbers or directly contact the listed service providers. Each ambulance is staffed with trained paramedics and essential medical equipment to provide immediate care while en route to healthcare facilities. PMC continuously monitors and upgrades ambulance services to maintain high standards of emergency medical response, ensuring that every resident receives prompt medical assistance when needed.

raw.title: Vehicles for Solid Waste Management
summary:
Solid waste collection and transportation is carried out with the help of high end mechanical equipment, some examples are as follows :

Tipper / Dumper

Through the Motor Vehicle Department, a total of 57 vehicles are provided daily for solid waste collection and transportation. The carrying capacity of these vehicles ranges from 5 metric tons to 10 metric tons. These vehicles are used to collect hotel waste from the city and transport it to the waste processing plant.
Dumper Placer

The Motor Vehicle Department operates 56 dumper placer vehicles. These vehicles have a load-carrying capacity of up to 3 metric tons. They are used to lift and transport 3.8 cubic meter capacity garbage containers placed at various locations in the city to waste transfer centers.
Small Ghanta Gadi
The Motor Vehicle Department has approximately 351 small Ghanta Gadi vehicles owned by the Municipal Corporation. These vehicles have a load-carrying capacity ranging from 700 kg to 1.5 metric tons. They are used for waste collection in areas with narrow roads. The waste collected by these vehicles is then emptied into a compactor vehicle. For the first time, the Pune Municipal Corporation has purchased 10 EV vehicles on a trial basis for waste transportation.
Large Ghanta Gadi
The Motor Vehicle Department has approximately 78 vehicles owned by the Municipal Corporation. These vehicles have a load-carrying capacity of up to 3 metric tons. They are used for door-to-door waste collection in Pune city and for transporting waste to transfer centers or waste processing plants. These vehicles have four separate compartments for wet waste, dry waste, sanitary waste, and household hazardous waste.
Compactor
The Motor Vehicle Department has 53 compactor vehicles. These vehicles have a load-carrying capacity of up to 7 metric tons. They are used to collect solid waste gathered by small Ghanta Gadi vehicles and transport it to the waste processing plant.
BRC
The Motor Vehicle Department operates a total of 36 BRC-category vehicles owned by the Municipal Corporation. These vehicles have a load-carrying capacity ranging from 10 metric tons to 22 metric tons. They are classified under secondary transport. Solid waste collected by primary transport vehicles is emptied into BRC vehicles at waste transfer centers. This waste is then transported by these vehicles to waste processing plants or farmers' agricultural lands.
Walking Floor

The Motor Vehicle Department provides 9 walking floor vehicles daily for solid waste collection and transportation. 3 walking floor vehicles have a carrying capacity of 55 cubic meters. 6 walking floor vehicles have a carrying capacity of 25 cubic meters. These vehicles are used to transport wet and dry waste collected at various waste transfer centers of Pune Municipal Corporation to different waste processing projects.
Mini Jetting Machine

The Motor Vehicle Department owns a total of 46 mini jetting vehicles under municipal ownership. These vehicles have a water tank capacity ranging from 500 liters to 1000 liters. The vehicles are allocated to 15 regional offices of the Municipal Corporation based on their requirements and demand. These vehicles are used for cleaning municipal offices, public toilets within municipal limits and schools, as well as statues, footpaths, and other public spaces in the city.

raw.title: Pune City Page
summary:
About Pune City

Pune, with its rich historical and cultural heritage, has experienced the reign of the Rashtrakutas, Satavahanas, and Yadava dynasties. The foundation of the city's establishment was laid by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and Rajmata Jijabai. The Peshwas also made significant contributions to the development of Pune. After the downfall of the Peshwa Empire in 1818, the British took control of Pune and its surrounding areas. In 1858, after the establishment of the Municipal Corporation, urban infrastructure was developed in the city.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) was established in 1950 in the culturally and historically significant city of Pune. In the following years, particularly after the devastating Panshet flood of 1962, the corporation efficiently and diligently undertook the task of restoring normalcy.

In the subsequent years, PMC played a crucial role in the city's rapid development, ensuring essential services such as water supply, roads, electricity, primary healthcare, and education while preserving its historical heritage. To promote tourism and safeguard the city's rich legacy, the Heritage Management Department was established. This department has successfully undertaken and completed several significant projects and has compiled a comprehensive list of the city's historical sites.

Cultural Identity of Pune:
  • Tradition and History: Pune was a central hub of the Maratha Empire and experienced major growth under the rule of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and the Peshwas. Places such as Shaniwar Wada and Lal Mahal, which are historical landmarks, bear witness to the rich history of Pune. It was Lokmanya Tilak who started the Ganesh festival in Pune, and thus the city became a place for great celebration of Ganesh Chaturthi.
  • Education and Literature: Pune is the cradle of knowledge. It has renowned educational institutions like Savitribai Phule Pune University, Fergusson College, and JJ School of Arts. Several great writers, authors, and poets have resided in Pune. The literary culture of writers like P. L. Deshpande and V. S. Khandekar was developed in Pune.
  • Music and Arts: Pune is a hub for Indian classical music. The 'Savai Gandharva Music Festival' is organized annually, providing a unique experience for music enthusiasts. Pune is also renowned for fine arts, drama, and theatre. Places such as Bal Gandharva Rang Mandir and Yashwantrao Chavan Natyagriha organize numerous outstanding plays.
  • Contemporary Cultural Trends: Pune plays host to some events such as the Pune International Film Festival (PIFF) and literary festivals. With growth as an Information Technology hub, Pune has now become a city that harmoniously balances modernity and tradition.
Ganesh Festival in Pune
  • Pune is known as the cultural capital of Maharashtra, and the Ganesh Festival celebrated here is famous throughout the country.
  • The festival begins with the installation of Lord Ganesha on the Shuddha Chaturthi in the month of Bhadrapad, and the celebrations last for ten days with great enthusiasm. Pune's Manache 5 Ganpati are Kasba Ganpati, Tambdi Jogeshwari Ganpati, Guruji Talim Ganpati, Tulshibaug Ganpati, and Kesari Wada Ganpati.
  • The Ganesh Festival in Pune is not just a religious event but is also significant from a cultural, social, and artistic perspective. Various mandals organize elaborate decorations, social awareness programs, music, dance, and drama performances. During this time, the city of Pune is lit up with lights, and the entire atmosphere becomes devotional.
  • After ten days of celebrations, on Anant Chaturdashi, the immersion of Lord Ganesha is done with great pomp. The immersion procession in Pune is famous across the country. Devotees bid farewell to Lord Ganesha with the sound of drums and the tossing of gulal, with millions of devotees participating in the procession.
  • In modern times, there is an emphasis on celebrating an eco-friendly Ganesh Festival. Instead of idols made of Plaster of Paris, idols made from clay are preferred. Additionally, artificial ponds are created for the immersion of home Ganesh idols to prevent water pollution.
Palkhi Procession in Pune
  • Pune is considered the cultural capital of Maharashtra, and many religious and traditional festivals are celebrated with great enthusiasm here. One of the most important and devotional events is the Ashadhi Wari Palkhi Procession.
  • The tradition of the pilgrimage has been ongoing for centuries. After the Samadhi of Sant Dnyaneshwar Maharaj and Sant Tukaram Maharaj, their devotees began the practice of carrying their padukas (footwear) in a palanquin to Pandharpur. This tradition later transformed into an annual pilgrimage.
  • Every year, during the month of Ashadha, the palanquin of Sant Tukaram Maharaj departs from Dehu and the palanquin of Sant Dnyaneshwar Maharaj departs from Alandi. By the time they reach Pune, millions of pilgrims join the procession. A grand welcome ceremony is organized in Pune for the palanquins.
  • The pilgrimage and the palkhi procession carry a message of devotion, tolerance, unity, and social equality. People from all walks of life, regardless of their wealth, caste, or background, come together in this event. Chanting prayers to the beat of the 'tala' and 'mridang' (traditional musical instruments), the devotees joyfully complete the pilgrimage.
Pune Festival
  • The Pune Festival is celebrated with great enthusiasm every year in Pune, the cultural capital of Maharashtra. This festival is held during the Ganesh Chaturthi period and includes events such as music, dance, drama, art, sports, literature, and cultural programs.
  • The Pune Festival began in 1989. It is organized with the cooperation of the Maharashtra Tourism Department and local cultural institutions. The main objective of this festival is to promote Indian culture, art, and traditions. It provides an opportunity for artists from Pune and across the country to showcase their art.
  • Various types of events are organized during this festival. These include Bharatnatyam, Kathak, classical music, Marathi plays, art exhibitions, yoga workshops, sports competitions, and fashion shows, which are the major attractions. Additionally, for literature lovers, poetry readings and discussion sessions are also arranged.
  • During the Pune Festival, tourists from all over India, as well as from abroad, visit Pune in large numbers. This boosts the tourism industry and helps the local economy. This festival plays a significant role in preserving Pune's historical and cultural heritage.
Sawai Gandharv Festival
  • The Sawai Gandharv Festival is one of the most prestigious and renowned classical music festivals in India. Held annually in Pune, this festival is a treat for Hindustani classical music enthusiasts. It is organized in memory of the famous vocalist of the Kirana Gharana, Pandit Sawai Gandharv.
  • The Sawai Gandharv Festival was initiated in 1953 by Pandit Bhimsen Joshi. The purpose of this festival is to promote classical music and provide a platform for emerging artists to showcase their art. The festival is organized by the Arya Sangeet Prasarak Mandal in Pune.
  • This festival lasts for three to four days and features renowned classical vocalists, instrumentalists, and dancers from across India and abroad. Famous singers, tabla players, sitarists, violinists, and other musicians captivate the audience with their soulful performances. The program runs late into the night, with many prominent artists performing their art.
  • The Sawai Gandharv Festival is not just a music festival but an important heritage of Indian classical music. This festival provides young artists with guidance from senior gurus and helps create a new generation of classical musicians. As a result, Pune city is recognized as an important hub in the field of music.
Transportation in Pune
  • Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML): Operates a vast network of buses across the city with approximately 2000 buses.
  • Metro Rail: The Pune Metro is an ongoing project designed to enhance connectivity across the city with 2 operational lines as of now.
  • Auto-rickshaws: Widely available throughout the city.
  • Cab Services: Various app-based and traditional cab services are accessible.
  • Two-Wheelers: A common mode of personal transportation.
