raw.title: Heritage management department's operations
summary:
The Pune Municipal Corporation has made efforts to fulfill basic necessities such as public health, water supply, roads, electricity, and education while also preserving and promoting cultural heritage. By establishing the Heritage Cell, the Pune Municipal Corporation has taken a significant step forward. The Heritage Department is responsible for the conservation and preservation of historical monuments under the jurisdiction of the Pune Municipal Corporation. The department has conducted a survey of historical structures in Pune city by Intach institute and has categorized them into Heritage Grade I, II, and III lists.

  • Preserving and conserving historical monuments owned by Pune Municipal Corporation
  • In Pune city, there are 79 Grade I, 82 Grade II, and 88 Grade III heritage monuments, totaling 249 heritage monuments. Among these, the following monuments are owned by Pune Municipal Corporation:

1. Lal Mahal 
2. Nanawada 
3. Vishrambaugwada 
4. Mahatma Phule Mandai

  • Preserving and conserving private historical monuments-

The proposal for restoration and new construction of private historical monuments listed in Heritage Grade I, II, III is approved by the Heritage Committee. For this, the proposal is submitted through the Heritage Cell by a conservation architect to the Heritage Committee established by the government. The committee reviews this proposal and approves the appropriate proposal as per the rules.

  • Central Government Protected Monuments Rules-

According to the Ancient Monuments, Archaeological Sites, and Remains Act of 1958 and the Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Sites and Remains (AMASR) Amendment and Validation Act 2010

  • Every area that begins from the limit of the protected area or protected monument, extending up to a distance of 100 meters in all directions, shall be the - Prohibited Area Zone.
  • Every area that begins from the limit of the prohibited area in respect of national importance monuments and archaeological sites and remains, extending up to a distance of 200 meters in all directions, shall be the - Regulated Area Zone.

The following three monuments in Pune city fall under the jurisdiction of the Archaeological Survey of India:

2. Pataleshwar Caves 
3. Aga Khan Palace

The Maharashtra Ancient Monuments and Archaeological Sites and Remains Act of 1960, Section 17 - Preservation of the monument's surroundings.

raw.title: Blood Bank
summary:
The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) is committed to ensuring the availability of safe and sufficient blood supply for medical emergencies and patient care. Several government-approved blood banks operate within the PMC limits, providing essential blood and its components such as plasma, platelets, and red blood cells. These blood banks adhere to strict safety and quality standards to ensure that every unit of blood is properly tested and stored.

Citizens can access blood banks in case of medical emergencies, surgeries, or treatments requiring blood transfusion. Many blood banks also facilitate voluntary blood donation drives, encouraging community participation in maintaining an adequate blood supply. PMC urges citizens to contribute to this noble cause and stay informed about the nearest blood banks for timely assistance when needed.

raw.title: Drainage Vehicles
summary:
Suction Machine

The Motor Vehicle Department owns a total of three vehicles for drainage line cleaning, including 1 Suction cum Jetting with Recycler Vehicle 2 Sludge Vans These vehicles are operated under the Sewerage Department. The Suction cum Jetting Recycler Vehicle is used for cleaning drainage lines in the city. The Sludge Vans are used for cleaning septic tanks.
Jetting cum Suction with Recycler Machine

The Motor Vehicle Department owns one Jetting cum Suction with Recycler Machine with a capacity of 12,000 liters. This machine is used for Cleaning sludge from drainage chambers, Suctioning water from drainage chambers, Purifying the extracted water for reuse.
Jetting cum Suction Machine

Pune Municipal Corporation has Jetting cum Suction Machines with different capacities, such as 3,000 liters, 6,000 liters, and 8,000 liters. These machines are used for: Pressure cleaning of sludge in drainage chambers, Suctioning sludge and water from drainage chambers.
Grab Machine

The Grab Machine is used to clean drainage chambers without direct human contact with wastewater. Functions of the machine: Removal of heavy objects, sludge, and solid waste from drainage chambers, Efficient cleaning of multiple chambers in less time.
Champion Machine

The Champion Machine is designed to efficiently lift manhole covers and remove sludge, dirt, or obstructions from drainage chambers using a hook and wire mechanism. Key Features are Easily lifts heavy manhole covers, Extracts sludge, waste, and blockages from chambers and Highly useful in urban areas due to its compact size and quick operation.

raw.title: Roles and Responsibility
summary:
As of today, the population of Pune Municipal Corporation is approximately 55 to 60 lakh. With the continuous establishment of new information technology institutes, educational institutions, and industrial organizations in the city, its growth is accelerating rapidly. From an administrative perspective, the administration is divided into five divisional offices, under which there are a total of 15 ward offices.

On 30/06/2021, as per the orders of the Government of Maharashtra, 23 new villages were included in the jurisdiction of Pune Municipal Corporation. Due to this expansion, the amount of waste generation has increased, and currently, around 2,300 to 2,400 metric tons of solid waste is produced daily in Pune city. This waste is processed using scientific methods in various waste processing projects. The non-processable waste is disposed of scientifically in Pune Municipal Corporation's scientific landfill sites.

Penalty Actions by the Solid Waste Management Department

  • Public littering on roads/paths - Rs. 500/-
  • Pet waste pollution - Rs. 180/-
  • Defecating on roads - Rs. 500/-
  • Urinating in open areas - Rs. 200/-
  • Dumping waste in rivers, drains, lakes, and ghats - Rs. 200/-
  • Burning waste - Rs. 5000/-
  • Spitting in public places - Rs. 1000/-
  • Use and sale of plastic:
    • First offence - Rs. 5000/-
    • Second offence - Rs. 10,000/-
    • Third offence - Rs. 25,000/- and 3 months imprisonment
  • Dumping debris:
    • Rs. 5000/- to Rs. 25,000/- (Rs. 25,000/- for water sources)
  • BWG penalty actions:
    • First offence - Rs. 5000/-
    • Second offence - Rs. 10,000/-
    • Third offence - Rs. 15,000/-
    • Third offence onwards - Rs. 15,000/- for each offence
  • Failure to segregate waste:
    • First offence - Rs. 60/-
    • Second offence - Rs. 120/-
    • Third offence - Rs. 180/-

raw.title: Fire Safety Audit: Laws and Regulations
summary:
Maharashtra Fire Prevention and Life Safety Measures Act, 2006

The government of Maharashtra has provided some provisions in the Maharashtra Fire Prevention and Life Safety Measures Act, 2006. These regulations are bound to be followed by the fire department. The following are some of the main points in the Act:

Key Provisions:
  • Appointment and Qualifications of Designated Officers: The Act provides for the procedure of appointing eligible officers for imposing fire safety measures.
  • Licensing of Agencies: Fire safety services agencies need to be licensed.
  • Memorandum and Panchnama of Seizure, etc.: Procedures for seizing and the actions to be followed are laid down in the Act.
  • Notice for Entry and Inspection: Procedure for issuing notices prior to entry and inspection of premises is specified.
  • Procedure for Closing a Place, Building, or Part Thereof: The Act provides for the procedure to be adopted during closing down of dangerous buildings.
  • License Renewal: Regulations for fire safety license renewals are outlined.
  • Notice of Hearing and Guidelines: Guidelines on conducting hearings and guidelines are given.
  • Report of Details of Loss During Firefighting Operations: Reporting of losses during firefighting operations is compulsory under the Act.
  • Report of Injuries to Fire Officers/Employees During Accidents: Reporting procedures on injuries to fire officers/employees during accidents are required.
  • Rate of Water Utilized for Firefighting: The Act prescribes rules for water rates utilized in fire fighting.
  • These and numerous other such significant issues are addressed by the regulations in this legislation. The fire officers are supposed to have thorough knowledge of these provisions.
Fire Safety Audit:

A fire safety audit is an important feature of this Act. It is intended to avoid loss of life in buildings. The Act categorizes buildings and prescribes the fire safety equipment and systems required for each category.

Apart from the buildings listed in the table, the Act also lays down rules for industrial buildings, star hotels, hospitals, warehouses, and hazardous buildings. The audit is performed by specialists, who write up a report. The report may suggest corrections, repairs, or demolition of unapproved buildings. Compliance is obligatory. Breach can cause penalties in form of fines, imprisonment, or both.

Role of Fire Audits

Fire audits are conducted for public safety. It is the duty of every citizen to strictly follow the rules. Instead of focusing on avoiding penalties, citizens should prioritize implementing safety measures to protect everyone's lives.

In summary:

This act is designed to create and regulate fire safety within the state of Maharashtra, and to keep the citizens safe from harm.

raw.title: Pre-Conception and Pre-Natal Diagnostic Techniques
summary:
Health Department

PCPNDT Section And Action Committee

The Pre-Conception and pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection Act) 1994 Amendment Act, 2003

An Act to provide for the prohibition of sex selection, before or after conception, and for regulation of pre-natal diagnostic techniques for the purposes of detecting genetic abnormalities or metabolic disorders or chromosomal abnormalities or certain congenital malformations or sex linked disorders and for prevention of their misuse for sex determination leading to female foeticide and for matters connected therewith or incidental there to.

  1. Prohibition of the misuse of Pre-natal diagnostics techniques for determination of sex of foetus, leading to female foeticide,
  2. Prohibition of advertisement of pre- natal diagnostic techniques for detection or determination of sex.
  3. Permission and regulation of the use of pre-natal diagnostic techniques for the purpose of detection of specific genetic abnormalities or disorders.
  4. Permitting the use of such techniques only under certain conditions by the registered institutions.

Punishment for violation of the provision of the proposed legislation.

  1. Act seeks to prohibit pre-natal diagnostic techniques for determination of sex of the foetus leading to female feticides
  2. The pre-natal diagnostic techniques like amniocentesis and sonography are useful for detection of genetic or chromosomal disorders or certain congenital malformations or sex linked disorders etc, however the amniocentesis and sonography are being on a large scale to detect the sex of the foetus and to terminate the pregnancy of the unborn child if found to be female.
  3. The proliferation of the technologies mentioned above may, in further, precipitate a catastrophe in the form of severe imbalance in male female ratio.

Accordingly, it is proposed to amend the aforesaid Act either a view to banning the use of both sex selection techniques prior to conception as well as the misuse of pre-natal diagnostic techniques for sex selection abortions and to regulate such techniques with a view to ensure their scientific use for which they are intended.

The Pre-Conception and pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection Act) 1994 Amendment Act, 2003 and updated in Section 17 has been formed under the Advisory Committee Pune Municipal Corporation. The Hon. Advisory Committee meetings are held on a regular basis. Hon. The Advisory Committee discusses the registration and renewal of sonography centers. and various letters received from State Government. Advisory Committee shall consist of, three medical experts from amongst gynecologists, obstetricians, pediatricians and medical geneticists, one Legal expert, one officer to represent the department dealing with information and publicity, three eminent social workers.

Vigilance Committee, of The Pre-Conception and pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection Act) 1994 Amendment Act, 2003 consist of following members Hon. Municipal Commissioner is the Chairman, Assistant medical officer and Appropriate Authority, PCPNDT Act is Member Secretary, Chairman of the Advisory Committee, PCPNDT Act, PMC, Chief legal officer, Chief Accountant officer, PMC, The police commissioner (Pune City)Chief Education officer, President / representative of the Indian Medical Association (Pune Branch) and Pune Municipal Corporation medical officer(PCPNDT Cell), Information and public relations officer and Zonal medical officer is a member of the committee.

Steps taken to enforce PCPNDT Act

  • All sonography centres are registered in Pune Municipal Corporation. Total no. of registered sonography centres are 808 (Active 451).
  • All these centres are examined & inspected by respective Medical officer of PCPNDT Cell And Food Inspector in every quarter of the year.
  • Till now 63 court cases have been lodged against the sonography centres.for violation of act since year 2002.
  • Toll Free Helpline 1800-233-6099 for complaint of PCPNDT Act Violation.
  • Constitution of Special Cell :- A Special Cell is constituted under supervision of the Commissioner of Municipal Corporation, for effective implementation of PCPNDT Act.
  • Registration of PCPNDT Centre.
  • Registration of PCPNDT Centre done under section 3 and rule No. 4 of PCPNDT Act. There are basically 4 categories.

            1. Genetic Counseling Centre.

            2. Genetic Laboratory

            3. Genetic clinic

             4. Ultrasound clinic or Imaging Centre.

  • Fees for each one of above is Rs. 25,000/-
  • For providing joint services of above the fees are Rs. 35,000/-
  • Form “A” for application of registration to be submitted in duplicate.
  • Form is to be submitted in duplicate along with prescribed for of Rs. 25,000/- or Rs. 35,000/-

Papers to be submitted with Form “A” are

  1. Application (A Form-2 Copies)(Should be filled in Capital Letters)
  2. Commercial Property Tax Invoice of Assessment year with paid Receipt.
  3. Sanctioned plan of Place(showing measurement & Location of clinic- (3 Copies Blue Print) Completion / occupation certificate from PMC building permission dept.
  4. If Society/Trust, Registration Certificate from Competent Authority .
  5. Quotation of Machine/Performa/Invoice from authorized dealer/ Manufacture.
  6. Affidavit/ undertaking as per rules 4 (i) i & ii Shall not conduct any test or procedure for selection of sex before or after conception or for detection of sex of foetus nor shall sex of foetus be disclosed except for the diseases specified in section 4 Notarized Affidavit containing undertaking on Rs100 stamp paper.
    A) From owner/Applicant
    B) From each and every person Operating USG Machine.

raw.title: Tuberculosis Department
summary:
National Tuberculosis Eradication Program, Pune Municipal Corporation

Integrated Health & Family Welfare Society – TB

Tuberculosis Department

  • Since 1998, the National Tuberculosis Eradication Program (NTEP) has been implemented under the guidelines of the Central and State Governments in Pune Municipal Corporation. The Government of India has set the target of eradicating tuberculosis from India by 2025. The global goal is to eliminate tuberculosis by 2035.
  • Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease. The main tasks are to conduct thorough investigations of suspected patients, diagnose TB, and ensure complete recovery of the TB patient by following up with regular treatment over a long period.
  • The following free services are provided to TB patients through Pune Municipal Corporation:
  1. Sputum examination for suspected TB patients.
  2. CBNAAT / TrueNat / X-Ray tests for suspected TB patients.
  3. TB medicines are provided in all Pune Municipal Corporation hospitals and clinics.
  4. Under the Prime Minister's TB Free India campaign, nutritional food is provided to underprivileged TB patients through Nikshay Mitras.
  5. Under the Nikshay Poshan Yojana, tuberculosis patients receive a first benefit of ₹3,000 at the time of diagnosis and a second benefit of ₹3,000 after completing 84 days of treatment. These benefits are provided through Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) by the Central Government.

 

  • A benefit of ₹500 is provided to individuals who inform about new TB cases under TB Notification.
  • For DSTB (Drug-Sensitive TB) patients, a benefit of ₹1000 is provided to those assisting in treatment completion, and for DRTB (Drug-Resistant TB) patients, ₹5000 is provided for treatment assistance.
  • Under the Prime Minister's TB Free India campaign, the central government has involved entrepreneurs, private professionals, and NGOs through the Nikshay Mitra scheme to provide nutritional support, including food, eggs, and protein powder for TB patients. A total of 66 Nikshay Mitras have been registered in Pune Municipal Corporation, and they have distributed 7750 food baskets to 3032 TB patients.
  • TB Notification is being carried out with the involvement of all private medical institutions within the Pune Municipal Corporation area.
  • By the end of 2024, a total of 3201 TB notifications under the government sector and 4780 under the private sector have been registered, achieving 100% of the target.
  • In 2023, out of 6581 DSTB patients undergoing treatment, 6360 (93%) were cured, and the death rate was 2.24% (165 patients).
  • By the end of 2024, out of 8555 TB patients undergoing treatment, 5214 patients have received ₹2,01,93,000 through the Nikshay Poshan Yojana via DBT.
  • In October 2023, during the active TB case finding campaign, 4079 suspected TB patients were examined from a population of 4,56,543. Among them, 141 were diagnosed with TB and started treatment immediately.
  • In November 2023, during both the direct leprosy and active TB case finding campaigns, 3032 suspected TB patients were examined from a population of 4,65,452, and 142 TB and 28 leprosy patients were diagnosed and started on treatment immediately.
  • In December 2024, 5531 suspected TB patients were examined from a population of 5,10,226, and 171 TB patients were diagnosed and started treatment immediately.

Integrated Health & Family Welfare Society – PMC

Pune Municipal Corporation

Sr. No. Name Position
1 Hon. Additional Municipal Commissioner (J), Pune Municipal Corporation Chairman
2 Medical Officer of Health (MOH), Pune Municipal Corporation Member Secretary
3 Director – Sassoon General Hospital, Pune Member
4 Deputy Health Officer (DY MOH) Member
5 Assistant Health Officer (National Program), Nodal Officer (RCH), Pune Municipal Corporation Joint Secretary
6 City Tuberculosis Officer, Pune Municipal Corporation Joint Secretary

 

National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme, Pune Municipal Corporation

Integrated Health & Family Welfare Society – TB

Tuberculosis Department

Since 1998, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) has been implemented in Pune Municipal Corporation in accordance with the guidelines of the Central and State Governments. The Government of India aims to eliminate tuberculosis from the country by 2025, with a global target of eradicating tuberculosis by 2035.

Tuberculosis (TB) is a contagious disease. The primary objective is to conduct thorough investigations of suspected patients, diagnose TB, and ensure complete recovery by providing long-term, consistent treatment.

Free Services Provided to TB Patients through Pune Municipal Corporation:

  1. Sputum examination for suspected TB patients.
  2. CBNAAT / TrueNat / X-Ray tests for suspected TB patients.
  3. TB medicines provided at all Pune Municipal Corporation hospitals and clinics.
  4. Under the Prime Minister’s TB-Free India Campaign, nutritious food is distributed to underprivileged TB patients through Nikshay Mitras.
  5. Under the Nikshay Poshan Yojana, ₹1000 per month is provided via Direct Benefit Transfer (DBT) to TB patients until they complete their treatment.
  6. A ₹500 incentive is given to individuals reporting new TB cases under TB Notification.
  7. ₹1000 is provided to those assisting DSTB (Drug-Sensitive TB) patients with treatment completion, and ₹5000 for those assisting DRTB (Drug-Resistant TB) patients.
  8. Under the Prime Minister’s TB-Free India Campaign, with the involvement of entrepreneurs, private professionals, and NGOs through the Nikshay Mitra scheme, nutritional support including food, eggs, and protein powder is provided to TB patients. As of now, 66 Nikshay Mitras have distributed 7750 food baskets to 3032 TB patients in Pune.

TB notification is actively carried out with the participation of all private healthcare institutions in Pune Municipal Corporation.

raw.title: Veterinary Department
summary:
The Veterinary Section of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) is committed to ensuring animal health and public safety through a range of services and initiatives. Led by the Chief Veterinary Officer under the guidance of the Medical Officer of Health, the section undertakes various critical activities, including the operation of the slaughterhouse, animal birth control programs, management of municipal markets, and more.

Key Activities

1. Operation & Maintenance of Slaughterhouse

  • - Established in 1948 at Salunke Vihar Road, Kondhwa, the slaughterhouse is equipped with modern mechanical facilities and an effluent treatment plant.
  • - Certified by FSSAI, HACCP, and HALAL, it operates under the consent of the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board.
  • - Fees: Rs. 15/- per small animal, Rs. 80 per large animal, plus a pre-slaughter inspection fee of Rs. 200/-.
  • - Managed by a team of veterinary officers, engineers, technicians, and permanent employees.

2. Quality Control Laboratory at Kondhwa

  • - Quality Control Laboratory funded by the Government of India, leased to a private agency for 10 years with annual rent increases.
  • - Ensures the safety and quality of food and water samples.

3. Municipal Meat & Fish & Beef Markets

  • - Management of 14 mutton markets, 5 fish markets, and 1 beef market, ensuring compliance with health standards.
  • - Fees: Rs. 400/-month for mutton and fish markets, Rs. 600/month for beef markets, with an annual license fee of Rs. 300/-

4. Health Licenses for Private Butcher Shops

  • - Annual fees: Rs. 1000 for mutton, beef, chicken, and pork; Rs. 500 for fish.
  • - Active enforcement against unlicensed sellers to ensure public health and safety.

5. Disposal of Dead Animals

  • - 24/7 service for the collection and environmentally safe disposal of dead animals.
  • - Managed by SH. Pawar Transport, with cremation facilities located at Naidu Pond and Mundhwa Keshavnagar. (Contact - 7020364459, 9022094073)

6. Dog & Cat ABC (Animal Birth Control) Program

  • - Sterilization and vaccination efforts to control stray animal populations, reducing the birth rate of stray dogs by 42.87% since 2018.
  • - Collaboration with NGOs such as CCC and Universal Animal Welfare Association for effective program implementation. (Contact - Vijay Ovhal 98901 46832, Universal Animal Welfare Association - 8655455100).

According to the guidelines of the World Health Organization, sterilization is the only scientific method to reduce the number of stray dogs in developing countries. Killing the dogs or relocating them is not a solution. Dogs are social animals. If some dogs are relocated from one area, other dogs will move into that area. It is not feasible to vaccinate or sterilize newly arriving dogs each time. Therefore, to achieve long-term results, sterilizing all dogs is the appropriate solution.

The Dog Squad of Pune Municipal Corporation will catch all such stray dogs and perform sterilization surgery on them. They will also be vaccinated with anti-rabies shots and will be released back to the place where they were captured within five days. The right ear of the dog will be notched to indicate that it has been sterilized. According to the law, dogs must be returned to the location from which they were picked up.

As per certain provisions of the Animal Birth Control Act 2023, the following actions are legal offenses:

  • - Removing lactating female dogs and their puppies.
  • - Removing puppies younger than six months.
  • - Removing sterilized dogs again.
  • - Transferring dogs from one place to another.
  • - Relocating these dogs outside the city limits.

How can you help?

  • - Assist the municipal corporation in identifying stray dogs in your area so they can be sterilized.
  • - Do not insist that PMC employees relocate these dogs from your area.
  • - Avoid throwing garbage on the streets as an increase in waste leads to a higher breeding rate among dogs.
  • - Educate others about the importance of dog sterilization.
  • - Each society should adopt at least one stray dog, taking responsibility for its feeding, sterilization, and vaccination. These dogs will protect your society and deter other dogs from entering.

7.Stray Pig Control

  • - Appointed for the management and capture of stray pigs to prevent property damage and public nuisance. (Contact – farmer’s Choice 9854444111).

8. Shifting of Cattle Sheds

  • - Relocation of cattle sheds to Mundhwa Keshavnagar to improve animal management and welfare.

9. Online Pet Registration

  • - Launched to facilitate easy documentation and licensing for pet owners.
  • - Available for dog and cat owners within PMC limits, streamlining the process of obtaining new licenses.

     Click here for Online Pet Registration: https://services.pmc.gov.in/

The Veterinary Section of the Pune Municipal Corporation continues to enhance its services, ensuring the welfare of animals and the health and safety of the community. For more information or to access our services, visit the PMC website at

Contact Us

Health Department Veterinary Section,
3rd Floor ,Shivaginagar Pune.
Ph. No. 02025501226, 02025501237.

Please contact PMC Care for the same.

Toll Free No: 1800 1030 222 WhatsApp / SMS: 9689900002

raw.title: Vector Borne Disease Control
summary:
Vector Borne Disease Control Department - 

Insect Control Department -

  1. Insect Section
  2. Malaria Section
  3. On Payment Section

​Services provided by the Insect Section - 

  1. House to house visit for eradication of mosquito breeding places.
  2. Weekly larvicide program and fogging in and around dengue positive cases.
  3. Removal of water hyacinth from Mula and Mutha river.
  4. Channelization of nallas.
  5. Fulfillments of complaints about mosquitoes.

Services provided by the Malaria Section -

  1. Door to door visits for blood smear collection of fever cases and get examined in corporation lab.
  2. Radical treatment of malaria patients.
  3. Collection of information from all hospitals, labs, private practitioners, municipal labs and hospitals daily.

Services provided by the On-Paymentsection -

In accordance to the resolution passed by the standing committee no 489/date 10/07/2012, Rs. 250/-  is charged for 10”X 10”sq ft i.e. 100 sq.ft room for fogging requested received from citizens about bed bug and cockroach infestation. Complaints from public about rats are also solved by putting cages.

Measures taken regarding removal of water hyacinth by Insect Control Department, Pune Municipal Corporation.

  1. Water hyacinth is removed from the river beds by labours on every Saturday and help of machinery like Spider-Man and JCB is also taken.
  2. Spraying of insecticides is done to lessen the mosquito breeding in ponds and pits near the beds of river.
  3. Labours work for deweeding as well as spraying of insecticides nearby  the river beds.

List of awareness initiatives carried out - 

  1. Pamphlets
  2. Stickers and banners
  3. Messages
  4. Radio jingles
  5. Booklets
  6. Teachers and students meeting
  7. Stickers about VBD on PMPL buses
  8. Society chairman’s meetings
  9. Audio, video.
  10. NGO women’s health groups, self-help groups
  11. Rallies and public meetings
  12. IMA and other private practitioners’ meetings.

raw.title: PMC Open Data
summary:
Open Data initiative:

Asset and value potentials of data are widely recognized at all levels. Data collected or developed through public investments, when made publicly available and maintained over time, their potential value could be more fully realized. There has been an increasing demand by the community, that such updated data collected with the deployment of public funds should be made more readily available to all, for enabling rational debate, increase transparency better decision making and use in meeting civil society and government needs.

Efficient sharing of data among data owners and inter-and-intra governmental agencies along with data standards and interoperable systems is the need of the hour. Hence, there was a need to formulate a policy on National Data Sharing and Accessibility which could provide an enabling provision and platform for proactive and open access to the data generated through public funds available with various ministries/departments/organizations of Government of India. In purview of the same, Pune Municipal Corporation has decided to endorse the National Data Sharing and Accessibility Policy and developed the Open data portal.

 “A dataset is said to be open if anyone is free to use, reuse, and redistribute it – Open Data shall be machine readable and it should also be easily accessible.”

PMC collects processes and generates a large amount of data in its day-to-day functioning. But a large quantum of government data remains inaccessible to citizens, civil society, although most of such data may be non-sensitive in nature and could be used by public for social, economic and developmental purposes.

These data need to be made available in an open format to facilitate use, reuse and redistribute; it should be free from any license or any other mechanism of control. Opening up of government data in open formats would enhance transparency and accountability while encouraging public engagement. The government data in open formats has a huge potential for innovation building various types of Apps, mash-ups and services around the published datasets.

 

Pune DataStore has been set up at http://opendata.punecorporation.org/ to provide collated access to Resources (datasets/apps) under Departments published in open format. It also provides a search & discovery mechanism for instant access to desired datasets. Pune DataStore also has a rich mechanism for citizen engagement. Besides enabling citizens to express their need for specific resource (datasets or apps) or API, it also allows them to rate the quality of datasets, seek clarification or information from respective data controller.

Pune DataStore Platform has a strong backend data management system which can be used by PMC departments to publish their datasets through a predefined workflow. They shall also have a dashboard to see the current status on their datasets, usage analytics as well as feedback and queries from citizens at one point. In future, the departments will also have an option to create visualization of their data.

Pune DataStore Platform will also feature a Communities component which facilitates forming of communities around datasets, domain of interest such as sanitation, education, health, or it could be app developers’ community or even of data journalists. This shall give first hand input to development community for building new components, apps. It shall also give input to departments as what kind of datasets is more useful and accordingly prioritize the release of the datasets. The key features are detailed as below:

  1. Open Source Driven: Developed completely using Open Source Stack, facilitating cost saving in terms of software and licenses and also provisioning community participation in terms of further development of product with modules of data visualization, consumption, APIs to access datasets etc.
  2. Metadata – Resources (Datasets/Apps) shall be published along with standard metadata along with controlled vocabularies on government sectors, jurisdictions, dataset types, access mode etc. Besides facilitating easy access to datasets, this shall be extremely useful in the future for federation/integration of data catalogs.
  3. Social Media Connect–To support wider reach and dissemination of datasets, anyone can share the information about any dataset published on the platform with his/her social media pages on a press of a click.
  4. Citizen Engagement – The Platform has also a strong component of Citizen Engagement. Citizens can express their views as well as embed the Resources (Datasets/Apps) in their blogs or web sites. Facility to contact the data administrator is also available on the Platform. Additionally the citizens can ask/ suggest for the required data set by clicking on ‘Suggest a Data Set’

Please visit http://opendata.punecorporation.org/ for accessing the open data portal of Pune Municipal Corporation.

Kindly share your views, feedbacks and dataset suggestions on info@punecorporation.org.

Open Data Policy & implementation Guidelines

Open Data Strategy:

1.Introduction

Asset and value potentials of data are widely recognized at all levels. Data collected or developed through public investments, when made publicly available and maintained over time, their potential value could be more fully realized. There has been an increasing demand by the community, that such updated data collected with the deployment of public funds should be made more readily available to all, for enabling rational debate, increase transparency better decision making and use in meeting civil society and government needs.

Efficient sharing of data among data owners and inter-and-intra governmental agencies along with data standards and interoperable systems is the need of the hour. Hence, there was a need to formulate a policy on National Data Sharing and Accessibility which could provide an enabling provision and platform for proactive and open access to the data generated through public funds available with various ministries/departments/organizations of Government of India. In purview of the same, Pune Municipal Corporation (hereafter, PMC) has decided to endorse the National Data Sharing and Accessibility Policy and developed the Open data portal.

2.PMC Endorsing the National Data Sharing and Accessibility Policy (NDSAP)

NDSAP overview: The National Data Sharing and Accessibility Policy (NDSAP) is designed so as to apply to all sharable non-sensitive data available either in digital or analog forms but generated using public funds by various Ministries/Departments /Subordinate offices/Organizations/ Agencies of Government of India as well as States. The NDSAP policy is designed to promote data sharing and enable access to Government of India owned data for national planning, development and awareness.

NDSAP aims to provide an enabling provision and platform for proactive and open access to the data generated by various Government of India entities. The objective of this policy is to facilitate access to Government of India owned shareable data (along with its usage information) in machine readable form through a wide area network all over the country in a periodically updatable manner, within the framework of various related policies, acts and rules of Government of India, thereby permitting a wider accessibility and usage by public.

Different types of data sets generated both in geospatial and non-spatial form by different ministries/departments are supposed to be classified as shareable data and non-shareable data. Data management encompasses the systems and processes that ensure data integrity, data storage and security, including metadata, data security and access registers. The principles on which data sharing and accessibility need to be based include: Openness, Flexibility, Transparency, Quality, Security and Machine-readable.

NDSAP once implemented would lead to:

  • Opening up of the information out of the Government System
  • Making available of the Accurate, Reliable and Unbiased information
  • Providing single data OGD Platform for the country for data sharing
  • Establishment of a platform to promote innovation in government applications
  • Enhancing government Transparency, Accountability and Public Engagement
  • Effective utilization of Government data by providing meaningful visual representations
  • Enabling development of Innovative Applications around datasets or mash-up from multiple datasets hence giving different perspectives to government data

3.Open Government Data

“A dataset is said to be open if anyone is free to use, reuse, and redistribute it – Open Data shall be machine readable and it should also be easily accessible.”

  • PMC collects processes and generates a large amount of data in its day-to-day functioning. But a large quantum of government data remains inaccessible to citizens, civil society, although most of such data may be non-sensitive in nature and could be used by public for social, economic and developmental purposes.

These data need to be made available in an open format to facilitate use, reuse and redistribute; it should be free from any license or any other mechanism of control. Opening up of government data in open formats would enhance transparency and accountability while encouraging public engagement. The government data in open formats has a huge potential for innovation building various types of Apps, mash-ups and services around the published datasets.

4. Identification of Resources (Datasets/Apps) and their organization under Catalogs

As per policy each department has to prepare it‘s Negative List. The datasets which are confidential in nature and are in the interest of the country‘s security in not opening to the public would fall into the negative list.

All other datasets which do not fall under this negative list would be in the Open List. These datasets would need to be prioritized into high value datasets and non-high value datasets. The data sets then must be published on the portal in 3 (three) months.

The data which are contributed to the Pune DataStore portal have to be in the specified open data format only. The data have to be internally processed to ensure that the quality standard is met i.e. accuracy, free from any sort of legal issues, privacy of an individual is maintained and does not compromise with the National security.

While prioritizing the release of datasets, one should try to publish as many high value datasets. Grouping of Related Resources (Datasets/Apps) should be planned and are to be organized under departments.

Though each department shall have its own criterion of high value and low value datasets, generally High value data is governed by following Principles:

  • Completeness
  • Primary
  • Timeliness
  • Ease of Physical and Electronic Access
  • Machine Readability
  • Non-discrimination
  • Licensing
  • Permanence

4.1 Data Formats

NDSAP recommends that data has to be published in open format. It should be machine readable. Though there are many formats suitable to different category of data. Based on current analysis of data formats prevalent in Government it is proposed that data should be published in any of the following formats:

  • CSV (Comma separated Values)
  • XLS (spread sheet- Excel)
  • ODS (Open Document Formats for Spreadsheet)
  • XML (Extensive Markup Language)
  • KML (Keyhole Markup Language used for Maps)
  • GML (Geography Markup Language)

5.Open Data Platform for pune (pune DataStore)

Pune DataStore has been set up at http://opendata.punecorporation.org to provide collated access to Resources (datasets/apps) under Departments published in open format. It also provides a search & discovery mechanism for instant access to desired datasets. Pune DataStore also has a rich mechanism for citizen engagement. Besides enabling citizens to express their need for specific resource (datasets or apps) or API, it also allows them to rate the quality of datasets, seek clarification or information from respective data controller.

Pune DataStore Platform has a strong backend data management system which can be used by PMC departments to publish their datasets through a predefined workflow. They shall also have a dashboard to see the current status on their datasets, usage analytics as well as feedback and queries from citizens at one point. In future, the departments will also have an option to create visualization of their data.

Pune DataStore Platform will also feature a Communities component which facilitates forming of communities around datasets, domain of interest such as sanitation, education, health, or it could be app developers’ community or even of data journalists. This shall give first hand input to development community for building new components, apps. It shall also give input to departments as what kind of datasets is more useful and accordingly prioritize the release of the datasets. The key features are detailed as below:

  • Open Source Driven: Developed completely using Open Source Stack, facilitating cost saving in terms of software and licenses and also provisioning community participation in terms of further development of product with modules of data visualization, consumption, APIs to access datasets etc.
  • Metadata – Resources (Datasets/Apps) shall be published along with standard metadata along with controlled vocabularies on government sectors, jurisdictions, dataset types, access mode etc. Besides facilitating easy access to datasets, this shall be extremely useful in the future for federation/integration of data catalogs.
  • Social Media Connect–To support wider reach and dissemination of datasets, anyone can share the information about any dataset published on the platform with his/her social media pages on a press of a click.
  • Citizen Engagement – The Platform has also a strong component of Citizen Engagement. Citizens can express their views as well as embed the Resources (Datasets/Apps) in their blogs or web sites. Facility to contact the data administrator is also available on the Platform. Additionally the citizens can ask/ suggest for the required data set by clicking on ‘Suggest a Data Set’

6.NDSAP Implementation in Ministries/Departments/States

 

In order to implement open data, PMC need to undertake the following activities:

  • Nominate Chief Data Officer
  • Nominate Data Contributors
  • Identify Datasets
  • Publish Resources (Datasets/Apps) on Pune DataStore portal
  • Prepare Negative List
  • Create Action Plan for regular release of datasets on the OGD Platform India
  • Monitor and Manage the Open Data Programme of the Department

7.Publishing & Management of Resources (Datasets/Apps)

Contribution of datasets/apps is by login into a simple web based Dataset Management System. Resources to be contributed under Departments are processed through a predefined workflow, ensuring compliance with government policies. Data Contributors nominated by PMC or department are authorized to publish datasets in open format on Pune DataStore Platform.

Once the Contributor is created by the Chief Data Officer, a mail is sent to the mail id of the contributor. The Contributor then can login and contribute datasets along with its metadata for further approval by the Controller. However, the responsibility on the relevancy and quality of datasets published on the portal rests with Chief Data Officer.

7.1  View & Respond to Queries on Published Datasets

Citizens can browse, search, filter, sort and access the datasets on the OGD Platform. Citizens also have the option to send their queries and feedbacks about the published datasets. This feedback would be available on the dashboard of the Chief Data officer to take further necessary action.

7.2 Respond to Suggestions for new Datasets

The portal has a strong Citizen Engagement feature built in. While browsing through the catalogue of datasets, if one is not able to find the dataset which is of interest to him then he can request for the same through suggestions module. Suggestions already made for particular datasets are displayed and one can also endorse the same. The suggested list i.e. the requirement for new datasets is sent to the respective department‘s data contributor. This would facilitate the data contributor to prioritize his release of datasets on the platform. They are expected to send in their response on the same.

7.3 Review Analytics & Plan

The Dashboard would be available for the datasets contributed by all the contributors of that Department. Feedback related to datasets would also be available along with the suggestions from citizen with respect to the requirement of new datasets. This feature would facilitate him to watch the analytics and accordingly plan his course of action.

7.3.1 DOs for Data Contribution and Approval

  • Identify and prioritize the release of datasets; categorize the type of access granted for them and publish as many high value datasets as possible.
  • Contribute datasets which are in the Open List and do not fall under the Negative List.
  • Ensure that the quality standards are met i.e. accuracy, free from any sort of legal issues, privacy of an individual is maintained and does not compromise with the National security.
  • Ensure that the datasets being published through a workflow process are in compliance with the policy. Details on original source of the dataset and methodology of the data collection should be provided in metadata.
  • Prepare and contribute the metadata in predefined format for the Catalogs and Resources (Datasets/Apps). The key metadata elements are Title, Description, category, Sector/Sub-Sector, Dataset Jurisdiction, Keywords, Access Method, Reference URLs, Data Group Name, Frequency, Granularity of Data and Policy Compliance. All the metadata elements must be filled with utmost quality and ease of use.
  • Pricing of data, if any, would be decided by the data owners as per the government policies.
  • Ensure that data being contributed to the OGD Platform are in machine readable or in specified open data format only. The advisable formats are:
    • CSV (Comma separated Values)
    • XLS (spread sheet- Excel)
    • ODS (Open Document Formats for Spreadsheets)
    • XML (Extensive Markup Language)
    • KML (Keyhole Markup Language used for Maps)
    • GML (Geography Markup Language)
  • Ensure that the data being uploaded on the portal is as complete as possible, reflecting the entirety of what is recorded about a particular subject and is de-normalized. The datasets also should be optimized by adding redundant data or by grouping data before uploading.
  • Priority should be given to data whose utility is time sensitive. Real time information updates would maximize the utility the public can obtain from this information.
  • Replace any Not Available, Not Reported or missing values in the data with ‘NA’.
  • Metadata that defines and explains the raw data should be included as well, along with formulas and explanations for how derived data was calculated.
  • Keywords must be defined in data catalog to make it search friendly.
  • Provide link to the reference documents (if any) or website for detailed information and explanation on the method of calculation or source of data.
  • Prioritize the release of datasets and take relevant action on the basis of feedbacks and suggestions received on the portal m from citizen‘s pertaining to the Department.

       7.3.4 DON’Ts for Data Contribution and Approval

  • Don‘t contribute datasets which fall under the negative List e.g. the datasets which are confidential in nature and are in the interest of the country’s security.
  • Don‘t impose ‘Terms of Service’, attribution requirements, restrictions on dissemination and so on, which act as barriers to public use of data.
  • Don‘t impose cost on the public for access of datasets, as imposing fees for access skews the pool of who is willing (or able) to access information.
  • Don‘t publish hand written note, as it is very difficult for machines to process. Scanning text via Optical Character Recognition (OCR) results in many matching and formatting errors. Information shared in the widely used PDF format is very difficult for machines to parse. Hence, the data in these formats should be avoided.
  • Data in non-Unicode formats should be avoided.
  • Don‘t contribute datasets with any special characters (e.g. @, %, $, &, etc.) or missing values.
  • Don‘t provide any explanation, including the method of calculation or source of data in data file to be attached in the web form.

8.Metadata Elements for Departments/ Resources and their Description

8.1  Departments

  • Title (Required): A unique name for the catalog (group of resources) viz. Current Population Survey <Year>, Consumer Price Index <Year>, Variety-wise Daily Market Prices Data, State-wise Construction of Deep Tubewells over the years, etc.
  • Description (Required): Provide a detailed description of the catalog e.g., an abstract determining the nature and purpose of the catalog.
  • Keywords (Required): It is a list of terms, separated by commas, describing and indicating at the content of the catalog. Example: rainfall, weather, monthly statistics.
  • Asset Jurisdiction (Required): This is a required field to identify the exact location or area to which the catalog and resources (dataset/apps) caters to viz. entire country, state/province, district, city, etc.

8.2 Resources (Datasets/Apps)

  • Category (Required): Choose from the drop down options. Is it a Dataset or an Application.
  • Title (Required): A unique name of the resource viz. Consumer Price Index for <Month/Year> etc.
  • Access Method (Required): This could be ―Upload a Dataset or ―Single Click Link to Dataset.
  • Reference URLs: This may include description to the study design, instrumentation, implementation, limitations, and appropriate use of the dataset or tool. In the case of multiple documents or URLs, please delimit with commas or enter in separate lines.
  • Language: Language of the dataset
  • Date Released: It mentions the release date of the Dataset/App.
  • Note: It mentions the anymore information the contributor/controller wishes to provide to the data consumer or about the resource.

9. Policies

Disclaimer

Although information and content in this portal has been put with care and diligence, PMC does not take responsibility on how this information is used or the consequences of its use. In case of any inconsistency/confusion, the user should contact the concerned Officer of PMC for further clarifications.

9.1 Hyperlinking Policies

  • Links to External Websites/Portals:
  • At many places in this portal, you shall find links to other websites/portals created and maintained by other Government, non-Government / private organizations. These links have been placed for your convenience. When you select a link you are navigated to that website. Once on that website, you are subject to the privacy and security policies of the owners / sponsors of the website.
  • PMC is not responsible for the contents and reliability of the linked websites and does not necessarily endorse the views expressed in them. Mere presence of the link or its listing on this portal should not be assumed as endorsement of any kind. PMC cannot guarantee that these links will work all the time and we have no control over availability of linked pages.
  • Links to the Portal by Other Websites/Portals
  • PMC do not object you for linking directly to the information that is hosted on our site and no prior permission is required for the same. However, we would like you to inform us (using the Contact Us option) about any links provided to our site. PMC do not permit our pages to be loaded into frames on your site. These pages must load into a newly opened browser window of the user.

                9.1.1 Content Archival Policy (CAP)

  • As per Open Government Data Platform archival policy, we don't need to archive anything right now. All the contents contributed by various stakeholders are accessible on the portal.

               9.1.2 Content Review Policy (CRP)

  • Pune DataStore has a very robust policy of review its content through routine testing of web pages and the content. Since this is a platform which boasts of datasets and catalogue, the Project Management Unit (PMU) is frequently in the process of updating and reviewing the datasets and catalogues in order to provide up to date datasets to its users. The feedback and engagement policy with the users itself provides an effective measure of review and check towards the content on the platform. Monitoring of Platform is done on regular basis.

              9.1.3  Privacy Policy

  • Your privacy is important to us. Anyone can generally visit the site without revealing Personal Information unless he chooses to provide such information.
  • As a general rule, this portal does not automatically capture any specific personal information from you, (like name, phone number or e-mail address), that allows us to identify you individually.
  • This portal records your visit and logs the following information for statistical purposes, such as Internet Protocol (IP) addresses, domain name, browser type, operating system, the date and time of the visit and the pages visited.
  • We make no attempt to link these addresses with the identity of individuals visiting our site unless an attempt to damage the site has been detected. We will not identify users or their browsing activities, except when a law enforcement agency may exercise a warrant to inspect the service provider's logs. If PMC portal requests you to provide personal information, you will be informed how it will be used if you choose to give it and adequate security measures will be taken to protect your personal information.
  • We collect and store the following information about user visits for statistical purpose:
  • The internet domain of users services provider and IP address from which user access our website.
  • The type of browser and operating system used to access our site.
  • Date and time user accessed our site.
  • The pages/URLs visited
  • If the visitor reached this website from another website, the address of that referring website.

9.2   Copyright Policy

  • Material featured on this Portal may be reproduced free of charge after taking proper permission by sending a mail to us. This is subject to the material being reproduced accurately and not being used in a derogatory manner or in a misleading context.
  • Where the material is being published or issued to others, the source must be prominently acknowledged. However, the permission to reproduce this material does not extend to any material on this site which is identified as being the copyright of the third party. Authorization to reproduce such material is obtained from the copyright holders concerned.
  • These terms and conditions shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the Indian Laws. Any dispute arising under these terms and conditions shall be subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the courts of India.Content Moderation & Approval Policy (CMAP)
  • Pune DataStore is a repository of large number of datasets meticulously divided into catalogues. All the datasets available are made available in adherence with the principles of Open Data Movement, which mandate easy access for further reuse in machine readable format. The datasets here are primarily sourced from the huge amount of data which is collected by various government institutions for administrative purposes and put together in machine readable format and made available on this platform.
  • PMC has appointed a chief data officer and data contributors from each department to become the point person for data sourcing, following which the data provided by the Chief Data Officer and the contributor is published on the platform after due moderation.
  • This particular platform is basically provides its user with important datasets of the various government departments without comprising its original value. The moderation process here is confined to formatting and ensuring that the datasets are made available in concurrence with the principles of Open Government Data, where no compromise or addition is made to the original values of the datasets which are provided by the data owners. The process of making the datasets into Open format forms the base for standardization in this particular platform.
  • Apart from data publication the platform also boasts of content matter which supports the datasets and gives an overview of the initiatives which are taken to make this platform more accessible and popular through community engagement and various other events. This content matter is contributed by the Project Management Unit (PMU) of the platform and ably moderated at the right level and published on the platform.
  • Finally with regard to the feedback and engagement with the larger public, the platform has a well laid out moderation and management process which involves moderation of feedback by the Admin followed by publication of the feedbacks and views. The larger public can also ask for and contribute datasets which is again moderated and based on sheer number of demand ultimately uploaded.

10.Terms and Conditions

  • This portal is designed, developed and maintained by IT Department, PMC. The content for the portal is provided by PMC and by accessing this portal, you unconditionally accept to be legally bound by the terms and conditions. If you do not agree to the mentioned terms and conditions, please do not access the portal. Efforts have been made to ensure that the content in the portal is accurate and up to date; however, the same should not be interpreted as a statement of law or used for any legal purposes. In case of any ambiguity or doubts, users are advised to verify / check with other source(s) and obtain appropriate professional advice.
  • Under no circumstances PMC will be liable for any expense, loss or damage including, without limitation, indirect or consequential loss or damage or any expense, loss or damage whatsoever arising from use, or loss of use, of data, arising out of or in connection with the use of this portal. These terms and conditions shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the Indian Laws. Any dispute arising under these terms and conditions shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the courts of India.
  • The Pune DataStore website is maintained for citizen benefits. Access and use of this site constitutes acceptance by you of these Terms and Conditions, which will take effect from the date of first use. Pune Municipal Corporation:
  • Requires that citizen use this site and its contents only for lawful purposes and in a manner that does not infringe or interfere with the rights of others.
  • Invites comments from citizens about this site and the data it contains but prohibits the posting or transmission of offensive, obscene, defamatory or otherwise unlawful material and any act that interferes with the normal use of the site.
  • Reserves the right, at its sole discretion, to remove any user posted material from this site which it deems unsuitable or inappropriate or otherwise infringes these Terms and Conditions of use.
  • May, at its sole discretion, edit, add to or change any aspect of this site without prior warning, Cannot always guarantee the accuracy of the data posted on this site. This will particularly be the case for data that has been extracted from this site and made available by a third party.

Citizens:

App Name: Rang Yatra

On February 15, Maharashtra’s first Art Gallery/Theatre Booking App was launched for Punekars by Minister Shri. Muldhiradhar Mohol.

Now, Punekars can book and make payments for 15 municipal art centers and their facilities, such as Art Gallery, Auditorium Hall, Conference Hall, etc., through the mobile app. There is no longer a need to visit in person to submit receipts or other physical documents.

This app will simplify all administrative processes related to bookings and ensure 100% transparency.

This initiative will be a milestone for Punekars, and it is expected to greatly help artists, the sports community, and the general public in showcasing their talents.

This app is available on Play Store / App Store.

raw.title: 100 Resilient Cities (100RC)
summary:
Pune is now part of the 100 Resilient Cities (100RC), led by the Rockefeller Foundation.

In May 2016, Pune was selected as one of the 100 Resilient Cities globally. We are now an integral member of a global community of leading, innovative, and highly respected cities working to build urban resilience. In 2013, the Rockefeller Foundation created the 100 Resilient Cities (100RC) initiative in celebration of the Foundation’s centenary.

Hundreds of cities around the world applied for the 100 Resilient Cities challenge. Among these, Pune's innovative approach to urban resilience, its collaborative partnerships, and its commitment to the 100RC network were exceptional. As a result, Pune was chosen as one of the 100 Resilient Cities. A total of four cities from India are part of the 100RC: Pune, Surat, Chennai, and Jaipur.

Cities are eligible for the following support from 100RC:

  • Funding to hire a Chief Resilience Officer (CRO) for at least two years.
    Technical and capacity-building services and support for developing and implementing resilience strategies for the city, in collaboration with the community, various stakeholders, and municipal officers.
  • Inclusion in the 100RC peer-to-peer and learning network, creating opportunities for professional development, sharing experiences, best practices, and exchanging innovative resilience strategies among CROs and other city officials.
  • Access to the 100RC Platform of Partners, providing resources to enable the implementation of resilience strategies and resilience-related initiatives, including finance, technology, infrastructure, land use, buildings and design, communications, community engagement, and more.
    (For more information, visit www.100ResilientCities.org)

For more information, contact: Mr. Mahesh Harhare, Chief Resilience Officer (CRO)
puneresilient@gmail.com

Mr. Ganesh Sonune,
Disaster Management Officer, PMC

raw.title: Drainage Connection
summary:
Information about repairs

SR.No

Questions – Drainage Connection

Information

1

Where can I make complaint about drainage line choke up or repairs to drainage chamber?

a) Complaints can be raised on various PMC channels:

  • Website – https://complaint.pmc.gov.in/home
  • Twitter – @PMCCare
  • Facebook – @PMC Pune
  • Whatsapp – +91-9689900002
  • Email – feedback@punecorporation.org
  • SMS – +91-9689900002
  • Call Centre – 18001030222

      b) Complaints (up to 450 mm diameter drainage lines) shall be addressed by Dy.Engineer,Sewage Department at respective ward offices (Zonal).

      c) Complaints (above 600 mm. diameter drainage lines) shall be addressed by Executive.Engineer,Sewage Department (Operation and Maintenance) at old Kasba Peth ward office building. (020 25508453)

2

Where and how should I submit application to get drainage NOC for Building Permission?

      Application can be submitted by a licensed Plumber/Architect via online services using https://services.pmc.gov.in/home​ corporation.org or at Citizen Facilitation Centers situated at the respective Ward office.

3

How many days it takes to issue drainage NOC for building permission?

NOC will be issued online,within 15 days of receipt of application.

4

What document are required to be attached along with application for obtaining NOC from drainage department for building completion certificate ?

1) Copy of the Licensed Plumber

2) Ownership Document (PRC / 7 / 12 Abstract)

3) Property Tax NOC

4) Copy of building permission given and attested copy of Commencement Certificate and four copies of Sanctioned Plan

5) Plan for drainage connection with site plan

6) NOC for Grahrachna Society (if Society)

5

Where and how do I apply to get drainage connection?

Application for new drainage connectionshall be submitted online or to Additional City Engineers,Sewerage Department, at main building of the Corporation,through licensed plumber along with scan copies of the certificate listed above in item no.4

6

How do I get drainage connection permission?

On submission of application through licensed plumber, approval is given by Dy.Engineer of drainage Department at Ward (Zonal) offices after site visit and all the required documents attach.

7

Where should I submit the application for the permission of drainage connection?

Application can be submitted at Citizen Facilitation Centers in the Corporation’s Main building or at Ward (Zonal) Offices.

8

Drainage connection and road cutting (concrete, tar road, foot path, etc.) charges?

1) Connection charges Rs.225/-

2) Development charges

a) Residential use Rs.1000/-

b) commercial use Rs.10000/-

c) Residential + Commercial use Rs.5000/-

d) Industrial use Rs.25000/-

3) Road excavation Rs.2600/- per running meter (for tar and concrete road, pavements and foot paths)

4) Soil / Murrum road excavation Rs.750/- per running meter

9

Where drainage connection charges should be paid?

Connection charges should be paid by challan at related Ward(Zonal) office.

10

Where should get license plumbers details?

List for the licensed plumbers list is available on web site and also at Additional City Engineers,Sewerage Department, at main building of the Corporation.

11

How many days it takes to issue drainage connection permission?

Permission will be issued online, within 15 days of receipt of application.

12

After completion of drainage(line/work)connection is it required to obtain the NOC?

Yes

13

What document are required to be attached along with application for obtaining NOC from drainage department require for building completion certificate?

1) Copy of the licensed plumber

2) Ownership Document (PRC / 7 / 12 Abstract)

3) Copy of building permission given and Commencement Certificate

4) Four Copies of Sanctioned Plan

5) NOC of grahrachna society (if society)

6) Property tax NOC

14

Where should be apply for new plumbing license?

Hand written application for plumbing license shall be submitted to Additional City Engineers, Sewerage Department, at main building of the Corporation

15

What Documents are required to be attached with application for new plumbing license?

Following documents should be submitted with the application:

1. Educational Qualification – Certificate

2. Copy of Aadhaar Card and Pan Card

3. Two color photographs (with red color background)

4. Work Experience Letters / Certificate,

5. ITI Passing Certificate,

6. School Leaving Certificate etc.

16

Is the plumbing license renewed annually?

Yes, Plumbing license should be renewed every year.

17

Where should one apply for renewal plumbing license?

Application for plumbing license shall be submitted to Additional City Engineers,Sewerage Department, at main building of the Corporation for renewal.

18

What Documents are necessary for renewal plumbing license?

Following documents should be submitted with the application for renewal:

1. Application for renewal Two colour photographs

2. Original copy of recent license

3. Two colour photographs (with red colour background)

4. Proof of residence (Ration Card, Driving License)

5. List of Work completed in previous by year experience letters / Certificate

6. ITI passing Certificate

7. School leaving Certificate etc.

19

Where charges should be paid for renewal of plumbing licenses

Application for plumbing license shall be submitted to Additional City Engineers,Sewerage Department, at main building of the Corporation

20

What charges for renewal of plumbing license

For plumbing renewal charges Rs.1500/-

21

How many days it takes to issue renewal of plumbing license

Permission will be issued online, within 15 days of receipt of application.

Verified by:

Jagdish Khanore

Chief Engineer,

Sewage Department

Pune Municipal Corporation

raw.title: Public Parking Policy 2016
summary:
Parking is an essential component of the transportation system. A typical vehicle runs for one hour on average and is parked for 23 hours in a day. It is also important to consider that a typical vehicle usually needs three different parking spaces-one at the owner’s residence, a second at the owner’s office/business place and a third at recreational/entertainment facilities. The rising number of vehicles in Pune city are likely to lead to 4.5 lakhs parking spaces every year, and that is simply preposterous to supply. Parking facilities are a major cost to society. As the numbers of vehicles in the city explode, parking becomes a public nuisance, swallowing all available spaces meant for other road users as well as creating a demand for all available open spaces to be turned into parking lots. The mindset that ‘provision of parking is a right’ must be changed. Creation of parking space and land required for that is extremely valuable and no resident has the right to its free use.

Traffic management and parking policy are closely interlinked and should serve a wider set of environmental, social and economic objectives. The city needs to give high priority to parking control initiatives, which encourage a shift from the use of personal modes of travel, especially the 2-wheeler and cars, to public transport, walking or cycling; and to traffic management programmes, which reduce accidents, congestion, pollution and dependency on personal modes of transportation.

Rather than having a reactive parking policy, one that constantly changes with the ever-increasing numbers of vehicles, the policy itself needs to ensure a reduction in the need for parking and support more strategic planning objectives.

In providing parking spaces, it is important to recognize that the location of such spaces, the car holding capacity and the price at which it is available can contribute in a significant manner in reducing the use of personal vehicles as well as in channelizing the demand for travel towards greater use of public transport. It is therefore necessary to strike a balance between the need to provide parking space and the need to locate it in such a manner as to encourage the use of sustainable modes of transport.

Parking spaces (on-street and off-street) have to be selected so as to have least impact on the flow of traffic. In such cases, parking shall not be available at all locations and people may have to finish their journey on foot or by other modes of transport.

In a city where a large share of trips are to be handled ideally by the public transport system, the intermediate modes of transport (auto rickshaws, taxis etc) become important to fill gaps left by the public transport grid. Currently no space has been allocated to these vehicles and they park or wait for rides on the roads and create major obstruction to traffic. In such cases, valuable parking spaces should be set aside for their use, especially at interchange locations between modes, like at bus terminals (both private and public) and railway stations and a separate study for demand management needs to be done.

The policy thus aims at achieving the following-

  • Encouraging use of alternative modes of transport and reduce motor vehicle use (thereby reducing traffic congestion, accidents and pollution).
  • Ability to accommodate new traffic management concepts and respond to traffic problems.
  • Appropriate use of land with promotion of environment friendly measures

Thus, this parking policy is expected to be such that it discourages usage of private modes, encourages efficient use of available parking spaces, aids in evolving a better transportation system, builds a strategy to reduce congestion, pollution, and also helps the public transport system to grow. The policy is expected to help the city in becoming more ‘people friendly’ than ‘vehicle friendly’.

PMC Public Parking Policy
PMC Public Parking Policy Resolution

raw.title: Crematorium Infrastructure and Eco Initiatives
summary:
Click here to view list of CEMETERIES

Various crematoriums of Pune Municipal Corporation offer options for cremation using electric cremation, gas cremation, and the traditional method of cremation using wood.

ELECTRICAL CREMATORIUM

Electrical Crematorium consists of :

  1. Moveable Trolley
  2. Furnace
  3. Gas Cleaning System with Venture Scrubber
  4. Chimney 100 feet
  5. Controls

Functioning of Electrical Crematorium :

  • The beginning process of cremation in the Electric Cremation is called incineration.
  • The furnace or incinerator is a high-powered furnace.
  • The body will be located in a combustion chamber called a retort. The crematory(also known as retort) is lined with refractory bricks that can withstand high fluctuations in temperature, but furnace chambers also have holes at the bottom.
  • The Electric crematorium is built with a double-chamber cremation furnace with a strong cremation bed and secondary air holes.
  • In the Electric Crematorium, the electrical connections do not need any particular fittings and a simple 220 Volts electrical outlet is all that is required.
  • The electric cremation furnace capacity is 54 Kw. The Electric heating coil is made up of NICROME 80/20 in the form of 25 mm dia coil with terminal rods and the entire furnace heating coil system (Coil holding brick wall) will be bonded with the side walls.
  • The cremation furnace is constructed with high-quality alumina refractory bricks, fire bricks, insulation bricks, arch bricks, and various sizes and types of slabs and bonded with high-quality castable, fire clay and mortars with a specific type of curing to the furnace to withstand the temperature up to 1200 degree centigrade.
  • The fitting of devices that prevent any dispersion from the cremation chamber has eliminated smoke and odors.
  • The cremation is completed in about 60 to 90 minutes maximum depending upon the body size and other biological reasons.
  • The hazardous gas and other substances are piped out from cremation chamber and cleaned by a venture scrubber with water treatment and finally the hot air is being discharged into 100 feet height chimney.
  • Electric Crematorium system has necessary controls, auto on-off, cut off switches and other necessary controls for the safety of cremation.

GAS CREMATORIUM

LPG Gas Crematorium consists of :

  1. Cremation Furnace
  2. LPG Gas Combustion System with Venture Scrubber
  3. Chimney 100 feet
  4. Controls
  5. The LPG gas automatic burners are built with fan, motor, pump, ignition transformer and electrode, flame sensor, sequence controller, gas solenoid valve, air pressure switch and gas pressure switch

Functioning Of Gas Crematorium :

  • A movable trolley places the body in the cremation platform in cremation furnace of the LPG Gas Crematorium.
  • Combustion blowers and air blowers are switched on and then the primary and secondary burners in the cremation chambers switched on to get the furnace temperature at about 850 degree.
  • By the movable trolley the body will be placed upon the cremation platform in the cremation chamber. The cremation door would then keep closed in the LPG Gas Crematorium.
  • LPG Gas Crematorium consists of primary and secondary chambers.
  • The LPG Gas crematorium is built with double chamber cremation furnace with a strong cremation bed and secondary air holes. The cremation furnace is constructed with high quality alumina refractory bricks, fire bricks, insulation bricks, arch bricks, various size and types of slabs and bonded with high quality castable, fire clay and mortars with a specific type of curing to the furnace to withstand the temperature up to 1200 degree centigrade.
  • The body, would incinerate in the primary and the secondary chamber between the temperature 850 and 1100 degree and the cremation get completed in about 60 to 90 minutes maximum depend upon the body size and other biological reasons.
  • Gas Cleaning System is also equipped with venture scrubber.
  • The hazardous gas and other substances are piped out from cremation chamber and cleaned by venture scrubber with water treatment and finally the hot air is being discharged into the 100 feet height chimney.
  • LPG Gas Crematorium system has the ash collection system to collect ash and remains for further customs.
  • LPG Gas Crematorium system has necessary controls, auto on-off, cut off switches and other necessary controls for a safety LPG gas crematorium.
  • The automatic LPG gas burners can be hooked with external control signal for total automation like PLC system, burner trip signal for alarm and hooter can be given from the burner sequence controller and burner fan can be by passed with a separate switch without any modification.

Air pollution control system

The department has installed air pollution control systems at various crematoriums in Pune. This is the alternative to the traditional open-burning system. The basic function of the system is to reduce the pollution. The gas produced after burning the body is passed through a water scrubber where its carbon content gets absorbed and filtered gas is released into the air. By use of this system, approximately 150 kg of; wood per body can be saved (in crematorium) resulting in around 40 per cent overall savings.  The system is in place at Vaikuntha, Hadapsar, Dhankawadi, Katraj, Yerawada and Kailas crematoriums.
