raw.title: Slum Eradication and Rehabilitation Department
summary:
Shri. Mahesh Patil

Deputy Commissioner (ZoNiPu)
Pune Municipal Corporation

Slum Rehabilitation Authority (SRA):

The Slum Rehabilitation Authority (SRA) is active in Pune and Pimpri-Chinchwad to rehabilitate declared/undeclared slums in Pune city.

Office Address: II Mutha Chambers (Extension Building), Senapati Bapat Road, Pune-16.
Phone No.: 020-25630234/36 Fax: 020-25630235
Email: addceo.srapune@yahoo.in Website: www.srapune.gov.in

The SRA is responsible for accepting proposals for slum redevelopment, verifying the eligibility of slum dwellers, approving rehabilitation projects, sanctioning project plans, overseeing construction, allocating flats to eligible slum dwellers, taking action against ineligible slum dwellers, and ensuring the execution of rehabilitation projects.

Question 1: What is the designation and office address of the Slum Eradication and Rehabilitation Department head?

Answer:

Shri. Mahesh Patil, Deputy Commissioner (ZoNiPu), Pune Municipal Corporation Office – Savarkar Bhavan, First Floor, Shivajinagar, Pune – 5. 

Under the Maharashtra Slum (Improvement, Eradication, and Redevelopment) Act, 1971, the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) provides facilities to slum dwellers, distributes service charge bills, handles slum transfers, takes action against illegal slums, and manages cleanliness and businesses in slum areas. The designated authorities are as follows:

  1. Shri. Rajiv Nandkar
    Designation: Competent Authority (ZoNiPu) & Deputy Commissioner (Zone Office No.1), PMC

Question 2: How many slums are there within the municipal limits? How many are declared/undeclared?

Answer:

  • Total slums – 390
  • Declared slums – 269
  • Undeclared slums – 121
Question 3: On whose land are the slums within the municipal limits situated?

Answer:

  • Slums (both declared and undeclared) on land owned by the Central Government, Maharashtra Government, MHADA, Municipal Corporation, Government + Municipal Corporation + Private land – 158
  • Slums on privately owned land – 232
Question 4: What documents are required for slum dwellers to obtain an identity card and qualify for the scheme?

Answer:
As per the Government Resolutions dated June 22, 2014, and May 16, 2015, the following documents are required:

  • Name must be listed in the voter list before January 1, 2000,
    or
  • Proof of residence in the slum before January 1, 2000, such as:
    • Electricity bill
    • Telephone bill
    • Sale deed
    • Business tax receipts
    • Income tax or other tax payment receipts
    • Ration card issued before January 1, 2000
    • School leaving certificate
    • Birth/death certificate
    • Driving license
    • Passport
    • Bank passbook issued before 2000
    • Tribal certificate
    • Voter ID card
  • Slum dwellers residing since January 1, 2003, should have cleared outstanding dues.
  • Slum dwellers on government initiative lands such as playgrounds, recreation grounds, parks, or non-buildable land before January 1, 2000, are eligible.
  • Business licenses issued by government/semi-government institutions, including trade licenses, eatery/hotel license, industrial license.
  • Any other legal documents proving residence before January 1, 2000.
Question 5: What documents are required for No Objection Certificates (NOC) for water and electricity connections in slums?

Answer:

For water connections, it is necessary to apply to the Water Supply Department of Pune Municipal Corporation, and for electricity connections, to MSEDCL (Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited) along with the following documents.

  • Application from the slum dweller
  • Proof of protected slum or eligibility as per revised government resolution
  • Copy of the service charge payment receipt for the current financial year
Question 6: What documents are required for the transfer of a slum dwelling?

Answer:

For hut transfer, it is necessary to apply to the concerned Regional Office along with the following documents.

  • Original photo pass of the slum dweller
  • Payment of transfer fee and processing as per the prevailing government resolution
  • Undertaking in the prescribed format
  • One of the following proofs from before January 1, 2000:
    • Name in the voter list
    • Election identity card
    • Government/Semi-government licenses or documents for the concerned location
    • Birth/death certificate, electricity bill, telephone bill, sales tax, business tax, income tax, or any other tax payment proof
Question 7: What documents are required for inheritance claims of a slum dwelling?

Answer:

For inheritance rights, it is necessary to apply to the concerned Regional Office along with the following documents.

  • Original photo pass of the slum dweller
  • Death certificate of the parent(s)
  • Legal consent letter from other heirs
  • One of the following proofs from before January 1, 2000:
    • Name in the voter list
    • Election identity card
    • Government/Semi-government licenses or documents for the concerned location
    • Birth/death certificate, electricity bill, telephone bill, sales tax, business tax, income tax, or any other tax payment proof
  • Proof of the inheritor's identity:
    • Aadhaar card number, current election identity card, or name in the voter list
  • The inheritor’s family must be currently residing in the said slum dwelling
Question 8: What is the annual water tax for a slum dwelling as per the Municipal Corporation?

Answer:

  • The annual water tax for each declared slum dwelling within municipal limits is ₹365.
Question 9: What is the annual service charge for a slum dwelling as per the Municipal Corporation?

Answer:
The annual service charge based on the slum area is as follows:

OwnershipUsage TypeArea (sq. ft.)Annual Fee (₹)Additional Monthly Charge (per sq. ft. beyond 225 sq. ft.) (₹)
Government/Semi-government & Private LandResidentialUp to 2253001.00
Government/Semi-government & Private LandJointUp to 2256001.50
Government/Semi-government & Private LandNon-residentialUp to 2259002.00
Question 10: What is the transfer fee for a slum dwelling?

Answer:
The transfer fee for a slum dwelling is as follows:

Usage TypeTransfer Fee (₹)
Residential40,000/-
Joint60,000/-
Non-residential60,000/-
Question 11: What is the fee for a slum identification card (Photo Pass)?

Answer:
The Photo Pass fee is as follows:

Usage TypeIdentification Card Fee (₹)
Residential200/-
Joint600/-
Non-residential800/-
Question 12: What should be the height limit for a hut?

Answer:
The height of a hut should not exceed 14 feet. If the height exceeds 14 feet, it will be considered unauthorized construction as per the provisions of the Maharashtra Slum Eradication and Improvement Act, 1971 (Revised Section 3Z-1), and action will be taken for its removal.

Question 13: Where can complaints regarding unauthorized slums/illegal constructions in municipal limits be filed?

Answer:
Complaints regarding unauthorized slums or illegal constructions should be filed with the Concerned Deputy Commissioner and Competent Authority (ZoNiPu) (Zone No. 1 to 5). A copy of the complaint should also be sent to the respective local municipal office.

Question 14: What are the eligibility criteria for beneficiaries under the Slum Rehabilitation Scheme?

Answer:
The eligibility criteria under the Slum Rehabilitation Scheme are as follows:

  • Original Photo Pass from 1987.
  • One of the following proofs from before January 1, 2000:
    • Name in the voter list
    • Election identity card
    • Government/Semi-government licenses or documents (birth certificate, death certificate, electricity bill, telephone bill, sales tax, business tax, income tax, or any other tax payment proof)
  • Current Proofs: Aadhaar number, current election identity card, or name in the voter list.
  • Survey list entry, cadastre map entry, and assessment register record for the slum dwelling.
  • The family must be residing in the slum dwelling at present.
  • If any other residential unit/shop is found in the municipal limits under the beneficiary's name, the eligibility will be canceled, and they will not receive benefits under the scheme.
Question 15: Where can I find the list of rehabilitated beneficiaries?

Answer:
The list of rehabilitated beneficiaries is available at the following locations:

  • Respective Hon. Deputy Commissioner and Competent Authority Offices of Zone No. 1 to 5
  • Slum Rehabilitation Authority, Pune, Pimpri-Chinchwad Region, II Mutha Chambers (Extension Building), Senapati Bapat Road, Pune – 16.

All the above information is subject to legal provisions and government resolutions.

raw.title: Key initiatives for Drainage mechanization
summary:
• Circular issued for 100% machine use and banning of manual cleaning without safety gears and safety equipments
  • PMC has bought 1 high capacity Suction cum jetting with Recycler Machine of 12 KL Capacity which will help in ensuring safety of Safaimitra and prevent them from entering the manhole for cleaning, PMC owns 7 Jetting machines.
  • Work contract given to contractor of high capacity 4 Suction cum jetting with Recycler Machine of 12 KL Capacity
  • Work Contract Given to contractor 35 jetting machines, 5 suction cum jetting machines, 31 grab machines.
  • (PMC outsources the equipments and machineries through tenders. Since the requirement of equipments is fulfilled as per the CPHEEO norms, the entire sewerage network and chambers is covered resulting into the entire city being catered in addition to the availability of special equipments like bandicoot and jetting cum suction with recycler)
  • Toll free number 14420 along with the existing toll free number 18001030222 is functional for grievance redressal.
  • The city has set up an ERSU (Emergency Response Sanitation Unit) in 2020 and appointed SRA (Sanitation Responsible Authority) to ensure that the complaints received in case of manual scavenging and issues with drainage lines can be resolved within few hours
  • (Eg: assessment, clustering, work contracts, financing/convergence, private engagement, setting of ERSU, purchase of mechanized equipment, etc

raw.title: PMC CARE
summary:
PMC CARE
C – Citizen
A – Assistance
R – Response
E – Engagement

Citizen Assistance Response Engagement

PMC CARE is a major initiative by the Pune Municipal Corporation, developed with the objective of providing citizens with all essential services conveniently and transparently through a single portal.

The PMC CARE mobile app and web portal, developed by the Information Technology Department, serve as a digital platform for the citizens of Pune and the officials of PMC. Through this platform, citizens can express their opinions in online forums, write articles, participate in competitions, pay property tax, obtain birth and death certificates, pay water bills, lodge and track complaints related to No Objection Certificates, receive important notifications, access emergency contact numbers, and find essential nearby locations, among many other services.

So far, this platform has facilitated the exchange of information with citizens through 784 blogs, 358 events, 43 webinars, 14 competitions, and 24 groups. Using this platform, 23,268 property tax transactions have been completed, 12,115 birth certificates and 3,371 death certificates have been issued, and 1,713 complaints have been effectively resolved.

Through app usage, visits to the website, and interactions on social media, over 17 million digital engagements have been achieved. This multi-dimensional platform not only provides services and facilities but also acts as a hub for information exchange and citizen interaction, making PMC CARE a center for effective public engagement.

Click Here to Download App

raw.title: Heritage Yatra Competitions
summary:
Heritage Yatra Competitions

A celebration of India's cultural richness through diverse competitions for school students.

Overview

The Heritage Yatra event is organized to encourage school students to showcase their talents and learn about India’s heritage through various creative competitions.

1. Essay Writing Competition

  • Theme: Heritage of India
  • Language: English or Marathi
  • Word Limit: 500–800 words
  • Eligibility: Students from Std. 8 to 10
  • Evaluation: Content, originality, grammar

2. Poetry Recitation Competition

  • Theme: Indian Culture and Heritage
  • Languages: Hindi, Marathi, or English
  • Time Limit: 2–3 minutes
  • Eligibility: Std. 6 to 8
  • Judging: Expression, clarity, modulation

3. Debate Competition

  • Topic: Impact of Modernization on Indian Traditions
  • Medium: English or Marathi
  • Time: 3 minutes per speaker
  • Eligibility: Std. 9 to 12
  • Marking: Relevance, logic, rebuttal

4. JAM Act (Just a Minute)

  • Theme: Indian Historical Monuments
  • Medium: English or Marathi
  • Time: 1 minute
  • Eligibility: Std. 6 to 8
  • Judging: Spontaneity, clarity, presentation

5. Shlok Recitation Competition

  • Source: Bhagavad Gita or Sanskrit texts
  • Time: 2 minutes
  • Eligibility: All school students
  • Criteria: Pronunciation, confidence

6. Rangoli Art Competition

  • Theme: Indian Festivals & Culture
  • Medium: Traditional Rangoli colors
  • Time: 1 hour
  • Eligibility: Std. 5 to 10
  • Judging: Creativity, neatness, theme relevance

7. Folk Dance Performance

  • Dance Form: Any Indian folk style (Lavani, Garba, etc.)
  • Time: Max 5 minutes
  • Eligibility: Group (5-10 students), Std. 6 to 10
  • Judging: Coordination, costume, authenticity

8. Heritage Quiz

  • Format: Multiple choice, oral questions
  • Topics: Indian history, monuments, freedom movement
  • Eligibility: Teams of 2 from Std. 7 to 10
  • Rounds: Preliminary + Final

9. Poster Making Competition

  • Theme: Unity in Diversity / My Heritage
  • Materials: Chart paper, colors, markers
  • Time: 45 minutes
  • Eligibility: Std. 5 to 9
  • Criteria: Creativity, clarity, visual impact

10. Patriotic Song Competition

  • Format: Group singing (school choir)
  • Theme: Patriotism and Indian Unity
  • Time: Max 4 minutes
  • Eligibility: Open to all students
  • Judging: Voice harmony, lyrics, enthusiasm

raw.title: Women Empowerment Centres
summary:
Women’s Resource Center (Sakshama Kaksha)

At each regional office level, Women’s Resource Centers (Sakshama Kaksha) have been set up by the Pune Municipal Corporation, through the Department of Social Development, to help resolve family disputes and tensions. Through these Family Counseling and Guidance Centers, a mediator role is taken to resolve family conflicts and misunderstandings through mutual dialogue. Free counseling and legal guidance are provided to women in need. Additionally, counseling and guidance are also offered for differently-abled individuals, senior citizens, and adolescent boys and girls.

At 15 ward office levels, through Women’s Resource Centers, the Pune Municipal Corporation provides information about various welfare schemes of the central and state governments.

raw.title: Water Distribution
summary:
Water Distribution

Metering water supply from source to consumers is the only way forward to stop water wastage: what is not measured cannot be managed! Once the network is equipped with a permanent monitoring system it will be possible to improve the level of service identifying both real and apparent losses, establishing an equitable distribution of the resource, providing a fair way to allocate costs, and promoting water conservation. 

Before reaching consumers, water flows from the abstraction point to the treatment plants and beyond, up to storage reservoirs and the distribution network. By monitoring the flow along such path, suppliers can get the knowledge of the amount that is being distributed and the amount that is lost in each part of the system, which is essential to guarantee an equitable distribution of water.

The installation of a detailed monitoring system is to be done at Pumping Stations in order to control the flow that is injected in the system, the pump efficiency and the energy consumption. Also reservoirs should be controlled by installing level meters to avoid the unfortunately frequent wastage of water through overflows.

Metering is then used to find out how much water is being extracted from the system and to bill customers according to their actual consumptions, which is perceived by many as the fairest way to allocate the costs of water supply to users. 

When people pay for the amount they use, water conservation is encouraged: there is evidence from the UK that there is an instant 10% drop in consumption when meters are being installed; in Hamburg (Germany) domestic daily water consumption for metered apartments (112 liter per capita) was 18% lower than for unmetered ones (137 liter per capita); and so on. Water conservation automatically leads to a reduction in costs, both in the short run (by reducing operating costs) and in the long run (by postponing costly system expansions).

Also portable equipment can be used for short term monitoring of flow and pressure in key points of the network. This activity is very important to support network model calibration, DMA (District Metered Area) design and implementation, and pressure management. 

Modern technologies allow to establish a remote control system able to receive data on a central computer from each bulk meter or pressure logger installed on the field by using GPRS protocol. Also users’ meters can be read automatically if an AMR (Automatic Meter Reading) system is installed.

To cut a long story short: monitoring is essential to start thinking the water supply system as an “industry” to be optimised in each step of the process: production, storage and distribution. 

UNIVERSAL METERING OF WATER SUPPLIES

Any resource supplied without measuring the quantity of supply has chances of being wasted. The quantity supplied is not known and hence quantity wasted is also not known. Charging for any resource on the surrogate measurement or indirectly do not motivate the consumers to use the resource judiciously. Same is true for water also. It is essential to supply water duly measured and charge for the quantity supplied. This reduces wastage and also undue consumption.

The metering efforts of water is traditionally opposed due to fears that it will lead to more bill for water and second being the human errors involved in meter reading will add to sufferings of consumers.

Answer lies in the fact that in flat rates for water, one who uses less water also pays the same amount as of the one who uses more. In turn the poor who uses less, subsidise the others who use more. The answer to human errors is now available in technology. The Automated Meter Reading type meters avoids the human errors in reading the meters and handling the data.

Another facts faced in the past by the consumers is meter going out of order very frequently and then average bills etc followed by meter repairing and testing etc made life miserable.

Earlier it used to be wet type meters in which there were train of gears which used to register the flow of water measured by rotating turbine. These gears used to go out of order frequently. Now in the dry dial type of meters the register is completely dry using magnetic transmission of motion of turbine to register. The earlier A - Class meters are now replaced by minimum B- class meters with 2% accuracy.

The air coming before the water gets registered as the meter rotates because of air is one more genuine reason for opposing fixing of meters.

This reason is valid for the consumers which live in higher areas and the distribution pipeline ascend from lower area to higher areas. The intermittent water supply systems have this problem for such areas predominantly. Now the air release valves are available which when installed earlier to the meter do not allow air to pass through the meter and completely expels it out.

One more reason for the opposition to water meter is after passage of some years when the strainer ahead of meters get loaded with dirt etc and due to heavy head loss across it, the consumer get less water.

This is a maintenance problem and the strainer shall be cleaned periodically. The Municipal corporation shall have a periodic maintenance protocol established and act on that. It shall also include calibration of meters at fixed intervals.

Cities which are going for universal metering

The cities going for universal metering are:

  1. Mumbai (AMR) in part area
  2. Navi Mumbai (AMR)
  3. Nagpur
  4. Guwahati
  5. New Delhi
  6. Mysore

The towns / cities / villages which already have universal metering are:

  1. Malkapur (AMR)
  2. Jalochi
  3. Thangaon
  4. Amravati
  5. Ambernath and Badlapur
  6. Yeotmal
  7. Hubali Dharwad (part)
  8. Panchgani
  9. Satara (Area under MJP)

raw.title: Model Schools
summary:
Model School Scheme in Pune

  • The Model School Scheme has been implemented in Pune city from the year 2023-24 as a joint initiative of the Pune Municipal Corporation Education Board and the Building Design Department.
  • Under this initiative, every year, one school from each regional office is selected, making a total of 15 schools. So far, work on 15 schools has been completed, and work on the next 15 schools is in progress.
  • In these selected schools, a uniform color scheme, standardized flooring, toilet design, and Bala painting are being implemented.
  • In addition, various structural repairs (e.g., toilets, water tanks, boundary walls, playgrounds, waterproofing, door and window repairs), electrical systems, CCTV setup, fire safety systems, and rainwater harvesting work are being carried out.

raw.title: TDR Generation
summary:
The Transferable Development Rights (TDR) process plays a crucial role in urban development and land acquisition in Pune. It allows landowners to receive development rights in exchange for surrendering their land for public projects such as roads, parks, and civic amenities. The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) ensures a transparent and streamlined process for granting and utilizing TDR, making urban expansion more systematic and sustainable.

In addition, the 33 MLD water treatment project at Fursungi, as well as the 12 MLD project at Manjari, are in the final stages under Maharashtra Jeevan Pradhikaran. Once completed, these projects will be transferred to the Pune Municipal Corporation.

Regarding the Quality of Drinking Water

  • Drinking water is supplied to Pune city through 14 water centers located at 11 sites managed by the Pune Municipal Corporation Water Supply Department.
  • The Water Supply Department maintains a central testing laboratory at the Parvati Water Center where physical, chemical, and biological analyses are conducted.
  • Approximately 15,000 water samples are collected every month from all water centers, distribution reservoirs, and various taps in the city for testing.
  • Daily tests are conducted on 40 parameters of drinking water as prescribed by the Indian Standard ‘IS10500:2012’.
  • Continuous testing is carried out at various stages in the water treatment centers to ensure the effectiveness of the purification process.
  • A consolidated report of the water sample tests is submitted every month to the Maharashtra State Health Laboratory, Pune.
  • Since April 2022, the water testing reports have been made available in the public domain on the website

    Water Sample Testing

    Inspection report of the source
  • The detailed water testing parameters maintained by the department’s laboratory are available for public reference.
  • The list of testing parameters along with the specifications as per IS10500:2012 is provided below.

Precautions for Maintaining Quality that Citizens Should Take

  1. Drinking water should always be stored in a clean environment and in clean containers.
  2. If the drinking water supplied by the Municipal Corporation is stored in a society’s basement or other storage tanks, ensure that the surrounding area is kept clean. All water tanks in the society should be cleaned at regular intervals.
  3. Take care to ensure that no water from external sources, which may not be properly treated or verified, is mixed into the drinking water tank supplied by the Municipal Corporation.
  4. Ensure that no sewage or similar water is stored near the drinking water tank or allowed to flow directly into it.
  5. When undertaking any plumbing work at home, verify that the pipelines for drinking water and other water supplies remain separate and do not get mixed.
  6. For the convenience of citizens, a paid water testing facility has been made available at the Parvati Water Center Laboratory, located opposite Bhandari Hotel, Sinhagad Road, Ganeshmala, Pune-30. The challan (payment receipt) for water testing can be issued between 9:00 AM and 12:30 PM, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and all government holidays. The water testing report will be provided on the fifth working day after submitting the water sample. To collect the test report, a photocopy of the paid challan must be submitted at the laboratory.

raw.title: Local Body Tax Sub Sections
summary:
Collection

The Dealers pay LBT on import goods within PMC limits, and the Collection Section maintains a detailedregister for all LBT payments (Dealer wise, date wise, month wise, budget wise). The reconciliation is done with assigned banks & Chief Accountant Department where the amount difference is rectified.

Following Banks are appointed to receive or collect LBT payment.

  • Bank of Maharashtra

Local Body Tax payment received through Cash / Cheque / DD / Online (Through HDFC & ICICI Bank) in appointed Banks all Branches within PMC limits.

Inward and Outward

The Inward section receives letters from the citizens and registers them. These letters are then sent to Joint Municipal Commissioner/Asst. Municipal Commissioner for their information and signatures if required. The signed letters are dispatched to the concern section.

The letters from the department sent to the concern departments, Individuals and citizens are registered in outward register.

Paybill

Services

  • Scrutinizes cases of heirs, Indemnity bonds and overtime payments
  • Maintains Labor / Employee Welfare Fund
  • Maintains inward / outward records of documents
  • Takes necessary follow-up of the cases of pension and departmental inquiries of the concerned employees, etc.

Pension

Services

  • Works on cases of the retirement and voluntary retirement of employees and puts up necessary submission against the queries concerned with such cases to the said department.
  • Processes financial payments of deceased employees to their legal heirs as per service rules.
  • Prepares appointment documents of legal heirs of the deceased employees as per the agreement of 1985, and submits it to the concerned department.

Administration

This section takes care of all the administrative activities of the department such as preparation of salary statements, employee records, retired employees documents, bill payments as per administrative directives/circulars (Dearness Allowance, Ex-gratia amount, festival (Diwali) advance, etc.), documents of office expenses etc.

Annual Return Checking

Annual Return Checking Section

It is mandatory for the registered vendors to submit their annual return of every year within the period of 90 days after the ending of the current financial year in the prescribed format or by online method as per the provisions of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act, 1949 and Local Body Tax Rules, 2010.

The registered vendor should submit a purchase register along with the bills of the materials imported within municipal limits in the said financial year. The vendors can present for the hearing fixed by the appropriate authority with its signature on the desired date and time to verify and assessment of the return submitted by the said vendors.

Stationery and Record

Services

  • Send office stationery requirements to PMC press & Store Department, PMC.
  • Stationery purchase procedure:
  • Make a proposal
  • Get quotations
  • Get approval
  • Create comparative price list
  • Make a bills of received stationery material from store department
  • Get all the bills scrutinized from PMC audit section.
  • As per office requirement local body tax related various books, notices, forms etc. to be printing in PMC press with approval of higher authority.
  • Maintain & Keep the record in prescribed format of all computer stationery & other printed stationery used by office. As per record rule, old records are destroyed by legal process.

RTI

Services

  • Acknowledge applications received under Right to Information Act and to bring it to the notice of the concerned Public Information Officer.
  • Connecting with the concerned sub section and ensuring the availability of necessary information and documents requested by the applicant.
  • Make challans available to the applicants and provide requested documents after payments.
  • Set date and time for appeals received under the Right to Information Act.
  • Citizens can file RTI application/appeal through online RTI Information system on https://rtionline.maharashtra.gov.in this website.

Court

It is duty of the Court Section to collect necessary information on the documents /papers submitted in the judicial court under the Local Body Tax.

Services

  • Submissions to the Joint Municipal Commissioner for filing of a criminal case against the vendors / defaulters
  • Get signatures of the Joint Municipal Commissioner on legal bond to be submitted in the court.
  • Request dates from the court time to time with a necessary note in the register, and intimate the concerned officers for required information.
  • File an appeals in the senior division or senior court / high court / supreme court, prepare necessary submission / papers along with a required signatures of the Joint Municipal Commissioner or Assistant Municipal Commissioner in case the decision is against PMC and submit it to the concerned advocates/lawyers.

Refund

It is necessary for vendors to apply or submit demand application on his/her letterhead or on simple page with an authentic signature to get refund of Local Body Tax as per the provisions of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act, 1949 and Local Body Tax Rules.

It is essential for vendors to enclose/submit the necessary papers i. e. an original receipt and chalan of Local Body Tax paid to the Corporation, copy of sale and purchase register, original bills of the goods imported or exported, the lorry or transport receipts, self attested bond of the vendors and other documents as per the refund policy, along with his application or demand application.

It is required that the goods without any change in its originality should be exported outside municipal limits within a period of 6 months. The importer and exporters should be same, and the vendor should submit refund application within a period of one month after exporting the said goods.

raw.title: License Inspector
summary:
The key component of the License and Hoarding Department is the License Inspector. There are 15 licensed inspectors working for the 15 regional offices, with one assigned to each office. The License Inspector visits business establishments within the jurisdiction of the regional office to inspect and verify whether the business has obtained the necessary permission. Additionally, actions are taken as per Sections 244 and 245 of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act, 1949, and the Maharashtra Government Advertisement Hoarding Regulation and Control Rules, 2022, on a regional office basis.

The Honorable Deputy Commissioner of Licenses and Hoardings, from the Head Office, regulates and controls the provisions under Sections 244 and 245 of the Maharashtra Municipal Corporations Act, 1949, and the Maharashtra Government Regulation and Control Rules, 2022. Since 2018, the Licensing and Hoarding Office has been decentralized. However, policy-related decisions are taken by the main department.

Additionally, official advertisement hoardings, boards, banners, and flex boards are approved through the Municipal Assistant Commissioner, with the consent of the Honorable Deputy Commissioner (Zone) and the final approval of the Honorable Additional Commissioner (Estates) through the Honorable Deputy Commissioner of Licenses and Hoardings.

Recovery Process

Unauthorized businesses, advertisement hoardings, boards, banners, flex, etc., are subject to legal action. A notice is issued to the concerned individual or organization, and the recovery process is carried out in Pune.

Action Procedure

Unauthorized advertisement hoardings, boards, banners, flex, etc., belonging to individuals or organizations are removed. As per the detailed order passed by the Hon’ble Bombay High Court in pending Public Interest Litigation (PIL) No. 155/2011 on 31/01/2017, police assistance is sought for the removal action.

As per the same High Court order, the following officers have been appointed for enforcement and monitoring.

Enforcement and Responsible Officers

raw.title: Current Status of Dams in Pune Region 2025
summary:
📞 Emergency Contacts

Current Status of Dams in Pune Region

July 15, 2025
Red Alert in Pune District – Large Discharge Likely Today (15 July 2025) from Khadakwasla Dam to Regulate Reservoir Levels, Citizens Advised to Stay Alert
July 15, 2025
On 15th July 2025 at 2:00 PM, water discharge from Mulshi Dam will increase from 8200 to 12300 Cusecs. Residents near the river are advised to remain alert.
July 14, 2025
As of 14th July 2025, Mulshi Dam is 76.53% full and rainfall activity continues with varying intensity. The ongoing water discharge of 1100 Cusecs into the Mula River will be increased to 3500 Cusecs at 6:00 PM today. If the rainfall continues or increases, the discharge may be further adjusted.
July 07, 2025
Mulshi Dam in the Pune region is currently 76.67% full, and continuous rainfall is ongoing in the catchment area. At present, 5,800 cusecs of water is being discharged into the Mula River, which is scheduled to be increased to 8,200 cusecs at 3:00 PM. Citizens residing near the riverbanks are advised to remain alert.
July 02, 2025
at 10:00 PM, the discharge from Khadakwasla Dam into the Mutha river is being increased from 2,464 cusecs to 3,883 cusecs. This is subject to change as per requirement. Residents along the riverbanks are requested to remain alert.

raw.title: 100 Days Action Plan
summary:
As per the Hon. Chief Minister's directives – 100 Days Seven Point Action Taken Report

Pune Municipal Corporation

Achievements within 100 Days
Click here to download the 100 Days Action Plan Report
Click here to download the Ward Wise 100 Days Action Plan Report
Website
  • Pune Municipal Corporation’s official website, www.pmc.gov.in, has been operational since October 2016.
  • Approximately 5 million citizens visit the website annually.
  • Upgraded using modern technology with a user-friendly interface.
  • All departmental information updated as of April 15, 2025.
  • Proactive disclosure under the Right to Information Act and updated Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs).
  • New security certificate obtained on April 15, 2025, valid until April 14, 2026.
  • 89 citizen services notified under the Maharashtra Right to Public Services Act and published online on the portal.
  • New website inaugurated by the Hon. Municipal Commissioner on April 22, 2025.

Ranked 1st in the Maharashtra Urban e-Governance Index 2024 for PMC CARE (Portal, App, Social Media) — as per a survey by Policy Research Organisation.

Coordination with Central Government
  • Follow-up with the Central Government on pending proposals and bills related to the PMC’s development.
Sr. No. Department Name Project Name Fund Requested (INR in Crores) Concerned Central Department
1 Water Supply Approval pending for 125 MLD Water Treatment Plant at Vadgaon under AMRUT 2.0 (INR 195.10 Cr) – Central Government share under consideration (SHPSC Date: 10-10-2024) 48.78 MoHUA, GoI (AMRUT 2.0 Division)
2 Drainage / Electricity Approval pending for upgradation/renovation of 9 existing Sewage Treatment Plants under AMRUT 2.0 (INR 842.86 Cr) – Central Government share INR 252.86 Cr (30%) (SHPSC Date: 10-10-2024) 252.86 MoHUA, GoI (AMRUT 2.0 Division)
  • Achieving the targets set under central government schemes for the state – Reforms and targets under the 15th Finance Commission successfully implemented by Pune Municipal Corporation.
  • Securing the central share for centrally sponsored schemes and ensuring budgetary allocation and disbursement of the state’s share – Achieved. (Under the National River Conservation Plan – for pollution abatement of the Mula-Mutha River in Pune city [JICA Project], INR 100 Crores disbursed by the Central Government to the State Government is being made available to Pune Municipal Corporation.)
  • Ensuring timely action and submission of compliance reports on communications received from various departments of the Central Government – Yes. (Under Phase 2 of the Sewage Treatment Project for the 23 merged villages, preliminary consent has been given by JICA to provide funding support for works worth INR 856.91 Crores.)
Cleanliness Initiatives
  • A special cleanliness drive was conducted across 68 offices, including all ward and departmental offices.
  • Records of 35 offices were audited, and obsolete / unusable furniture was disposed of in 10 offices.
  • All headquarters, zonal, and ward offices provided assurance of compliance with office cleanliness protocols.
  • Expired records were disposed of as per procedure.
  • The register of heavy equipment and materials was updated, and old, unusable items were properly discarded.
  • Decommissioning and auctioning of old vehicles – A total of 473 vehicles owned by PMC that had exceeded 15 years of service life were scrapped under the Government of India’s 2021 Vehicle Scrapping Policy, generating ₹8 crore in revenue for the corporation.
Grievance Redressal

Resolution status of complaints received through various portals

Portal Complaints Received Complaints Resolved Pending (%)
Aaple Sarkar Portal 1,928 1,862 3.42%
P.G. Portal 542 524 3.32%
Pune Municipal Corporation (2024 - 2025) 107.90K 96.74K 2.20%
  • 9 platforms available for citizens to register complaints (Website, PMC Care, Mobile Application, Toll-Free Number, WhatsApp, WhatsApp Chatbot, X [Twitter], Facebook, Email)
  • A dedicated department is operational for addressing grievances
  • Visitor desks established at the Main Building and Ward Offices
  • All complaints received through PMC and State Government channels are resolved at the earliest
  • Officials interacted with visitors at the main office and resolved issues at the ward and zonal offices
Amenities and Facilities in Offices
  • Permanent drinking water facilities (RO filters with coolers) available on each floor of the Main Office and at other PMC offices
  • Accessible toilets for men, women, and persons with disabilities
  • Updated visitor lounges with seating arrangements and electric wheelchair accessibility for citizens
  • Parking facilities for two and four wheelers
  • “Hirakani” Room and Counseling Centers operational
  • Nameplates, directional signage, and beautification (painting and cleanliness) works are ongoing at all offices
Improvements in Operations
  • The e-office system has a total of 500 users, of which 395 are active.
  • A total of 34 departments have been registered, with 87 positions and 97 types of vacancies entered.
  • A total of 80 workshops have been conducted in this regard.
  • Cases are resolved by obtaining approval at 4 or fewer levels within the e-office system.
  • Clarifications or explanations regarding government opposing news appearing in newspapers or on social media are published on the municipal website and social media platforms.
Employee Training, Service Matters, and the Use of Artificial Intelligence Technology (AI)
  • Training has been provided to newly recruited officers/employees.
  • Confidential reports of officers and employees have been completed for the period up to March 31, 2024.
  • Service seniority lists have been published, and between January 1, 2025, and April 15, 2025, a total of 393 officers and employees have been promoted.
  • Training on Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology was provided to 367 officers / employees on April 4 and 7, 2025. AI is now being used in daily operations.
Promotion of Economic and Industrial Investment
  • Out of the 89 services notified under the Right to Public Service Act, a total of 79 services are provided online, with 24 of these services launched in the last 100 days.
  • Online construction permits are now being issued with QR codes and digital signatures.
Improved Standard of Living

Urban Poor Medical Assistance Scheme

  • Eligibility - The scheme is applicable to families in the municipal corporation's jurisdiction who hold a yellow ration card under the poverty line, and whose annual income is up to ₹1,60,000.
  • For each family, the maximum amount allowed for one year is ₹1,00,000, and for kidney, heart disease, and cancer treatments, the amount is ₹2,00,000.
  • The process of issuing membership for the scheme has been computerized since September 2022. In this system, citizens can upload the necessary documents on the website https://sgy.pmc.gov.in/.
  • Benefits - Pre-approval letters, which citizens previously had to obtain from the SGY department, are now being issued by the hospitals.
  • About 100 letters are prepared daily.
  • Each hospital is provided with a separate login.
  • Cardholders who previously had to visit the office 2-3 times for letters no longer need to come.

Through the RTS portal, 24 new services have been made available online, bringing the total number of online services to 79.

S.No Department Name Service Name under the Maharashtra Right to Public Service Act 2015

2 Change in Water Connection Charges

23 Change in Number of Partners (Increase/Decrease)
24 Changing the Business Name
Innovative Initiatives - Office Management Improvements
  • Beautification of the Dhankawadi-Sahakarnagar Regional Office: Expansion and beautification of services for citizens, making it more accessible.
  • Under the initiative of the Assistant Commissioner, key improvements have been made such as painting, tree plantation, appropriate arrangements for meetings, water supply, informative picture boards, directional signboards, and a reception area. These upgrades have made the office environment cleaner, more attractive, and more convenient for citizens.
  • Appreciation of Citizen-Friendly Initiatives: Additional Municipal Commissioner Prithviraj B.P. has specially appreciated this citizen-friendly initiative and urged other regional offices to follow this example.
  • Advanced Services and Effective Management: Dedicated planning has been undertaken to more effectively meet the basic needs of citizens and resolve their complaints promptly. Special emphasis is placed on providing immediate services.
  • Effective Implementation under the Chief Minister’s 7-Point Program: Efforts are underway to implement the 100-day planned schemes effectively under the state government's Chief Minister's 7-Point Program. These beautification and improvement measures at the Dhankawadi-Sahakarnagar regional office are an important step toward making it an exemplary service center for citizens.

raw.title: Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)
summary:
Join Us in Building a Progressive and Inclusive Pune

Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) warmly invites companies, corporate foundations, institutions, and philanthropic organizations to become valued partners in the city's journey toward inclusive development and urban excellence.

Under the ambit of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), we welcome your collaboration on initiatives that:

  • Uplift communities
  • Protect the environment
  • Strengthen public infrastructure
  • Create long-lasting social impact

Whether through health, education, sustainability, or innovation, your partnership can help shape a progressive, equitable, and sustainable Pune for current and future generations.

Why Partner with PMC?

Pune is one of India’s fastest-growing urban centers. At PMC, we are committed to delivering quality services, resilient infrastructure, and inclusive growth. Your CSR support can accelerate transformation in key areas that impact millions of lives.

Here’s why your partnership matters:

  • Transparent & Accountable Governance
  • Impact-Driven and Scalable Projects
  • Credible and Proven Implementation Mechanisms
  • Public Recognition for Contributors

raw.title: Pune Darshan AC Bus Service
summary:
Explore the Heritage & Beauty of Pune in a Day

Whether you're enchanted by natural beauty or fascinated by historical landmarks, PMPML’s Pune Darshan bus service offers an unforgettable one-day tour across the city’s iconic tourist attractions. Designed for travelers from across India and abroad, this guided journey showcases the rich cultural, historical, and spiritual heritage of Pune.

For years, PMPML has proudly provided this convenient and affordable service, helping to promote and preserve the essence of Pune through accessible tourism

Tour Highlights

The Pune Darshan tour covers 16 major tourist attractions:

  1. Kesariwada
  2. Shaniwarwada
  3. Lal Mahal
  4. Shrimant Dagdusheth Halwai Ganpati Mandir (External view)
  5. Aga Khan Palace
  6. Tribal Museum
  7. National War Memorial – Southern Command
  8. Shinde Chhatri
  9. Rajiv Gandhi Zoological Park
  10. Sarasbaug Ganpati Temple
  11. Mahalakshmi Temple (External darshan)
  12. P.L. Deshpande Garden
  13. Raja Dinkar Kelkar Museum
  14. Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar Museum
  15. Chatushrungi Mata Mandir
  16. ISKCON Temple – Kondhwa Road

Booking Information

  • Booking Options:
    Book your tickets offline at PMPML counters.
  • Boarding Points & Timings:
    • Pune Station – 08:30 AM
    • Deccan Gymkhana – 08:30 AM
  • Arrival Time: Approx. 6:00 PM

Why Choose PMPML Pune Darshan?

  • Trusted and safe transport
  • Expertly curated route of 16 attractions
  • Affordable for individuals, families, and groups
  • Promotes Pune's heritage and tourism
  • Hassle-free experience with designated stops and timings

Plan Your Pune Experience Today!

Explore Pune with comfort, knowledge, and joy – all in a single day with PMPML. Book now and immerse yourself in the heart of Maharashtra’s cultural capital.

Visit PMPML site for more details.

raw.title: Rajiv Gandhi Academy of E-Learning
summary:
About School

The Rajiv Gandhi Academy of e-Learning has been established by Pune Municipal Corporation in the year 2011 in line with its motto "Varam Janahitam Dhyeyam". The school aims to serve the community at large and to focus on the needs of the less privileged sections of the society. The school is dedicated to achieve continuous and comprehensive development of the child beyond the conventional method education based on textbooks. Rajiv Gandhi Academy of e-Learning offers schooling from Junior KG to Class 10th and is affiliated to Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE). The medium of instruction at school is in English.

Infrastructure at School
The school, which is located at Shivdarshan Road, Parvati Paytha, offers excellent infrastructure to its students comprising of well furnished, spacious ventilated classrooms, e- Learning facility with LCD screen in each classroom, Computer Laboratory, Science Laboratory, Amphitheatre with capacity of around 450 and high quality public address system.

Facilities
The school provides free and quality education, books and stationery, school uniform, sweater shoes to students along with milk, breakfast Nutritious lunch

Teachers
A Teacher plays the vital role in the lives of children for the formative years of their development. Keeping this in mind, we carefully appoint the professionally qualified staff for teaching as well as non-teaching responsibilities. The school has hired trained housekeeping staff for maintenance cleanliness of school.

Activities at Rajiv Gandhi e-Learning School

1. Sports

Sports play an essential role in the personality development of a child. We at Rajiv Gandhi e-Learning, encourage our students to engage themselves in various sports. The students at our school possess dynamic abilities in various sports like Chess, Gymnastics, Karate, Boxing and other sports. They successfully bring medals and trophies for the school by participating in state and national level competitions.

2. Cultural Activities

The school provides a platform for pupils to showcase their talents in various cultural activities such as music, dance, and drama. Students are encouraged by teachers to participate in various cultural activities to develop their confidence.

3. Co-Curricular Activities

Co-curricular activities are very much essential for the students to learn life values and prepare them to work in a team and many other values. Activities such as "Swachhta Abhiyan", Essay Competition, Handwriting competition, Craft making, Fort making, Rangoli, Diya making etc. are conducted throughout the year.

4. Science exhibition

Science exhibition aims to provide a platform to innovative ideas of students in each academic year. The students participate and present their science projects, working models to other students, parents and invitees. Students get a valuable guidance from their teachers for this presentation and communication with the observers.

5. Guest lectures for general awareness

Various types of lectures by expertise are arranged for the students to create general awareness among students regarding behavior, developing certain skills, duties towards society etc.

For example lectures on good and bad touch, good habits, e-waste management, etc

Admission Process

  1. The only entry point for students is Junior KG. Therefore, the admissions for the academic year open only for class of Junior KG. The process of admission is offline.
  2. Advertisement- Advertisement for Admission to Junior KG is published in the local newspaper in the month of December or January every year. We accommodate about 80 students for each academic year.
  3. Criteria for Admission: The Criteria for the admissions are mentioned in the newspaper advertisement as per the norms. The age of student of should be around 4 years. 100% seats are reserved for the students below poverty line . (Annual Income less than 1 Lakh)
  4. Distribution and submission of form: Admission forms are distributed and collected at the school itself for near about 10 days without any charges. Parents have to submit the admission form of their child along with all the necessary documents (Birth Certificate, Income Certificate, and Residential Proof). They will get a receipt with an application number on it after the submission of the form.
  5. Scrutiny for shortlisting the candidates: The scrutiny is done by the authorized committee appointed by PMC. The committee shortlists the candidates and the list of the eligible candidates is displayed at the school notice board.
  6. Selection Process : The selection of the candidates is done by the draw of lots in presence of all the parents of eligible candidates, local corporator, PMC members and school staff.

Various Committees of the School
Various committees have been established for the efficient management of the school. Monthly Quarterly meetings are conducted regularly for the smooth functioning of the school. The list of committees is as follows:

  • School Management committee
  • Parents Teacher Association.
  • Sexual harassment committee.
  • Mid-day meal committee.
  • Sports committee.
  • Exam committee.
  • Cultural committee.
  • Discipline committee.
  • Transport committee.

Image Gallery

raw.title: COVID-19: Citizen Awareness and Precaution Guidelines
summary:
COVID-19: Citizen Awareness and Precaution Guidelines

As per the Hon’ble Maharashtra Government’s guidelines, it is important to note that most COVID-19 cases are currently mild in nature.

The currently circulating Omicron variants include JN.1, XFG, and LF 7.9. These variants typically cause mild symptoms such as fever, cough, and throat irritation, which usually resolve on their own. Most individuals do not require medical treatment. Hence, citizens are advised not to panic and to follow the preventive measures listed below:

Precautions to be Taken in Public Places:

  • Practice proper cough etiquette (cover your mouth and nose while coughing or sneezing).
  • Do not spit in public places.
  • Senior citizens, people with comorbidities, and those with weakened immune systems should avoid crowded or poorly ventilated areas, or use face masks in such places.

Measures to Prevent Respiratory Illness:

1. Respiratory Hygiene

  • If you have a cold or cough, wear a triple-layer medical mask.
  • Always cover your mouth and nose with a handkerchief or tissue while coughing or sneezing.
  • Patients showing severe respiratory symptoms should self-monitor their health, and if symptoms like shortness of breath or chest pain occur, they should immediately seek medical attention at the nearest hospital.

2. Hand Hygiene

  • Wash hands frequently with soap and water or use hand sanitizer.
  • Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth without washing hands.
  • Avoid close contact with people who are unwell.

Who Should Get Tested for COVID-19?

Individuals with the following conditions should get tested for COVID-19 after consulting a qualified medical professional:

  • Acute respiratory infection with a history of fever (above 38°C) and cough lasting more than 10 days.
  • Patients requiring hospitalization due to respiratory illness.

This advisory is issued in public interest to ensure citizens remain informed, cautious, and safe. Let us all work together to stay healthy and prevent the spread of infection.

raw.title: Swachh Survekshan 2025 - Deep Cleaning Drive
summary:
Swachh Survekshan 2025 - Deep Cleaning Drive

July 12, 2025
Pune on the path of cleanliness, even at night!

The Solid Waste Management Department of Pune Municipal Corporation has launched night-time mechanical sweeping operations from 12th July 2025.

The formal inauguration was carried out by Hon. Municipal Commissioner Shri Naval Kishore Ram on the Swargate–Satara Road.

The event was attended by Additional Commissioners Shri Prithviraj B. P. and Shri Omprakash Divate, Deputy Commissioner (SWM) Shri Sandeep Kadam, Assistant Commissioners Smt. Surekha Bhange (Dhankawadi-Sahakarnagar) and Smt. Nalini Suryawanshi (Bibwewadi), along with officials from the health and engineering departments.
July 11, 2025
To ensure cleanliness in Pune, the PMC Commissioner conducted a midnight inspection. A total of 213 vehicles and 1,472 sanitation workers were deployed during the night shift. During the night, 188 metric tons of waste were collected.
July 03, 2025
A cleanliness rally was organized in Ambegaon Budruk by PMC's Dhanakwadi-Sahakarnagar ward office to raise awareness about sanitation. Citizens actively participated to support the cause of a cleaner Pune.
July 04, 2025
In line with Swachh Survekshan 2025, the Pune Municipal Corporation conducted the "Swachh Pune Abhiyan" and "Safai Apnao – Bimari Bhagao Abhiyan" on 04/07/2025 under the Bhavani Peth and Yerwada-Kalas-Dhanori Ward Offices. The Deep Cleaning Drive covered areas from Swargate Jedge Chowk to Cantonment Gate, Shankarsheth Road and flyover, and from Bombay Sappers Chandrama Chowk to Mental Corner.
July 03, 2025
As part of Swachh Survekshan 2025, the Pune Municipal Corporation organized a “Deep Cleaning Drive” under the Kasba-Vishrambaugwada Ward Office from Panchami Hotel on Satara Road to Swargate Chowk, and under the Shivajinagar-Ghole Road Ward Office covering the areas from Senapati Bapat Road to Chatushrungi Mandir, including Shivaji Housing Society and Vaiduwadi.

raw.title: Educational Schemes
summary:
!! Important notice !!

The Bharat Ratna Maulana Abul Kalam Azad Scheme for 10th-passed students by the Pune Municipal Corporation and the Lokshahir Annabhau Sathe Scheme for 12th-passed students are applicable only for the residents falling within the jurisdiction of the Pune Municipal Corporation. An advertisement regarding the scheme will be published on the official website, after which online forms will be available on the DBT website.

raw.title: Pandharichi Wari
summary:
Ashadhi Wari 2025 – Welcoming Ceremony

The festival of Ashadhi Wari, a unique and sacred spiritual tradition of Maharashtra, is celebrated with deep devotion every year. The Pandharpur Yatra, with the Palkhi processions of saints and thousands of Warkaris walking on foot while chanting the holy name of Lord Vitthal, represents the spiritual soul of our state.

This year, as always, the Palkhi of Shri Sant Tukaram Maharaj begins from Dehu, and the Palkhi of Shri Sant Dnyaneshwar Maharaj begins from Alandi, both headed towards Pandharpur. Lakhs of Warkaris are joining this divine pilgrimage, filled with devotion and dedication.

The Pune Municipal Corporation and all Punekars are fully prepared to welcome both Palkhis into Pune city with warmth, care and devotion. As the Warkaris begin their journey from the banks of the Indrayani River, their destination is the holy Chandrabhaga River at Pandharpur.

Important Dates:

Sant Dnyaneshwar Maharaj Palkhi

Friday, June 20th

Sant Tukaram Maharaj Palkhi

Friday, June 20th

Arrangements organized by PMC

The Pune Municipal Corporation is implementing all essential arrangements to ensure the smooth passage and stay of the Palkhis and Warkaris in the city

Medical Team

A medical team from Pune Municipal Corporation, along with both Palkhiis, will be present to serve the Warkaris.

Free First Aid

Some clinics on the Palkhi route will be open 24 hours for first aid. These clinics will provide free treatment to the Warkaris.

Arrangements for Rest

The PMC has made arrangements for rest at various places on the Palkhi route so that the Warkaris can rest.

Waterproof Tent and Toilet Facilities for Monsoon

Setup of waterproof tents and portable or mobile toilets to stay safe and clean during the rainy season.

Important Emergency Contact Numbers

Emergency Contact Dial Now for Immediate Assistance
02025506800 / 02025501269 / 02067801500
Women Helpline Dial Now for Immediate Assistance
1091
Police Dial Now for Immediate Assistance
100
Ambulance Dial Now for Immediate Assistance
102
Fire Brigade Dial Now for Immediate Assistance
101
PMC Care Dial Now for Immediate Assistance
+91 9146383383
Pune Municipal Corporation Dial Now for Immediate Assistance
1800 1030 222

All Punekars are kindly requested to extend heartfelt hospitality to the incoming Warkaris and participate in this spiritual journey. The chanting of Vitthal-Nama, devotional songs, and the spirit of togetherness reflect Pune's rich cultural and spiritual heritage.

More Information on Arrangement by PMC

Sant Dnyaneshwar Maharaj Palkhi Schedule – 2025

  • June 19: Departure from Alandi to Pandharpur at 8 PM with religious rituals and prayers
  • June 20–21: Stay in Pune City – Bhavani Peth
  • June 22–23: Saswad – Devotional programs and stay
  • June 24: Jejuri – Spiritual prayers and evening Bhajan
  • June 25: Walhe – Traditional offerings and community interaction
  • June 26: Lonand – Major rest and devotional singing
  • June 27: Tardgaon – First ringan at Chandobacha Limb, stay in Tardgaon
  • June 28: Phaltan – Spiritual activities and Kirtans
  • June 29: Barad – Rest and spiritual events
  • June 30: Natepute – Chanting Abhangas and Ovis of Sant Dnyaneshwar
  • July 1: Malshiras – First round ringan at Purandavade, stay at Malshiras
  • July 2: Khudus Phata – Second round ringan, stay at Velapur
  • July 3: Velapur – Third round ringan at Thakurbuwa Samadhi
  • July 4: Bhandishegaon – Second standing Ringan
  • July 5: Vakhri and arrival at Pandharpur – Final standing ringan at Vakhri
  • July 6: Ashadhi Ekadashi – Main festival and Darshan at Vitthal-Rukmini Temple

Sant Tukaram Maharaj Palkhi Schedule – 2025

  • June 18: Departure from Dehu to Pandharpur
  • June 19: Akurdi – Welcome to the Pimpri Chinchwad area
  • June 20–21: Pune City – Grand welcome with cultural and spiritual programs (Stop at Shri Vitthal Mandir, Nana Peth)
  • June 22: Loni Kalbhor – Bhakti Sammelan
  • June 23: Yavat – Participation of many Warkaris and Dindis
  • June 24: Varvand – Traditional prayers and short rest
  • June 25: Undavadi Gawlyachi – Spiritual discourses and stay
  • June 26: Baramati – Warm welcome from residents
  • June 27: Sansar – Devotional lectures, rest and cultural programs
  • June 28: Nimgaon Ketki – Singing of Abhangas and Kirtans of Saint Tukaram
  • June 29: Indapur – Rest stop
  • June 30: Sarati – Devotional singing and discourses
  • July 1: Akaluj – Round ringan at Akaluj
  • July 2: Borgaon – Stop at Malinagar, stay at Borgaon
  • July 3 and 4: Vakhri – Final major halt before Pandharpur
  • July 5: Arrival in Pandharpur – Final ringan and grand entry
  • July 6: Ashadhi Ekadashi – Main festival and Darshan at Vitthal-Rukmini Temple

Ashadhi Wari Arrives in Pune – June 20, 2025

The Ashadhi Wari arrived in Pune city on June 20, 2025. On this special occasion, Pune Municipal Commissioner Hon. Shri. Naval Kishore Ram, Additional Commissioner Hon. Shri. M. J. Pradeep Chandran, along with Shri. Prithviraj B. P. and Shri. Omprakash Divate, welcomed the Warkaris on behalf of the Pune Municipal Corporation. They also participated in the Dindi, showing their respect and support for the tradition.

raw.title: Maharashtra Right To Service Act 2015
summary:
The Maharashtra Right to Public Services Act, 2015 is enacted and is in force since 28/04/2015 to ensure that notified services are provided to the citizens in a transparent, speedy and time-bound manner by various Government Departments and Public Authorities under the Government. Its objective is to provide easy, prompt and time bound services to the citizens.

The Maharashtra State Commission for Right to Public Service has been constituted under the above Act to monitor, coordinate, control and improve the public services being provided by the Government. The Commission consists of a Chief Commissioner and six Commissioners. The headquarter of the Commission is at the New Administrative Building, Opposite Mantralaya, Mumbai and the Divisional Offices of the Commissioners are at the six Divisional Headquarters.

If any notified service is not provided to any eligible person within stipulated time or is rejected without proper grounds, the concerned person may file 1st and 2nd appeals with the higher authorities and if he is not satisfied with their decision, he may prefer third appeal to the Commission. The erring officer is liable for a penalty up to Rs. 5000/- per case. Notified Services rendered by this Department are as per enclosed proforma.

State Commission for Right to Services

raw.title: Bhama Askhed Project
raw.other_details:
Bhama Askhed Water Supply Scheme for the Eastern part of Pune City:

The scheme is designed for water supply of 200 MLD. It will cover 58 sq.km area of the eastern part of Pune city along the Nagar road for projected population of 14.50 lac up to 2041.

This project is sanctioned under JNNURM scheme of Govt. of India vide sanction letter no. K14012/2(123)/2006-NURM-III dated 5th July 2013 amounting to Rs. 380.16 Crores. The funding from details are as follows:

SourcePercentageAmount
Govt. of India50%Rs. 190.08 Cr.
Govt. of Maharashtra20%Rs. 76.03 Cr.
PMC30%Rs. 114.051 Cr.
Total100%Rs. 380.16 Cr.

We have received two installments from GOI & GOM as mentioned below. The proposal for release of the 3rd installment has been sent to the Govt. of India.

S.No.SourceAmount
1Govt. of India (GOI)Rs. 76.03 Cr
2Govt. of Maharashtra (GOM)Rs. 30.40 Cr.
TotalRs. 106.43 Cr.

Bhama Askhed Water Supply Scheme is divided in 6 Package as below:

Package No.NameEstimated Cost
1Construction of Jackwell & Pump HouseRs. 54.89 Cr.
2Providing & Laying Raw Water M.S. PipelineRs. 127.44 Cr.
3Construction of Water Treatment Plant at KuruliRs. 58.68 Cr.
4Providing & Laying Pure Water M.S. PipelineRs. 70.77 Cr.
5Providing & Laying Feeder Main PipelineRs. 55.08 Cr.
6Construction of 7 Nos. of ESR of 2 ML Capacity EachRs. 12.69 Cr.

The up to date expenditure is Rs. 172.00 Cr. The work was stopped by local MLA & farmers for their various demands from Oct 2015. These demands were concerned with the Govt. of Maharashtra. After the meeting with Hon. Chief Minister (Govt. of Maharashtra) on 13 / 05 / 2016 and continuous follow up with the State Govt Departments and officials, most of the demands were fulfilled and work was restarted from June 2016. Work on the raw water rising pipeline (8 KM) from Bhama Askhed Dam to BPT at Bhamboli is still stopped by Local MLA.

Our target completion date is 31 July, 2017 and all the contractors are notified of the same. Weekly project review meetings are held with the contractors to ensure proposed timelines are met.

raw.title: Eco-Friendly crematorium
raw.other_details:
Various crematoriums of Pune Municipal Corporation offer options for cremation using electric cremation, gas cremation, and the traditional method of cremation using wood.


ELECTRICAL CREMATORIUM

Electrical Crematorium consists of :

  1. Moveable Trolley
  2. Furnace
  3. Gas Cleaning System with Venture Scrubber
  4. Chimney 100 feet
  5. Controls

Functioning of Electrical Crematorium :

  • The beginning process of cremation in the Electric Cremation is called incineration.
  • The furnace or incinerator is a high powered furnace.
  • The body will be located in a combustion chamber called a retort.The crematory(also known as retort) is lined with refractory bricks that can withstand high fluctuations in temperature, but furnace chambers also have holes at the bottom.
  • The Electric crematorium is built with double chamber cremation furnace with a strong cremation bed and secondary air holes.
  • In the Electric Crematorium, the electrical connections do not need any particular fittings and a simple 220 Volts electrical outlet is all that is required.
  • Electric cremation furnace capacity is 54 Kw. The Electric heating coil is made up of NICROME 80/20 in the form of 25 mm dia coil with terminal rods and the entire furnace heating coil system (Coil holding brick wall) will be bonded with the side walls.
  • The cremation furnace is constructed with high quality alumina refractory bricks, fire bricks, insulation bricks, arch bricks, various size and types of slabs and bonded with high quality castable, fire clay and mortars with a specific type of curing to the furnace to withstand the temperature up to 1200 degree centigrade.
  • The fitting of devices that prevent any dispersion from the cremation chamber have eliminated smoke and odors.
  • The cremation gets completed in about 60 to 90 minutes maximum depend upon the body size and other biological reasons.
  • The hazardous gas and other substances are piped out from cremation chamber and cleaned by venture scrubber with water treatment and finally the hot air is being discharged into 100 feet height chimney.
  • Electric Crematorium system has necessary controls,auto on-off, cut off switches and other necessary controls for the safety of cremation.

    GAS CREMATORIUM
  • LPG Gas Crematorium consists of :
  •        1. Cremation Furnace
  •        2. LPG Gas Combustion System with Venture Scrubber
  •        3. Chimney 100 feet
  •        4. Controls
  •     5. The LPG gas automatic burners are built with fan, motor, pump, ignition transformer and electrode, flame sensor, sequence controller, gas solenoid valve, air pressure switch and gas pressure switch
  • Functioning Of Gas Crematorium :
  • A movable trolley places the body in the cremation platform in cremation furnace of the LPG Gas Crematorium.
  • Combustion blowers and air blowers are switched on and then the primary and secondary burners in the cremation chambers switched on to get the furnace temperature at about 850 degree.
  • By the movable trolley the body will be placed upon the cremation platform in the cremation chamber. The cremation door would then keep closed in the LPG Gas Crematorium.
  • LPG Gas Crematorium consists of primary and secondary chambers.
  • The LPG Gas crematorium is built with double chamber cremation furnace with a strong cremation bed and secondary air holes. The cremation furnace is constructed with high quality alumina refractory bricks, fire bricks, insulation bricks, arch bricks, various size and types of slabs and bonded with high quality castable, fire clay and mortars with a specific type of curing to the furnace to withstand the temperature up to 1200 degree centigrade.
  • The body, would incinerate in the primary and the secondary chamber between the temperature 850 and 1100 degree and the cremation get completed in about 60 to 90 minutes maximum depend upon the body size and other biological reasons.
  • Gas Cleaning System is also equipped with venture scrubber.
  • The hazardous gas and other substances are piped out from cremation chamber and cleaned by venture scrubber with water treatment and finally the hot air is being discharged into the 100 feet height chimney.
  • LPG Gas Crematorium system has the ash collection system to collect ash and remains for further customs.
  • LPG Gas Crematorium system has necessary controls,auto on-off, cut off switches and other necessary controls for a safety LPG gas crematorium.
  • The automatic LPG gas burners can be hooked with external control signal for total automation like PLC system, burner trip signal for alarm and hooter can be given from the burner sequence controller and burner fan can be by passed with a separate switch without any modification.

Air pollution control system

The department has installed air pollution control system at various crematoriums in Pune. This is the alternative to traditional open burning system. The basic function of the system is to reduce the pollution. The gas produced after burning the body is passed through a water-scrubber where its carbon content gets absorbed and filtered gas is released into air. By use of this system, approximately 40 percent wood saving (in crematorium) could be achieved. The system is in place at Vaikuntha, Hadapsar, Dhankawadi, Katraj, Yerewada and Kailas crematoriums.

raw.title: Water Purification at Parvati
raw.other_details:
• Capacity : 500 million litres per day
  • Pre-calculated / Estimation Sheet Amount : Amount of Rs. 17906 lakhs
  • Tender Amount : Amount of Rs. 1,61,10,00,000
  • Contractor : M’S Degrimont Ltd.
  • Word Order : Outward No. 2017, dated 07.02.14

Nature of Work:

There exists a water purification plant with a capacity of 535 million litres per day at Parvati, Sr. No. 121 and 122. From the said water purification plant, water is predominantly supplied to the centralized area of Pune city and vicinity of S.N.D.T. and Chaturshringi areas. The water purification plant in the Cantonment with a capacity of 360 million litres per day is about 125 years old and the life of the old tanks have mostly come to an end and hence, it is of utmost importance that the said water purification plant be rebuilt. This water purification plant is within the limits of the Cantonment and there is no place available next to the existing water purification plant to build a new water purification plant, and there is no possibility of getting any land in the Cantonment area. Hence, an alternative arrangement needs to be looked upon.

Quotations have been invited for an amount of Rs. 17,906 lakhs (approved project cost + repairs and maintenance cost) for the construction of a water purification plant with a capacity of 500 million litres per day, construction of a clear water pumping station and recycling plant next to the existing water purification plant in Parvati, Pune, to make a plan for all this work, to construct, to test-run it, to operationalize it successfully, and to run it with repairs and maintenance for the next 5 years. From among the quotations  received, the quotation of contractor, M/s. Degrimont Ltd., who submitted the lowest of all quotations, of an amount of Rs. 1,61,10,00,000/-, has been approved as per R. No. 2103 dated 13/1/14 of the Hon. Standing Committee. Accordingly, an work order as per Outward No. 2017, dated 07.02.14 has been given to the contractor, M/s. Degrimont Ltd. The duration for the said work is 30 months plus 5 years for repairs and maintenance.

Proposed scheme of the new project and benefits from the Project : 

It has been planned to construct a new water purification plant of a capacity of 500 million litres per day at Parvati by demolishing the existing water purificatio plant of a capacity of 360 million litres per day at Cantonment. The existing water purification plant at Parvati  is nearly 40 years old and as some parts of it needs repairs on a large scale, it has been planned that if Step / Stage no. 1 from the said plant is demolished, the remaining 200 MLD capacity can be used as an alternative source for this part. While the old water purification plant with the capacity of 360 million litres per day situated in Cantonment is being completely demolished and rebuilt, it is possible to supply water from the proposed water purification plant.

For the said water station, a provision of taking water from the raw water, with a diameter of 2,500 mm, that has been laid from Khadakwasla dam up to the Parvati water station and also from a line of 1500 mm diameter from the raw water of Parvati water station has been made. M/s. Shah Technical Consultants are working as technical consultants for the said work.

The main units within the Project :

It includes construction of the said proposed water purification plant of a capacity of 500 million litres per day, to build a pure water sump well, to construct a recycling plant etc.

Most of the unit work from the said water purification plant has been initiated; out of which, more than 70% of the work of the units of filter bed, pulsar tube, annex building, sub station, pure water sump well, wash water recovery tank, sludge thickener has been completed. After the hutments on the said area were removed on 22/03/2016 by the Regional Office, possession of the said area was taken up and immediately the work regarding the units of the water station at the said area has been started. Also, by the end of August 2016, an amount of Rs.101 crores has been spent.

raw.title: Widening of Tarkareshwar Bridge and Development of T-Junction at Yerwada
raw.other_details:
Project Overview:

The widening of the Tarkareshwar Bridge and the development of the T-Junction at Yerwada will help reduce traffic congestion and improve connectivity in the area.

Key Information:

  • Contractor: M/s. Tirupati Construction.
  • Approval: Standing Committee Resolution No. 541 (Dated: 08/09/2023)
  • Work Order No: J.O. No. 2607 (Dated: 26/09/2023)
  • Estimated Cost: ₹6,55,76,902.26
  • Approved Budget: Resolution No. 82 (Dated: 23/06/2022)
  • Tender Amount: ₹5,46,16,136.28
  • Project Duration: 12 months
  • Approved Tender Amount: ₹4,45,39,459.13 + GST (18.45%)

Project Benefits:

Upon completion, the project will significantly reduce traffic congestion on the Yerwada side of the Tarkareshwar Bridge, ensuring smoother traffic flow.

Technical Details:

  • Installation of railings
  • Concrete work (Grades M-40, M-35, M-30, M-15)
  • RCC Railings (M-30)
  • Mastic work
  • Installation of signboards
  • Use of structural steel

Updated information on project progress will be available soon!

raw.title: Pune Okayama Japanese Style Friendship Garden
raw.address: Sr. No. 537, Sinhagad Road, Pune
raw.body:
Pune Okayama friendship garden is a symbol of Indo-Japanese friendship between partner cities of Pune and Okayama and the garden is truly the pride of Pune. It is the biggest Japanese style garden, out of Japan, in Asia. The idea of recreating the original Japanese garden in Pune was, of course, inspired from the 300-year old Okayama Korakuen Garden developed by the Ikeda Royal family in the 12 spacious hectares in Okayama

The Japanese garden is spread over an area of 10 acres, representing the culture and intricate ideology of an authentic Japanese Garden. This garden is a perfect bridge between to cities of Okayama and Pune, encouraging cultural, traditional, economic, industry and friendship ties.

The garden is named after eminent Marathi litterateur Purushottam Laxman Deshpande, who was popularly known as Pu La Deshpande.
raw.entry_details:
• For children: ₹5
  • For adults: ₹10
  • Monthly pass: ₹100
  • For foreign nationals: ₹50

    Open all 7 days
raw.key_attractions:
• Harmonious Experience: The garden is planned in such a way that it gives the visitors a pleasing experience throughout the year. As a person strolls, he/she can enjoy the wide lawns, ponds, artificial hills, and forest, while listening to the murmur of a meandering stream. This brings one close to nature, revitalizes one's senses, and rejuvenates one spiritually. Characteristics of the garden are a composition of fire, harmony, line, spirit, world, and water. Thus, the garden expresses various elements, such as light and darkness, soft and hard, stillness and motion, and warm and cold.  There are wooden pergolas to sit and rest. There are bright red-orange fish in the ponds.
  • Unique Japanese Garden Theme: The only Japanese garden in India, inspired by the culture and concept of Japanese gardens.
  • Design Based on Zen Philosophy: Modeled after the Koraquan Garden in Okayama, Japan.
  • Grand Greenery: Lush, expansive greenery throughout the park.
  • Large Pond: A tranquil pond filled with multi-colored fishes.
  • Serpentine Streams: Flowing streams that enhance the natural beauty.
  • Diverse Bird Population: Home to numerous crows, other birds, and insects.
  • Indigenous and Foreign Trees: A mix of native and exotic tree species.
  • Six Pagodas: Beautiful pagodas made of mahogany wood.
  • Mesmerizing Waterfalls: Scenic waterfalls adding to the park's charm.
  • Open Surroundings: A peaceful environment that helps relieve tension.
raw.timings:
• Morning 6:00 AM to 11:00 AM
  • Evening 4:00 PM to 9:00 PM
